Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.
(WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND)

April 15, 1934.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

To salary for Manual Training teacher for the months January, February & March $120.00

[Signature]
Victor Rassier
Principal
Christie Indian Residential School

Kakawis, B.C.

(WEST COAST VANCOUVER AND)

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 28th ultimo, file number 159-0-11, I am submitting the following report on vocational training at Christie School as therein requested:

(a) Instruction:
(1) Instructor in the mechanics of gasoline engine: Mr. Don Stevens, age 35; five years with the electrical contractors Hawkins & Hayward, Ltd., of Victoria, B.C.; two years with the boat-builder and marine engine expert, H.F. Stephens of the same city.
(2) Instructor in Manual Training: August Barlage, age 27; served his full time as an apprentice in Germany;
(3) Assistant to above: August Olthoff, age 35; holds several certificates and diplomas of courses taken in Germany.

(b) Industries:
(1) Industries taught: mechanics of gasoline engine & manual training;
(2) Number of pupils in these classes: 13;
(3) Number of hours weekly each pupil engaged: about an average of 10 hours, explanation of which is contained in information requested as to how the school is carrying out instructions of March 16, 1934.

(c) General Remarks: Our experience has been that the average pupil is very much interested, realizes the advantage such instruction means to him, and is eager to reap profit from his opportunity. I am convinced that results obtained justify the expenditure that is being made, and I could not help but look upon it as being most unfortunate as far as the Indians of this portion of the West Coast are concerned, should the Department decide to discontinue the course. A relative proficiency in the use of carpenter tools and a working knowledge of the mechanics of the gasoline engine is as indispensable to the male Indian, and, therefore, as necessarily a part of his education, as a knowledge of cooking, housekeeping and sewing are to the Indian women. To teach him to farm would be wasted effort, farming being out of the question for him because of the nature of the terrain and the climate. Even so much as keeping a milk-cow is quite impossible because of his prolonged absence from the village in which he lives the greater part of the time to secure his staple article of food in the inlets where fish abound. But his dwelling must be erected, and repairs to it and to his trolling-launch upon which he must depend to a great extent for his livelihood must be made by himself. The care of, and very frequently the repairs to, the engine in his launch, are details he himself must, because of his poverty, take care of.
For the explanation to "(b)", and a reply to your inquiry as to the carrying out of the instructions contained in the circular letter of March 18, 1931, permit me to submit the following:

Certain conditions at Christie School were so deplorable, and the need for their correction so imperative, that something simply had to be done about them, and done immediately. During the summer of 1932, on a visit to Ottawa, I presented the state of affairs to the late Mr. Farrier with a view to obtaining assistance from the Department. I was made to realize the financial crises existing precluded for some years hope of assistance in any form. Taking counsel with myself on returning to the school, I decided that the only course left for me to pursue was to strive for a solution of my problems by directing to the task every available bit of energy on the premises, and by economizing to the bone in every department so that funds for materials might not be lacking. I had recourse principally to the teachers of the industries, and gave them instructions to proceed co-operatively in the work to be done with not only the members of their classes, but with all the boys available during the half day period set aside for other than class activities; but so arranging the work that as much compensation as circumstances permitted might be made to the former for the work that would have been done in the training classes. That an idea may be gained as to what form that compensation took, and to what extent, consequently, the plan can merit your approval, a detailed list of the work accomplished follows:

(1) Buildings erected: sheep-shed, bakery and engine house, seating stand and dressing rooms at football field, excavation and concrete floor and walls for coal storage;

(2) Machinery, etc., installed: bake-oven, dough-mixer, gasoline engine;

(3) Repairs made: to roof, floors, steps and stairs; parts of water main replaced and others mended; freight launch caulked, overhauled and painted; engine over-hauled, freight boat overhauled, caulked and painted;

(4) Improvements made: faulty electric light wiring throughout entire building removed (the fire hazard was appalling) and replaced with a system that leads via porcelain tubes and loco through joists between ceilings and floors and within walls and all wire joints welded; remodelling of building: boys' bath room and rain-apparel room, bread-store room, girls' cloak and shoe room, boys' clothing room, boys' class room, chicken house; fire alarm installed; entire incline at front of building cleared of stumps and underbrush (necessary to locate certain sewer outlets); entire drainage system of surrounding grounds inspected and mended; necessary as basement and boys' wash room continually being flooded; concrete floor laid in front of kitchen; all board walks on premises replaced and added to; tubs and clothes wracks in laundry and necessary piping installed; painting: entire exterior of all buildings given a first coat (work interrupted by rain season) and large part of interior (work still in progress); football and play-ground filled in with dirt, evened off, seeded with grass, and draining ditches dug (heavy work previously performed by paid help); board walk at field, drinking fountain, mens' and women's toilets, fencing made from cedar logs and fence therefrom round football field constructed; bread-proofer and accompanying heating system made and installed; fences constructed: around sheep enclosure, chicken run, garden.
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.
(WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND)

The Secretary Page Three

(5) Cabinets, tables, etc., constructed: Girls' dormitory: 86 feet of lockers, towel racks; boys' dormitory: 16 feet of lockers; private rooms: 5 clothes lockers; sewing room: 2 lockers and large table with drawers; girls' dining room: cabinet for dishes and utensils, combination sink and cabinet, 7 tables; kitchen: elaborate 5'3" x 8'2" combination table and cabinet, sinks remodelled; bakery: 2'7" x 7'7" combination cabinet and table, dough trough, store room; Sisters' community room: community table with drawers; boys' dinning room: 3 tables, ten benches, combination cabinet and sink.

In the same manner I propose to do the following: (1) replace hot water boiler in laundry with steam boiler (necessary because with present arrangement impossible to dry clothes); remodel and re-adapt clothes drier; (2) excavate space for a boys' toilet, construct same of concrete and install a range of 6 toilets; (4) lay three to four hundred feet of sewer pipe of a diameter large enough to take all sewage and drain conduits (now finding outlet at several places); (5) repair slip and track, construct freight house at the terminal on beach and house for hoist at upper end; (6) repair workman's house; (7) wrap all main pipes of heating system with asbestos insulation; (8) replace floors of large part of main building; (9) cover with sufficient earth large portions of exposed main water line to provide necessary protection. This we wish to accomplish before the termination of this school year, and our hopes are that routine training classes can be resumed at the opening of school after the summer holidays. Of course, continuing in this manner is contingent on the Department's approval. School inspector Barry has written me his intentions to inspect the school on April 25th. A copy of this letter will be given him and a check-up of its statements invited.

As regards the girls' department, we feel that, judging from the encouraging manner in which the homes of ex-pupils in the villages are being conducted, the course of instructions and practical work given the girls in sewing, cooking, housekeeping, cleanliness and the rudimentary knowledge of caring for the sick, is quite satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
(Rev.) Victor Rassier, O.S.B.,
Principal
Ottawa, February 28, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

As soon as possible after March 31st next, you should forward to the Department a detailed report regarding the vocational training that is given at the Christie Residential School. This report should contain the following information:

(a) Instruction: Name, age and qualifications of instructor or instructors.

(b) Industries: Under this heading you should specify the industries taught, the number of pupils in each industry, number of hours weekly that each pupil is engaged, and list of work accomplished during the period April 1, 1933, to March 31, 1934.

(c) General Remarks: Under this heading you should state if the pupils are interested, and if you consider the results that are being obtained justify the expenditure that is being made.

If you feel that the value of the course could be improved, you should state in what manner you believe this could be done.

In addition to the above, you should let me know what is being done at your school to carry out the instructions contained in circular letter of March 15, 1931, a copy of which is enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. Victor Nassier, O.S.B.,
Principal,
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakawis, B.C.

Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith a letter in duplicate, dated July 28th, ultimo, received from Mr. Indian Agent Frost of West Coast Agency, in which he recommends the purchase of lumber for the purpose of manual training classes at the Christie Indian Residential School, Kakowis, B.C., as requested by Reverend Principal Rossier. An Abstract of tenders, in duplicate, is sent herewith which will indicate that I have obtained tenders for this material from firms on the local list for consideration, the tender of Messrs. Cameron Lumber Company Ltd., of Victoria, being the lowest at $75.48. I would recommend the Department's favourable consideration of this requisition and tender.

Your obedient servant,

C. C. Perry,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of March 3rd, with reference to a building for Manual Training,

We are pleased to note that you have awarded us $2500.00 for this purpose. At present I cannot just see how we can construct the building I have in mind for this amount on money, but we will do the best we can.

I am drawing the plans, but do not contemplate building until some time in June when the boys will have returned to school. It is our intention to use the construction of this building in the practical course of carpenter work for those who are old enough to benefit by it. Our regular working staff will also assist, but, together with this, it will be necessary to employ at least one competent carpenter who can remain constantly on the job. Without this last arrangement the construction would drag on through too long a period of time.

We have already communicated with Mr. Ashbridge, and we will be pleased to follow your instructions in referring all details to him. Again I thank you very kindly for this material assistance. We only hope that our children will be able to derive the benefits from this development that we now contemplate.

Yours very truly,

(Hildegard Melchior)

Reverend Sir:

I have recently received a copy of Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Christie Residential School on March 21.

The Inspector reported very favourably on general conditions at the school but I feel that a more competent person could be secured as manual training instructor.

I trust that you will be able to advise me in the near future that you have found it possible to replace Mr. Leslie by someone who has a better general knowledge, at least, of the duties of manual training instructor.

April 7, 1938.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report of March 21, 1938:

As previously reported Scientific Manual Training is not taught here. The boys just carry out various repairs around the school.

The present Manual Training Instructor if he may be called this is a Mr. J. P. Leslie, who describes himself to me as a carpenter and farmer from Alberta.

I am informed by the Reverend Principal that the Department has sanctioned the erection of a modern Manual Training Shop. I certainly hope that when this shop is built there will be some attempt at the teaching of Manual Training as far as the construction of those articles which are needed around the school and homes of the Indians. I pointed out to Mr. Leslie that he could at least teach the repair of the broken chairs now in the Manual Training Shed. He did not appear to me to understand what was required of him.

The statement of the Reverend Principal with regard to Manual Training which I have added to this report as Page 6 would lead the Department to believe that much good work was being done in this Department. This is not so in my opinion. I think the Indian Agent might well keep his eye on the Manual Training at this school and later in 1938 report to the Department what steps have been taken to improve this part of the school activities. I know that he is not at present satisfied with the work being done and I agree with him.

The girls have a much better course in Vocational Work as they of necessity must learn to cook, wash, iron, mend, darn, patch, sew etc.

Gerald Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

May 2, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

The following is an extract from the annual report of Mr. F. B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent for the West Coast Agency:

"Due to existing conditions on the Coast making it imperative that Indians seek other than their natural source of livelihood, it is respectfully recommended that manual training and domestic science be conducted on more practical lines. At present the girls are taught fancy sewing and are employed in kitchens, both admirable in their way, but they should be taught how to make fishing nets and the operation of canning machinery, also how to wash without the aid of electric washing machines, and the baking of bread without electric bakeries. They should also be taught simple home nursing, hygiene, and kindred subjects.

"Boys should be taught practical boat building and operation of marine engines. These Indians are natural mechanics and could very easily be taught under a competent instructor. Every year these Indians lose hundreds of dollars owing to shipping furs not properly prepared, and this art could be taught to advantage."

I expect that you will give these your careful consideration as their adoption would result in the pupils receiving the practical training that they require.

Rev. H. Melchior, O.S.B.,
Principal,
Christie Residential School,
Kakawis, B. C.
It will not be possible for the Department to continue indefinitely paying per capita grant unless we receive definite assurance that the curriculum has been arranged in a manner that will ensure the pupils being taught those subjects which will best fit them for their after-school life.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

In answer to your communication of April 9, 1938-0-11, relative to Manual Training Instructor at Christie Indian Residential School,

I would say that in compliance with your request and on recommendation from Inspector Barry, and also some complaint from the Indian Agent, Mr. Ashbridge, we have, with the close of school, released Mr. Leslie.

However I would say for Mr. Leslie that we found him to be a very fine man around the boys and very patient. We believe that he did his work very well with the facilities with which he had to work. Furthermore he was not alone in this work, but others of the faculty bridged it over on occasion.

I am in hopes that our next man will be able to carry on in the new building in a way that will be completely satisfactory to the Department.

Dec. 15th, 1938

Mr R A Hoey,
Director of Welfare and Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr Hoey:

All of us here wish you a merry Christmas and a happy New Year.

Things in general seem to be going smoothly although there is the occasional jolt and bump. The children are in good health and apparently satisfied. If we can keep this up, we should have a full school before long.

We have had to do a good deal of repair work, to install another boiler, etc., and have been working steadily on our celebrated trail. It is about half a mile long and when it is completed it will help solve some of our freighting problems. We have no tractor, horses or scraper and all has therefore to be done by hand. The work is fairly well advanced. Rain has kept us from doing more.

I am very pleased that the Department has found it possible to give us the necessary materials to put up a manual training shop. It will be divided into two main rooms, the one for carpentry and the other for machine work. The boys need to know a little about carpentry and even more about repairing and adjusting engines. I have been unable to find a man who was both a qualified mechanic and a competent carpenter and have, therefore, had to employ two men. I hope that the Department will be able to grant $40.00 per month towards the salary of each. This request may seem a bit odd but one should remember that we are not in the Cariboo where the boys could and did work both inside and outside during the winter. Here, during the rainy season, there can be no outside work and, so, they have hitherto had to neglect manual training on rainy days or spend the morning and afternoon in the classroom. If we have only a carpenter or a mechanic, he cannot sufficiently supervise and train twenty or thirty boys. The solution is to have both a carpenter and a mechanic and to divide the boys between them.

Another thing that I hope to do is this: when everything is organized, the Indians could bring their engines, etc., here and work on them under the direction of the mechanic or leave their engine to be attended to by the mechanic and the boys and thus save them money.

I have further plans with regard to fishing and to train the boys along this line but there are certain angles which I wish to discuss with the Indian Agent (who, by the way, has been very courteous and helpful) before mentioning it to the Department.

We have a small canning machine but our boiler was in such a state that I have not yet set up the machine. I hope to give the girls a little training in canning. I have discussed the question of making nets with the Indians and find that it is not practical. It may be practical to have the pupils learn to mend fishing nets.

Again wishing you the best of everything at Christmas and during the coming year,

Yours sincerely,

I enclose purchase requisitions for lumber and other materials required for the erection of a new vocational training building at the Christie Indian Residential School.

The closest source of supply to this school is Fort Alberni, B.C., from which point there are direct boat connections to the Christie school.

As it is desired to erect this building before the rainy season starts I should appreciate it if you would arrange for the immediate purchase and shipment of the articles listed on the attached requisitions.

Director.
Ottawa,
November 17, 1938.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Christie Indian Residential School, West Coast Indian Agency, Electoral District of Kemox-Alberni.

The amount of $2,500.00 was included in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new vocational training building at the Christie Indian Residential School.

A competent carpenter-foreman is required to supervise the erection of this building and the Principal estimates that he will have to be paid approximately $200.00 for the period his services are required. The balance of the labour is being supplied free of cost to the Department by the school management. I should, therefore, appreciate it if you would let me know as soon as possible whom you desire employed. The Indian Agent advises that the erection of this building should commence immediately in order that it may be completed before the rainy season starts.

The requisitions for materials are going forward to the Purchasing Agent.

For your information I may add that P.C. 321 of April 25, 1936, authorized the expenditure of the amounts provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvement and purchasing new equipment at Church owned Indian Residential Schools. The Christie Residential School comes in this class and the amount specifically provided for this school, namely $2,500.00, was included in the Order-in-Council just mentioned.

Director.

Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.
(WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND)
Jan. 4th, 1939

Mr. R. Adams,
Superintendent and Training Division,
Dept. of Mines and Resources.

Dear Mr. Adams:

I wish to thank you for your recent letter and also for the increase of the grant towards the salaries of the instructors in manual training. We are ready to begin work on the vocational shop as soon as the material arrives.

Two of our older girls are engaged and will be married at Easter. On that account, I would like to exempt them from further attendance in the classroom so that they may devote all their time to cooking, sewing, mending and similar things. I used to do that while in charge of the Cariboo School and I had the permission of the Department to do it. Would you please let me know if the Department approves of my plans?

We had an enjoyable Christmas with toys, nuts, candy, etc. The children had two concerts, a party and other amusements which kept them happy. I am pleased to say that all appear to be in good health and seem to be doing fairly well in class.

With every best wish for the New Year,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of February 1 with reference to the erection of the new vocational training building at the Christie Indian residential school.

As requested, a record of Mr. Bond's pay list will be forwarded to your office as soon as received.

The material supplied up to the present time was secured from the following firms:

Messrs Mitchell & Fowler, Tofino, B.C., purchase order No. 9340, December 29, 1938.

Director.
Ottawa,
February 4, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of November 9, 1938, in connection with the erection of the vocational training building at the Christie Indian residential school.

In the second paragraph of that letter you stated that the school management would supply all the common labour but that it would be necessary to employ a master carpenter the estimated cost of whose services was $200.00.

In official letter of November 30, 1938, you were instructed to employ Mr. W.E. Bond of Tofino as carpenter-foreman.

Please let me know how this work is progressing and if Mr. Bond is still employed you should state the approximate length of time his services will have to be retained.

When forwarding request for payment for his work a detailed pay list should accompany your voucher giving the exact dates on which he was employed.

As mentioned in my letter of November 30 the Department understood that the only labour for which we would be obliged to pay would be Mr. Bond's services. Please let me know at once if I was correct in this inference.

Yours truly,

F. B. Ashbridge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B. C.

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
MEMORANDUM

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Feb. 1, 1938

Christie Indian Residential School,
West Coast Agency.
re- new Vocational Training Building.

I understand the new Vocational Training Building is now under construction, Mr. W.E. Bond of Tofino, carpenter-foreman, supervising the work.

When the work is completed, will you please have the Indian Affairs Branch furnish this office with the following information:

(a) A record of Mr. Bond's pay list, including his own and any others he may have employed.

(b) Names of firms from whom materials and other supplies were purchased, with amounts paid.

Dr. McGill -

For information as requested.

W.J.F. Pratt
Private Secretary.
Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant regarding certain girls at the Christie school who will be discharged at Easter it is considered that it would be advisable to exempt them from further attendance in the class room. They should devote all their remaining time in the school to vocational training.

Yours truly,

H. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. G. Forbes, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Kakawis, B. C.

Dear Mr. Neill:

I am in receipt of your letter of July 14 regarding the erection of a manual training building at the Christie Indian residential school, Nahsis, B.C.

The lumber, shingles, windows and doors were purchased by the Department from the Alberni Pacific Lumber Co., Ltd., Port Alberni, B.C. The total cost of the material, including delivery to the school, was $857.00.

The only labour for which the Department paid was the services of Mr. W. E. Bond who was employed from March 6 to March 31 and was paid a total amount of $140.00.

The building is now completed and in use.

Memorandum:

Mr. R. A. Hoey,

With reference to your requisition of the 20th instant, your file H.159-0-11, with attached quotations on material for the Christie Indian Residential School, Kakawis, B.C., I may say that the following additional data is needed to assist us in placing the order for same:

1. Items 1 and 2 - lathe and table.

There is considerable variation in the price and kind of machinery offered by the two Vancouver firms quoting. It would assist us in dealing with these two items, and in securing additional competition, if you could send us a description or more exact specification of the type of lathe and bench table needed.

2. 250 feet 8" x 6" x 25' common fir.

How many lengths are required? Do you require 250 feet board measure, or 250 lineal feet? All three firms tendering quote on a different quantity.

3. Paint.

The firms quoting do not advise definitely as to the brand, grade, or name of manufacturer of the paint they offer. I consider that a good grade, manufactured by a reliable paint firm should be supplied. There is no information on the requisition or tenders as to whether some of the items will be used for inside, or outside, work.
4. Oak.- Item 3.

Only one quotation was received on the 200 feet of rough oak, 2" x 4" x 16'. Here, again, there is some doubt as to whether 200 feet board measure, or 200 lineal feet, are actually required. The price, $450.00 per thousand feet board measure f.o.b., Kleecoot, B.C., seems rather high. Would a less expensive hardwood answer the purpose?

5. From information available, it does not appear that Commissioner MacKay made any recommendation regarding this proposed purchase. This is regrettable, particularly regarding the lathe and table, which he could have inspected at Vancouver with a view to standardizing, in so far as possible, on machinery of uniform type and make for use in Vocational Training Schools.

In telephone communication with your office, the question of the advisability of authorizing Commissioner MacKay to make the best possible arrangements for local purchase of the material requisitioned was considered. Before authorizing this method of procedure, however, I should appreciate your views. If the additional information outlined above is supplied this office, I shall be pleased to arrange to complete the purchase.

W. H. Bailey
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA
Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular Agency Letter, covering conditions within this Agency during the month ending January 31st, 1941.

Schools:

Christie Residential School was thoroughly inspected and found to be in first class order.

Fire drill was carried out very satisfactorily. All fire fighting appliances were in good order.

The pupils were all in splendid health and were clean, well clothed, well fed, attentive and industrious. Splendid progress is being made in vocation training.

Girls were being taught wool combing, carding, spinning and knitting, and are producing first class sweaters, socks, etc., through every process from sheep shearing to the finished article. In addition they are being taught needlework, cooking etc.

The boys are being instructed in boat building and repairs, marine engine operation and repair, carpentry etc. Splendid progress is also shown in physical training, and both boys and girls gave a creditable display of gymnastics.

Outhouses, boiler room and laundry were all in first class order. General condition of the school was very good.

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Philip Phelan

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I received a letter a few days ago from Father Forbes at the Cranbrook School. He spoke of the merit of your Mr. Doucet and the courses he laid out in manual training.

He said that the Carpentry course given by him was excellent. A Carpenter who saw the course said that even without an instructor a boy following that course could become proficient in that line.

Would it be possible for you to send me a copy of this course and one in mechanics. We certainly need all the assistance we can get in this line because it is almost impossible to hire a skilled worker. War work seems to have swallowed all the Mechanics and Carpenters.

If you cannot secure

REPORT ON WEST COAST INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

Schools.

Christie Residential School was also found in first class order.

New classrooms and addition to dormitory have been completed, and make a decided improvement. All classrooms, dormitories, kitchens, etc., were clean and tidy. Also basements, outbuildings and grounds.

Health of the School is excellent, and all pupils are happy and contented.

Excellent training is being given both boys and girls. Boys are being taught boat building and practical carpentry, and girls are taught needle and bead work, darning and mending, also the making of their own dresses, while all are given instruction in cooking and general domestic science.

MEMORANDUM TO THE INDIAN COMMISSIONER FOR B.C.

Re: Christie Indian Residential School

On the occasion of my recent visit to the above-mentioned School I discussed with the Reverend Principal the possibility of the establishment of a more comprehensive course for boat building. You are aware that this School has previously constructed three launches, one a deep-sea troller which is now used by the School as a freight boat and two smaller light cabin launches.

The Principal states that, in order for work of this nature to be carried on efficiently and so that boats of the size required for fishing on the west coast of Vancouver Island might be constructed, a boat shed would be required located so as to give easy access to the water. He has submitted a list of the materials required for this work amounting to $680, a copy of which is attached. This appears to be very reasonable. The present boat shed is too small to permit the construction of the type of boat which would make this project practical. It is also located behind the School some 200 or 300 yards from the water. The finished boats have to be moved this distance down a very steep incline to the water's edge. This is both a difficult and dangerous operation. The construction of the shed will be undertaken by the boys under the direction of the boat builder now in the employ of the School. I believe that this scheme will provide useful instruction and will be self-supporting as there should be no difficulty in finding a ready market for the boats. The Reverend Principal has had considerable dealings with the fishing industry before his
appointment to his present position. I understand he was primarily responsible for the organization of the Indian Co-operative known as the "Nootka Trollers" and supervised its operation during the initial period. He, therefore, knows the requirements and the possibility of marketing the boats.

In view of the past success of the School in this type of work and the fact that nearly all the boys graduating from the Christie School will either own or operate a fishing boat on graduation, it is recommended that the Department authorize the purchase of the required materials as requested by the Reverend Principal.

I have previously forwarded pictures of the boats constructed at this School but, if the Department so wishes, I can send additional prints.

R. F. Davey,
Dist. Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

Re: IGNACE, Joseph - Death of - Inquiry for Indian Dept.

On February 15th, 1937, the above named Indian boy died at the Christie Residential School, Kakawin, Clayoquot Sound, B.C.

Mr P.B. Macbridge, Indian Agent, at Port Alberni, requested me to act as Chairman on a board of inquiry to be held at the Christie School, into the death of this boy.

Members of the board were Rev B. McLaughlin, O.S.B., Principal, Christie School and Doctor John G. Robertson of Tofino, B.C. On February 20th, 1937 the inquiry was held and Rev B. McLaughlin stated that the boy first complained of being sick on February 14th, he was put to bed in the school infirmary. The doctor was absent at the time this pupil became sick but was called on February 16th and prescribed for the boy. He died on February 15th, 1937.

Dr Robertson stated that he had attended this boy from March 14th, 1936 until his death. The immediate cause of death was thrombosis of middle meningeal artery and the contributory cause was possibly syphilitic. Everything possible had been done for the boy by the school authorities.

Death of Joseph Ignace was due to natural causes.

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you of a serious matter in connection with the health of Christie Residential School, and to urgently request your advice as to procedure.

On September 6th, pupil Andrew Tom died, his case being diagnosed as Tubercular Enteritis. On September 14th, pupil Cecil Williams died, diagnosis T.B. Meningitis. On October 19th, pupil Alice George died, diagnosis T.B. Meningitis. Pupil George Johnson, whom I had brought to Fort Albert hospital, is not expected to live, diagnosis T.B. Meningitis.

In all these cases, the School authorities have permitted the patient to go home, none having died at the school. While I am satisfied that all due care was taken in each case, I feel that they should not have been sent to their homes, and would appreciate your ruling as to the responsibility of the school, morally and financially.

The more serious aspect of the case is the possibility of this not being tuberculous meningitis, which is not contagious, but that it may be a different type, say Meningococcus Meningitis, which may be contracted from a "Carrier".

When on my inspection last week, I endeavored to see Dr. Foster at Tatline to talk over this matter, but was unfortunately unable to do so and was obliged to leave on account of violent weather. I have written him to forward me a complete report on the situation but feel that you should be informed, and that Dr. Macquarie should advise me, by wire if necessary, should he consider an autopsy and pathologic report warranted.

This series of deaths has naturally caused considerable consternation among the Indians, and may lead to attempts being made to burn the school, as has been done on other occasions. I have informed the Indians that the school is in no way responsible for the disease, but as you know it is difficult to convince them.

D. H. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir;

Re: Death of Rose Johnson

I am in receipt of your letter of April 29, in the matter of the above.

I did not see this child before she died. The Christie School authorities first called me at around 3:00 A.M. and described the onset of a sudden dyspnea and attendant symptoms which seemed at the time to be on an asthmatic basis. Since such episodes are not an infrequent occurrence among these local Indian children, and since I was not requested to see the child, I asked for a further report should the child not react favorably to small repeated doses of Adrenalin which I had given to the School. Around 7:00 A.M., a school messenger called at my house and asked me to return with him since there had been no improvement. We called (telephone) before starting and were informed that the child had just died. The additional circumstances you are acquainted with.

On two or three occasions since December 1940 when I first to Tofino, I examined this child and apart from Dental caries and a multiple extraction of deciduous teeth, there was nothing abnormal to be detected. There was no history of illness up to and immediately preceding the sudden onset of this episode. After considering the facts at hand, it would occur to me as reasonably feasible that this represents a possible acute Influenza Pneumonia. During this past winter, there have been several cases in B.C. with similar histories and terminations. The absence of other cases of Influenza at the School must be considered for what it is worth.

I regret my failure to do the necessary thing by calling the Provincial Coroner but can assure you that such steps will be taken in the future when required.

Yours very sincerely,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

REPORT ON LORENA THOMAS, age 6, of CHRISTIE SCHOOL.

I first saw this girl on Nov. 24th at 10:15 when she was brought into my office. She was complaining every so often of severe abdominal pain which seemed to radiate across the lower abdomen being as bad on the right as on the left. The sister said that she had had some pain in the midline, lower abdomen for 5 days off and on, with vomiting once only. But on the morning of the 24th she awakened and screamed with the pain. Patient said that bowels had moved in the a.m. of 23rd. She had no complaints referable to the respiratory or urinary tract.

Examination: young girl, slightly thin, lying on her back with her knees flexed, skin hot and dry, breathing rapidly, and moving no more than absolutely necessary; pain seemed aggravated by movement. T.101 2/5 oral and 105 (Rectal). R. 65, P. 144. Lungs: clear to auscultation and percussion. Abd.: lower portion held quite rigid, upper portion moved with respiration. Palpation was attempted, but she was so tender that she would not allow a hand to do any more than be placed on the abdomen. Tenderness appeared to extend all over the abdomen.

LAB. Owing to the rapid respirations—simulating pneumonic breathing—and the history of old tuberculosis, an x-ray plate was attempted. The plate was blurred by rapid breathing, but the right lung appeared slightly denser than the left.

She was admitted to hospital, given sulfonamides, clear fluids only. Her temperature fell to 102 3/5 rectally, but the respirations and pulse remained rapid. The abdomen did not change that day. On the 25th she commenced to vomit dark greenish fluid at intervals. An intravenous of 5% dextrose in Saline was given which alleviated the vomiting for a time, but when it returned she a Wangenstein suction was connected to a Levine tube in the stomach. This stopped the vomiting, and reduced the distension which had begun to appear in the epigastrium. However, at about 9:30 p.m. she began to fail and despite coramine passed away at 10:55 p.m.

POST-MORTEM: Heart normal. Lungs: considerable adhesions to right upper lung and evidence of healed tuberculosis. Lower lobes of both lung had considerable hypostatic edema. Abdomen: about 1/2 quarts of greenish thin pus flowed out of the cavity on opening. The intestines were matted together by a thick layer of pus, odor definitely faecal. The appendix was found tied down under the caecum, with a hard faecolith in it and a definite perforation in a gangrenous area.

CONCLUSIONS: This child had a perforated gangrenous appendix which led to a generalized peritonitis. The appendix had had a smoldering infection all week and apparently perforated.
Friday morning 24th. As the child had been active enough to take part in a concert on Wednesday night at her own request, and did not complain of severe pain until Friday morning, no blame is to be attached to anyone that medical attention was not sought earlier. When seen she had a peritonitis and her condition was not suitable for operation. Her old history of tuberculosis left her with no resistance to fight the infection.

A. J. Karagian M.D.

In explanation let me say the expenditures have not been authorized by the Department and have been paid out of the school funds. Inasmuch as they are unauthorized the school is responsible.

However, there are reasons why I might present the voucher and receipted accounts, trusting the Department for the following reason might consider a refund.

The reason I would advance is the urgency of the work undertaken. Our repairs which are of a minor character are kept up to date without being allowed to wait or accumulate, thus avoiding general deterioration. The wisdom of this is obvious. The total expenditure in a building of this size by the government (since it was opened) has been below a very moderate estimate generally allowed for such a purpose. The stationary equipment and fixtures of light, water, drainage and power are kept in good repair and not allowed to remain out of order. The accounts represent a certain amount of skilled labour, the bulk however is for material, all used in the school and out-buildings. It was necessary to do a little plastering and to build a cement trough, making the necessary water connections with the barn. The metal partitions, separating the compartments of the shower baths on the boys' side became loose and had to be taken down and rebuilt. This necessitated the employment of skilled labour. On account of the mudroom which was opened in October, in order to provide sufficient isolation, we re-lined the boys dormitory, so that its warmth and comfort could not be questioned; lining also at the same time the top story of the technical building, thus making a room for the manual training instructor. This emergency work was in good order. The carpentry work was done as a good project by the manual training teacher and the senior boys. It has served two purposes, giving us the extra accommodation and practical instruction.

I should like to be perfectly clear that inasmuch as, there was no request sent in to the Department, I do not consider there is any obligation. So I send the voucher and accounts along for consideration. If favourable consideration is given to the payment, we shall be very grateful.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No. 153-0-5 dated Ottawa March 21st, 1931.

When the school was built in 1923, the matter of a door being cut between the boys' infirmary and the boys' corridor was fully considered and it was considered undesirable for various reasons. It was not a fault of the architect's plan.

It was then considered to have as little connection as possible between the boys' and girls' side. The character of the students has changed so greatly in the years that they are not so irresponsible. They have improved morally and are more trustworthy.

We have discussed the question at a couple of staff meetings and are now unanimous it would be a great convenience, for the following reasons.

1. It would give a direct approach to the infirmary from the boys' side of the building for the visitors whom it was not desirable should pass through the girls' side.
2. If it was necessary to bring in a stretch case from the boys' side, it could be done more easily than under the present arrangement.

3. In case of fire, it would give an exit to the boys' side from both boys' and girls' wards in the infirmary without having to go through the main corridor to the boys' side.

My opinion is that it would be better to have the change made. The cost would be about thirty dollars.

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very truly,

G.H. Raley,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your file 153-0-5 dated March 21, 1931

I beg to enclose voucher and receipted accounts in duplicate, covering fire hose. With reference to this, you will notice I purchased more than was authorized. In my opinion this was justifiable. Last August a neighbor's house was burnt down in the middle of the night. It was situated 200 yards from the barns and 300 yards from the house. Fortunately the night was wet, though sparks and bits of burning shingle were blown over our out buildings. It is the first time a fire has been so near. Watching the barns, we, considering the matter felt we should meet such a situation with more of the larger hose.

We have only a small pipe leading from the school supply with a small hose and little pressure, so I purchased sufficient of the three inch hose to reach from the main water supply of the school, to the large barn, the little barn and the new piggery. With this attached to the main water supply, we get good pressure.

I submit we are entitled only to the payment of the two lengths authorized, but trust the Department with regard this as a justifiable expense.

In connection with installing the two extra iron fire-escapes, leading from the small girls and small boys dormitories, we had the iron landings and
ladders from the old building. These being in first class condition we utilized and repainted. A first class job was done by a carpenter and the senior boys at no cost to the Department. Mr. Inspector Barry saw the finished work and was satisfied it was substantial and complete. We now have direct communication from each of the ten dormitories to an iron fire-escape without having to go into a corridor.

I delayed forwarding the accounts in this connection until the fire escapes were completed, thinking it might be necessary to employ a bricklayer. This was avoided. Hoping this explanation is satisfactory

Fire Protection:

There are eight stand pipes with hose, situated in various parts of the building; inside; but no hydrant outside. One new hydrant should be placed in front of the main building and one new hydrant should be placed at the rear of the building. There are four portable fire engines in good condition; there are 15 fire extinguishers placed at various points inside the school building. The pressure in the mains for fire fighting would be about 60 pounds. This is reported by the Principal as sufficient to throw water over the roof of the main school. The water is from the Elk Creek Water Co.

Further instructions have been received from the Department with regard to fire protection since I made my inspection of this school. A number of details will be taken up with the Principal on my next visit.

Extinguishers were tested in January, 1932.

Laundry:

Over 3000 articles per week pass through the laundry. There is very great need for a drying room or some other method of drying clothes, sheets etc. It is due to the great difficulty of drying articles that such a condition of things as is reported under the heading of Dormitories, can arise. Better provision should be made for the washing and drying of sheets, pillow slips, etc. These should certainly be changed much more frequently than is being done now. The reason given for their rather dirty condition was that the laundry was holding up the articles. In the laundry, the whole difficulty was put down to the lack of proper drying facilities.

I beg to recommend that a drying room with a cement floor, steam heated, and with drying racks, be added to the S.W. corner of the present laundry. If this room were built, there would be no necessity to have a steam mangle, which, in the absence of such a room, is now necessary and should, in my opinion, be supplied. Some sort of steam iron is also badly needed here. All the machines are now guarded. This applies to belts, cog wheels, etc.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter dated April 30th, let me state that we have made a thorough investigation of the needs of the case in order to give what Capt. Barry might consider adequate fire protection.

He was here this week and went over the ground thoroughly with me and I showed him the proposed plan of increasing protection, not only from the outside but within the building. The rough sketched plan shows the existing fire lines and main. It shows the proposed line for the school, the proposed line to the barn and outbuildings and also what might be considered good precaution for the future.

The total cost for material for outside fire protection for the school building is $249.44. The skilled labour, including plumbing would be $65.00, making a total of $314.44. This also gives protection for the Principal's Residence and the garage and until water was laid on in the Manual Training Building with sufficient hose available, it could be used there also.

Included in this cost is material to increase the supply of water to the fire lines or standpipe in the boys' wing. At present there is only a two inch pipe to serve three one and a half inch hose lines which is impossible. This is bushed into the main which also retards the flow of water.

By the time the main supply which enters the building in the boys' wing reaches the fire line or standpipe in the girls' wing, it has had so much drawn from it and has been reduced in size that it is inadequate to supply flow enough to the three hose lines on the girls' side. (It is not, of course, supposed that there would ever be three lines attached and in operation at the same time).

You will see the plan includes a booster line from the proposed main to this fire line. Everything is covered in this cost of material as shown in figures A.B.C. and D. At
point C. provision is made to continue the lines on to the barn. The fire service to the two barns, piggery and implement shop would cost $195.14 for all the material. This line could be used as water service also, thereby keeping the water fresh and eliminating the dead end. The cost of installing this, apart from the digging and excavating, which would be done by the school, would be $20.00 to $25.00. We have water in the barn but this only a three quarter inch pipe.

Fittings would also be placed on the line, to pipe over to the cottage and also to the clubhouse, and annex, if found necessary in the future.

Capt. Barry and I did not go thoroughly into the matter of continuing the protection to the barn and annex. The Main Building, however, we were agreed upon as to outside protection being advisable.

If the Department favours this suggestion, we would have the matter undertaken immediately.

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very truly,

G.H. Raley
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find voucher in quadruplicate, and receipted certified accounts, all in good order, for expenditure in connection with the annual camp held at Ocean Park this year, from July 13th to August 31st, for the students of Coqualeetza Residential School, who are unable, on account of distance and otherwise, to go to their homes for summer holidays.

This holiday by the sea was very beneficial for the pupils. It broke the regularity and monotony of school life and gave them the open air for six weeks.

When the holiday camp commenced in 1915 a grant of $200.00 was made by the Department annually; that being insufficient, it was increased to $300.00 which amount was paid up till last year. This year I understand the grant is to be cut. I sincerely hope it will not be less than the amount requested as this does not represent one-third of the cost of giving this holiday to the children. Trusting the grant will be made as it is all legitimate expenditure and reduced to the minimum.

Thanking you for your interest.

Yours very truly,

G. H. Raley

Dear Sir,

Since the fire at an Indian Residential School on the Prairies recently, which the papers said was caused by defective wiring, I have had Mr. Marsh, electrician of Chilliwack, inspect and report to me any defects or necessary repairs which should be attended to without delay, and I herewith enclose his report. The repairs are of a minor character but important. We have been carefully watching and checking our lighting and heating, and every night a double check is made. We fully realize that nothing can be left undone and constant vigilance is the price we have to pay for security of life and property.

A matter that is referred to in Mr. Marsh's report was the collection of the material over the joists of the carpenter's shop. The danger of this was that the boards which rested on the joists might have been pushed aside and have rested on the wire and perhaps broken it. The material has been removed. In the printing shop the motor connections should be permanently wired and the motor will not be used until this is done. The cost of supplies for the work in these changes will be $62.00 and I would advise this expenditure and request the approval of the Department for the same.

I called on Friday with these papers but unfortunately it was the lunch hour and I had to go on to Vancouver. Trusting this may have your approval.

Yours very truly,

At the commencement of the influenza epidemic from which the schools of British Columbia have suffered in common with the Province generally, we had a number of cases of pneumonia. In order to keep down the expenditure of sending them to the hospital, we increased accommodation in the infirmary by taking a radiator from the store-room, where it was not needed, and installed it in the sun porch of the infirmary, where there had been previously no heat, thus increasing our accommodation by making use of the sun porch.

By this expediency we were able to look after the less serious cases of pneumonia. This emergency measure was considered desirable by the Department's Doctor, not only to increase our accommodation during the epidemic, but as economy as he would only take to the hospital severe cases where there was danger and when he considered it absolutely necessary.

While this expenditure was not authorized by the Department, and I understand it is their policy not to pay, for obvious reasons, any vouchers and receipts not previously approved; I trust the Department will consider this bill favourably in the light of emergent conditions, which made the work a necessity.

(Sgd.) G.H. Raley,

REPORTAGE

We had a few cases of chicken pox last fall which we isolated in a cottage we use when necessary, as an isolation hospital. In this cottage we did not have the conveniences necessary for the Nurse and we felt it imperative there should be a toilet built adjoining the house and septic tank installed at a proper distance.

In order to effect this improvement as economically as possible with efficiency, we purchased some of the material at a second hand junk store in Vancouver, and lumber for the lean-to and septic tank in Chilliwack. I obtained the assistance of one skilled plumber who, together with the Manual Training Instructor and boys, made the septic tank and did all the wood work. The total cost of the material and installing the toilet and septic tank and connecting waste pipe was $60.00. The job complete, if by contract and new material throughout, would have cost $100.00.

It is complete and modern. We have been using this building without this convenience for a couple of years and we just completed it when we had one case of Smallpox which was immediately isolated and the Nurse in charge of the case during the colder months had the benefit of this improvement, which, I am sure the Department will consider a very necessary and legitimate expenditure.

At the commencement of the influenza epidemic from which the schools of British Columbia have suffered in common with the Province generally, we had a number of cases of pneumonia. In order to keep down the expenditure of sending them to the hospital, we increased accommodation in the infirmary by taking a radiator from the store-room, where it was not needed, and installed it in the sun porch of the infirmary, where there had been previously no heat, thus increasing our accommodation by making use of the sun porch.

By this expediency we were able to look after the less serious cases of pneumonia. This emergency measure was considered desirable by the Department's Doctor, not only to increase our accommodation during the epidemic, but as economy, as he would only take to the hospital severe cases where there was danger and when he considered it absolutely necessary.

While this expenditure was not authorized by the Department, and I understand it is their policy not to pay, for obvious reasons, any vouchers and receipts not previously approved; I trust the Department will consider this bill favourably in the light of emergent conditions, which made the work a necessity.

RE: CHANGE OF HEATING SYSTEM

At COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, SARDIS, B.C.

To change to Differential Vacuum System, would require no change in sizes of piping now in use, but whole system would have to be checked over to make it absolutely tight to draw high vacuum necessary.

All traps on radiators at present should be sent to factory to have bodies inspected and seated; caps and discs renewed.

Cost per trap, approximately $3.00

Where radiators are at present wet dripped with no trap, cost of new traps would be approximately $4.75 each.

Install 2" P.R. valve with controller
" 4" P.R. " " "
Approximate cost $260.00

Install 8,000' Vacuum pump, approx. cost $800.00

These are just material costs, not labour.

This is the ultimate in heating: working on 1# pressure or less with automatic balanced vacuum maintained; low steam consumption; less fuel used.

The above cost can be cut down by not going so far in changing system, using Vacuum Sub Atmospheric System. Where vacuum is not so great your present traps and piping might be satisfactory and tight enough to save cost of overhauling and trap repairs, thereby eliminating much labour and material costs.

Vacuum Pump would be approx. $100.00 less

2" and 4" P.R. valves would be the same cost. Any new traps required would be same cost as above.

This is a good system, just one step removed from the Differential System. Flexible, giving full control from maximum to minimum needs in heating on low pressure.

At this season of the year it may not be possible to have your heating plant closed down even for a day, to have any changes made, so I suggest you do this:

Have your Engineer check up on any radiators that do not heat, making a note of where they are located; whether they are partially heated, or not at all; if supply pipe to radiator is hot, if not, how far back from radiator before pipe feels hot to the touch. What is outside temperature at this time and positively what is steam gauge pressure at the boiler.
If pressure is high, I suggest cutting it down as it is possible that you have developed back pressure on your return line, thereby flooding the Air Eliminator and getting the system air bound.

Should reducing the boiler pressure fail to relieve the system of air, I suggest taking the radiator farthest from the boiler which gives trouble, and venting it. Should there still be trouble, take the next radiator in line, which is not heating, and vent it, and so on until you have proper circulation, only doing one at a time and no more than is necessary. In fact, I want to stress that it is better to get your circulation through manipulation of boiler pressure, keeping it low, rather than by too much venting of radiators.

Dear Sir: Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Sardis, B.C.

On July 11th, 1935, I made an inspection of the mechanical equipment of this school, which consists of:

- Two very large sectional cast iron boilers
- One vertical tubular boiler
- A full and complete laundry
- A wood cutting plant

**BOILER NO. 12358.**

I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found it in good condition except the blowdown pipe and also the cold water supply pipes to the boiler which must be renewed. Also a new fusible plug must be installed.

I gave this boiler a Hydrostatic Test of 25 lbs., and found it quite tight, only a few small leaks were showing around the packing nuts. These will be attended to by the Engineer.

I set the Safety Valves to blow at 6-1/2 full, at 10 lbs. cold water pressure and have issued a certificate allowing a pressure of 10 lbs. and condition good. This boiler was built in 1928.

**BOILER NO. 12360 B.C.**

On the same day I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found it in very good condition. I then gave it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs., and found every part quite tight. A new fusible plug must be installed. The steam gauge is 1 lb. tight. The Safety Valves are set for 6-1/2 full, 10 lbs. steam pressure.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 10 lbs. and condition good. This boiler was built in 1924.

**BOILER NO. 43864 B.C.**

On the same day I inspected this boiler which is a vertical tubular and is used to supply steam to the Laundry. This boiler has been well kept.

This boiler calls for a hydrostatic test of 200 lbs., and a working pressure of 140 lbs. Upon giving the hydrostatic test, when the pressure reached 60 lbs. 12 tubes began to leak around the top plate. I did not increase the pressure, but emptied the boiler and...
gave it an internal inspection and found that as many of the tubes as I could see were very badly corroded and in places quite thin, so I would recommend that this boiler be retubed.

I did not issue a certificate as another inspection will be required when the repairs are completed. Also a new fusible plug must be installed.

The whole of this plant is well kept, but the type of boilers is very uneconomical and at some time should be changed to some of a more economical type.

My attention was called to the fact that the circulation of the whole plant was very poor. In some parts of the building it was very difficult to get any heat. I made an inspection of the main and found that the returns were very flat. The boilers were set so high that there is just sufficient grade to prevent the lower radiators from being flooded. These are placed high on the wall to prevent it happening.

I pointed out to the Engineer that if he installed five or six automatic air valves on the slow radiators that it would help the circulation considerably, but the only permanent solution is to install a new vacuum condensate pump in the boiler room.

An experiment had been tried to use less coal, which has proven successful in other plants, that is by building a bridge wall across the furnace, but in this case the whole back of the furnace had been allowed to fill up with burnt ashes, which more than defeated the possible saving and which, in this case, I am very doubtful would take place as these boilers are high instead of long and the heat passages have a short travel.

My attention was also called to the fact that the domestic hot water was insufficient for the school and a proposition had been made to install a steam coil in the large storage tank and supply this coil with steam from the vertical boiler.

I suggested that steam could also be taken from the heating mains and used during the winter months, but upon examining the storage tank I found that it would be necessary to cut a manhole in it to allow for the installation of the coil and as this tank had been installed for some time, I do not recommend cutting into the plates, as if this is done it is quite possible a new tank would be required.

I would recommend that a new water heater be installed outside the tank and steam supplied to it from both the vertical boiler and the steam heating boilers and by passed with valves so that each could be used when required. At present the tank is heated with a cast iron jacket heater.

I then inspected the laundry machinery which I found in good condition. All moving parts are well protected with substantial wooden guards.

The same also applies to the wood cutting plant.
I will furnish you with the approximate cost of the alterations in a few days.

The cost of retubing the boiler should be about: $150.00

Dormitories:- The dormitories are in very good condition. The bed linen appears to be kept cleaner than was the case last year. Some of the mattresses should be renewed and I would recommend that 125 should be provided before the opening of school in the Fall. The matter of who will pay for these outworn mattresses will of course have to be decided by the Department. All I ask is that they be placed in use as soon as possible.

Buildings:- The floors in the Boys' and Girls' Play Rooms in the basement need renewal. Some sort of lasting material should be used when this is done. The roof of the Laundry needs renewal this summer. After snow comes this roof leaks. About $100.00 will be required for this. A covered playground for the small boys and girls is very badly needed. These children should be out in the fresh air as much as possible, and under cover in poor weather of which there is much in the Lower Fraser Valley. It is most important that the health of these children should be attended to as well as is possible under the circumstances. Please see under Health below.

Sanitary Conditions:- Four toilet bowls on the Boys' Side need renewal at once. The general sanitary condition of the school is very good. Repairs to the basement floors mentioned above are very necessary, in fact new floors will have to be placed in these basements and adjoining rooms, if the proper sanitary condition of the school is to be preserved.

Laundry:- In addition to repairs to the roof, mentioned above, some facilities for drying clothes are needed here. I made a recommendation last year, and beg to refer the Department to my report after my inspection of January 1932. Nothing has been done. It is impossible to keep the bed linen in proper condition if there is no proper way of drying sheets after washing them.

Boiler Room:- The water gauge in the high pressure boiler needs to be renewed. I beg to recommend that the high pressure steam boiler be attached by steam coils to the hot water tank. This will cost about $75.00. My recommendation is made after a conference with the Principal and the boiler inspector who were present in the boiler room at the time of my inspection there. Such an addition will give a better supply of hot water for domestic use, at no extra cost, beyond that of the pipes now recommended.

April 30, 1934

A. O'N. Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B. C.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

With reference to your letter #1-9-B, dated April 16th, re painting and redecorating the Principal's Residence, in which you ask for definite and absolutely necessary requirements and a reliable and fair estimate of the amounts of cost. In this regard I have had Mr. Max Wilson, who is an old, established, reliable and competent painter and house decorator, and who has previously done any necessary work for us, make an estimate.

We found the following to be absolutely necessary:

Three bedrooms to be repainted,

Upper hall front, lower hall and back hall, kitchen and two pantries, also front and porches of the house require paint.

Four bedroom floors and the study floor should be varnished,

Worn spots of woodwork, such as window ledges, should be patched up and renewed,

Two bedroom floors require a little repairing before being varnished.

$175.00 would cover the cost of this work. This includes repainting of one wall of the kitchen and the repairing of the plaster on the kitchen ceiling.
COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SARDIS, B.C.

April 30, 1934

This is really and essentially in order that my successor, Captain Scott and his wife, may have some sense of comfort. There has been nothing spent on the house by the Department for ten years and the charge is very reasonable.

Trusting the requisition will commend itself to your valuable attention,

Yours very truly,

G. H. Raley
PRINCIPAL

D. O'N. Dasset Esq.,

Dear Mr. Dasset,

You know we expect to be withdrawing from Coqualeetza after twenty years. I am interested in your success as regard the Principal's Residence.

The interior of the house should be done up completely. It requires papering, varnishing and some painting.

I feel it will be quite unfair to the new owner if provision is made for the cost altogether. If not, however, I shall have to wait about two years before I could get anything done at all.
COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SARDIS, B.C.

was distressing and annoying.
Throughout the twenty years there has been much work done but at no time a complete renovation.
I do think it would be good if you to give this matter consideration and try to have some grant made, which would be available as soon as Mr. Scott comes to Coqualeetza, $150 or $200 bright set the place in order.
I really am writing from a woman's point of view.

Yours Sincerely,
Rev. G.H. Raley

July 31, 1934

Dear Mr Daunt:

May I present to you a situation which I feel to be of importance both to the School and the Department as well as to myself.

I refer to the contemplated marriage of Mr P.F.Pirie, our Farm Instructor, of whose work Dr Raley, the retiring Principal speaks in the highest terms. I am trying to get along with as little change in the personnel of the Staff as possible, knowing the efficient and loyal group of workers whom Dr Raley has secured over a period of years. As you may know, Mr Pirie has been with the School as Farm Instructor for the last ten years, having joined the Staff in January 1925. He has proved himself to be a loyal and painstaking employee in his particular department, and is splendid in handling the boys both in the period of their work outside, and during those hours when staff duties bring them under his care. In addition he is the Instructor of the Coqualeetza Cadet Corps, and the leader of our Boy Scouts, and I have been depending upon him for the coming year in all these departments of work.

It will be difficult, however, to continue him as a member of the Staff unless we have some house accommodation for him. He could not continue, when married, to reside in the School building as he does at present, and it would be difficult for him to carry on his duties and live off the School property.

If the Department could see its way clear to assist us with a small grant, we could build a suitable cottage, and solve the problem of accommodation for such a worker for the present and also for the future. I understand this matter has been before the Department before, and that at one time a suggestion for a grant upon their part, was forthcoming in an amount greatly exceeding that which I beg liberty to suggest.

I have the figures from a local carpenter who has done a lot of work for the School. He offers to build a six-room cottage by superintending the work of our larger boys, and asks only .40¢ per hour, for a maximum time of four weeks, for his own labour. This would be of great practical benefit to our boys, as Mr Mower, the Carpenter concerned, is a fine workman, thoroughly efficient, and would be able to give them instruction in carpentry which would be of real help to them when they go back to their homes upon Graduation. The estimate includes cost of supplying all materials, and doing all work, inside and out, namely: Cement foundation blocks, Dimension and finishing lumber, doors and windows, hardware, lath and plaster-2 coats, bath rooms complete, chimney-16 feet, and painting inside and out. I feel that both the figure itself, and the idea of using the labor of the boys will appeal to the Department, as it practically means they are supplying materials, and wages only for the superintending carpenter. His figure, by the way for his own work in this connection, was 192 hours at .40¢ making a total of $76.80. Personally, it will mean much to me in my first year of service at Coqualeetza if I were able to continue Mr Pirie happily in his position, and I think the Department would agree with me in the solution of a problem which is bound to recur from time to time.

I trust that you may see your way clear to recommend this expenditure, and trust that, even though the financial stringency makes it necessary to scrutinize each item of expense, the Department may be able to grant the request as above. With all good wishes and hoping for a favorable reply, I am,

Yours sincerely,

PRINCIPAL

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the report of the Engineer, Department of Public Works, Victoria, on his inspection, in June, last, of the boilers and machinery at the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. He reports as follows:

Boiler No. 12368 B. C. - The Engineer reports this boiler was found in good condition. He suggests that the fusible plug be renewed and states that two new firebars will be required.

Boiler No. 12369 B. C. - This boiler was found in good condition. The blow-down cock was leaking and will need regrounding. The fusible plug must be renewed.

Boiler No. 42804 B. C. - The Engineer reports that he found all rivets, plates and tubes in good condition. This boiler had been re-tubed since previous inspection, but the tubes were too long and not properly headed and rolled which allowed them to leak at the top plate. Since then he states he has received a letter that they have been rewelded and headed and are now quite tight. However, a new fusible plug is required.

With reference to the auxiliary machinery, the Engineer states that the whole of this machinery is in very good condition, that new guards have been installed and there was a considerable improvement of the whole plant.

The Department understands that the certificates of inspection have been forwarded to you; and I would request that you will see that they are posted in a conspicuous place in the boiler-room.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers & Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Sardis, B.C.

Boiler No. 12369 B.C.

On June 12th, 1934, I gave this boiler a careful inspection and found it in good condition.

I then gave it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs. and found it quite tight. I set the safety valves to blow off at 10 lbs. water pressure. The fusible plug is to be renewed. The steam gauge is correct. Two new firebars will be required.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 10 lbs. and condition good.

Boiler No. 12358 B.C.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar inspection and found it in similar condition as Boiler No. 12369.

I gave it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs. and found it perfectly tight, except the blow-down cock which was leaking slightly and will need regrinding.

I set the safety valves to blow off at 10 lbs. water pressure. The steam gauge is correct. The fusible plug must be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 10 lbs. and condition good.

Boiler No. 42804 B.C.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar inspection and found all rivets, plates and tubes in good condition.

This boiler has been retubed since my last inspection but the tubes are too long and not properly beaded and rolled which allowed them to leak at the top plate, so I could not give it a hydrostatic test. Since then I have received a letter stating that they have been rerolled and beaded and they are quite tight.
Boiler No. 43804 B.C. (Cont'd).

The steam gauge is 10 lbs. light. A new fusible plug is required. The safety valve works freely.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 130 lbs. and condition good.

Whilst I was there my attention was called to the large amount of fuel which was being used. There are two methods to partly remedy it without installing new boilers; that is to install new electric driven condensation pumps on the very flat returns and to install some type of underfeed automatic stokers where a cheaper grade of coal could be used and a much more efficient and economical operation of the plant acquired.

Auxiliary Machinery.

The whole of the machinery is in very good condition. New guards have been installed and a considerable improvement of the whole plant is apparent.

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall
E.S. Arnall,
Engineer, D.P.W.
