Dear Sir:

In order to provide room for our boy pupils this year, we are using a Dormitory in the Manual Training building. This adds urgency to the need of proper heating in that building. The instructor informs me that last year the heating was very inadequate and the classes in Motor Mechanics were scarcely able at times, to continue, because of the cold, and the smoke which poured up out of the register. On investigation I found that the furnace was beyond repair.

I had Messrs Parquharson & Eckel Ltd., who installed it, come in and look it over and they reported that it was not worth repairing. I do not feel that this firm gave us a satisfactory job in the first place, because we found the check, which should have been installed on the smoke pipe, lying under the furnace, never having been put in place at all. The cold air leads were quite inadequate, and two of them were brought down out of the one conduit. This made a vicious circle from the furnace up through the conduit and back, so that no fresh air was drawn in, and I feel it was a potent factor in the breaking down of the furnace, as well as rendering it inefficient when in operation. There was no cold air conduit taken off the Manual Training room whatever, and neither hot air or cold air pipes to the Dormitory above it. Heat for this latter had been supplied by use of a stove; I do not feel that this is adequate or safe in a Dormitory like this.

I have had an estimate from Mr. Pooke of Chilliwack, who, I believe has done Government work before, and he will undertake to run hot air pipes through to the Dormitory, and take off cold air pipes from both the Dormitory and the Manual Training room. He will also rectify the vicious circle, mentioned previously, and see to it that the supply of cold air is adequate. He will do all this work, supplying the material, in addition to installing the furnace, for the sum of $115.00. The cheapest way to renew the furnace, which was thoroughly burned out, is to install a similar one, since we would not need to buy casings, or anything more than the bare furnace body itself. This can be done for $25.00. For the sum of $200.00, then, we can install an adequate heating equipment in the Manual Training building, which will take care of the class rooms used for Manual Training, Motor Mechanics and Boat Building, as well as the Dormitory above.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Scott, the Principal of the Coqualeetza Residential School, in which he expresses real distress because of the damage done to the school property and out-buildings by the recent severe ice and rain storm. SIR:

I beg to forward you herewith, a letter addressed to the Department, brought in today by the Reverend Mr. R.C. Scott, Principal of Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, in which he points out many repairs and alterations which he wishes attended to at that Institution.

Estimates of most of these expenses are given, and total approximately $2,700.00, so that including work not estimated for, an outlay of about $3,000.00 is indicated.

In view of the large sum involved, I hesitate to make any recommendation and am forwarding the letter as it stands for the general consideration of the Department.

The following brief comments however are, I think, in order:

The Linoleum generally is in very bad condition, being badly chipped and worn away in many places.

The windows are draughty and the sashes do not appear to set properly in the brickwork.

The composite floors in many places in the corridors and play rooms have broken up and certainly need patching. This also applies to the walls in the Junior Boys' room, where the wire netting on which the plaster is set, has also been broken. It is a question here, whether wooden wainscoting would not be more serviceable than the plaster.

The waste-pipe from the Senior Boys' lavatory has damaged the ceiling of the Senior Boys' class-room by leaking. Both leak and ceiling should certainly be attended to as soon as possible.

Main Roof repairs should, if possible, be attended to, so that possible leaks be averted, and the moss removed, thereby preventing fire hazard. The Shingles should be stained to prevent decay.

In connection with the electric lighting etc., the repairs indicated should be carried out. I do not like the idea of a high voltage wire crossing the girls' play ground, and this should be eliminated.

The items, repairs to Heating System, Laundry Room, window screens, dairy wash-room and Farmer's cottage, total a considerable amount, and while no doubt of advantage to the School, do not appear to be as urgent as other repairs.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS:

I beg to apply for the following repairs to Coqualeetza Residential School. In doing so I would point out that the Main Building has been in use for eleven years and has reached the time when repairs are necessary. In addition, the extreme weather conditions and the ice storm in which it culminated, have rendered certain of the repairs, herein set forth, vitally necessary.

A. IN THE MAIN BUILDING:

1. Renew Linoleum in halls throughout. The linoleum has "perished" and has become brittle. It is ragged and broken. Not having been cemented down it allows dust and small gravel to get underneath. Recently we had to have it nailed down along both edges for the extreme length of the corridor of the Main floor, as the children were tripping over its broken and curled up edges. Estimate attached. "B" quality would be less expensive and might last a good while if rightly laid.

2. Windows: The frames seem to have shrunk away from the sides of the opening, so that when the East wind blows it is impossible to heat the front of the building. The wind blew through around the sash and behind the casings and it will be necessary to have the latter taken off and the space between the frames and the brick filled with some liquid preparation, which will harden. The casings could then be replaced. This should be done, preferably, during the summer vacation. For days at a time, we had to nail blankets over the windows to try and keep out the cold. Even then, with both furnaces going, we had to dismiss the Primary Room the day Inspector Barry was here. The Dormitories were not warm and the Infirmary was cold; it was hard to see sick children in a room so cold, they had to be covered up in bed and electric lights on all day because all windows were covered with blankets. I trust this may be rectified.

3. Repairs to Heating System: Under advice from a Government Heating Inspector, our engineer informs me that an electric vacuum pump installed on the return line, near the furnace would greatly increase the efficiency of our heating system. The size of the Return pipe is too small and condensation takes place, pockets are formed and it is impossible to force steam through some radiators. Results - extreme fuel consumption-cold-and in some instances frozen radiators. Estimated cost of Pump installed not over $250.00

4. LAUNDRY ROOM: New cylinder for washing machine; the present one will not last much longer. Estimated cost, $125.00. A new and larger "Thor" Ironing Mangle, the present one is very inadequate.

Remove Electric Motor from ceiling and hang it on wall above washing machine. Bearings are constantly burning out and it is impossible to lubricate them properly with the motor in its present position. A new 3 Phase Motor, installed as suggested would be much the better unit, as compared with the present single phase one.

A drying room is urgently needed and could be economically built into the end of the Laundry Room. This would lessen the work now laid upon the girls, shorten their hours of labor, reduce fuel consumption, and give room for other purposes, now taken up by improvised clothes drying racks. Steam heat is conveniently available. Cost of material the main one.

Woodshed:

A lean-to woodshed, attached to the old barn collapsed under the weight of snow during the storm in January. It needs rebuilding badly as there is no storage room for dry wood and in winter time the boiler room is used at times, something which ought not to be, but under the circumstances has to be resorted to. This new woodshed would give storage room for 50 cords of wood, and provide a place for the boys to cut and split wood during wet weather. This has to be done at present, outside, and in bad weather cannot be carried on at all. The motor and circular saw are being installed in the old barn alongside the proposed shed.

Electric Lighting:

Certain repairs were necessary even before the ice storm. The pole upon which the transformers are placed is unsafe. There is little doubt at all that kept it from falling during the ice storm was the heavy iron conduit down one side into the ground. The cross arm to which the transformers are attached, is loosened away from the pole, and the bolts have been pulled into the wood. The B.E. Electric Co. advised moving the transformer back beyond the edge of the girls' playground owing to high voltage wires crossing same. As the pole carries, at least, 700 pounds weight and has to be renewed anyway, the only cost to the school would be the extra heavy wire necessary to carry the low voltage across the playground and into the building, plus the new pole. The company will undertake the actual work of moving the transformers. ESTIMATED COST - labor and materials, to school $125.00.

In addition to the above all electric light wires were carried down in the recent storm and had to be replaced. This being necessary, two of the poles which were out of line were moved into line, resulting in a much stronger and better looking job.

The motor for cutting wood, which has up to now, been hung in the large barn, with considerable fire hazard, owing to dust and chaff, I have moved to the floor of the shop contiguous to the new wood workshop. This will allow a roomy and dry place, affording good footing to the boys during wood cutting, as compared with the old position, where the saw was outside, the ground uneven and often muddy and slippery. The saw has been placed upon new timbers and we have now, a much safer unit for the boys to work with. The only cost to the school will be the few yards of extra wire and the time spent in moving and setting up the motor. All other work has been done by the boys under supervision of Staff members.
Fire Equipment:

All large fire extinguishers have been refilled at a cost of $43.20. Five extra fire lanterns have been provided and two extra fire axes, all of which have been placed in glass fronted cabinets at a cost of $25.45 for labor and materials. I would strongly advocate the provision of two sets of iron steps to be placed on low wheels on the lowest landing platform of fire escapes at the rear of the school on both boys and girls sides. This would more than double the efficiency of present escapes, and it would make possible a continuous exit. At present the delay is caused by pupils having to go down through the opening in this lower platform by a ladder attached to the wall. I am quite sure this affords possibility for tragedy in case of fire.

On Route No. 1, down the stairway and out the front door we can empty the building in three minutes, but down the above fire escapes it took the boys 9 minutes and the girls 13 minutes owing to the congestion, caused as above. I have plans drawn for this suggested improvement, but have not yet been able to get estimates as I have not been able to locate a firm doing this sort of work.

Farmer's Cottage:

I beg to re-submit estimates for a farmer's cottage as contained in my letter to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, under date of August 6, 1934, at $820.00.

As an alternative we have a cottage which, last year, was moved, at school expense and might be re-conditioned for a farmer's residence. It would need re-plastering in some rooms; re-papering, painting inside and out, verandah and roof and chimney repairs. Water laid from barn across to cottage, with sink and bathroom installed. Estimated cost $475.00.

Bridge:

The Bridge over the Lukakuk has sunk down on one side at the west end owing to embankment being undermined by the recent freshet. This resulted in one of the cement pillars being pushed away, out of position, allowing bridge to sag. As this bridge is on the Main Road between the Barns and the back farm and all farm traffic passes over it, I am having it repaired at once. Estimated Cost - Replace cement pillar - Jack up Bridge and repair abutment and under structure. $25.00

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I have been wrestling with the matter of repairs to the school building for some time. It has been very difficult to get estimates for the various jobs and has taken much more time than I would have thought possible. There are some I shall just have to let go, after waiting more than two weeks for figures from the parties concerned. I shall have to submit alternative plans, as, if the Department persists in allowing only $900.00 of the $1200.00, it will be quite impossible to have all that really ought to be done, attended to. I shall list only those which are essential and beg to submit the following:

1. (a) Take off present San-san on two boys' playrooms and one boys' cloakroom in basement and re-lay with cement and sand.

(b) Take off present San-san and re-lay with San-san, floors in #2 & #3 Boys' Lavatories.

(c) Patch two girls' playrooms and passage way with San-san.

TOTAL cost of above --------- $ 665.00

2. Renew walls in basement lavatory and patch walls in boys' cloakroom and in hallway in basement. Build up from floor with sheer cement instead of present baseboard finish in basement lavatories and lavatories #2 & #3 on boys' side.

TOTAL cost of above --------- $ 60.00

3. Take out wash basins and toilets in lavatories #2 & #3 on boys' side to enable contractor to lay floors with San-san. Install and raise all connections to waste pipes, toilets and baths above new flooring.

TOTAL cost of above --------- $ 60.00

4. Renew materials for waste pipe to lavatory, basement, boys' side, using galvanized iron piping and re-connect same.

TOTAL cost for materials and labor --------- $ 18.75

5. Construct hood over kitchen stove and carry outlet through the roof and into stack, of galvanized iron, at least 25' high, to insure draft.

TOTAL cost of above --------- $ 60.00

6. Removal of slop sink from kitchen and install same in infirmary kitchen. Extend hot and cold water pipes and connect waste pipe with same.

TOTAL COST of above --------- $ 45.00

7. Scrap moss from roof of main Building and stain same.

TOTAL cost of above --------- $ 85.00
8. (a) Renew roof over laundry with traffic deck built up of one ply heavy base sheet, nailed to boards. Then mop solid, two layers of asphalt felt on top using 170 degrees melting point asphalt and a heavy mopping of same materials on top. Renew sump in roof also counter flashings at walls, and flashings over division walls.

(b) Repair weak spots and recut roof over kitchen. Install new water hoppers through wall, and head outside of wall.

Total cost for (a) and (b) $150.00

9. The total of above repairs amounts to $1,143.55 so I have been again in touch with the contractor for the floor job and have asked him to tender only on renewing floors in the Boys' cloakroom, renewing floors in no's 2 and 3 Lavatories on the Boys' side, and patching floor in Junior girls' playroom with San-San and the price for this will amount to --------------$358.00. This will leave the floors in the boys' playrooms for another year, but it seems the best thing to do under the circumstances. Recapitulating then, we have:

New figure for repairs to floors - $358.00
Cost for walls as in 2-6-60.00
" for remove plumbing fixtures-3-60.00
" " renew plumbing, basement boys' lavatories, as in -4-18.75
" " Bond over kitchen store as in -6-60.00
" " Remove slop sink etc as in -6-45.00
" " Surfaces roof, main building as in -7-85.00
" " Renew roof over laundry etc as in -8-150.00

Total for repairs as per new figure- $836.75

Balance of $900.00 grant for repairs to be used to redecorated dormitories and class rooms etc $63.25 $900.00

I may say that the above repairs are absolutely necessary to my mind. There is a regular flood of water coming down the rear wall of the laundry during a heavy rain, and the roof over the kitchen will not last much longer without extensive repairs or renewal. This list, even if granted by the Department will leave several items to be cared for by the School such as taking off window casings and caulking space between them and the brick wall, and the above figure for redecorating will not much more than cover the cost of materials— if it does that. I regret that this matter has dragged into July, but it has really been considerable trouble to get these figures. Some that I have asked for weeks ago, I have not received yet, as for instance estimate for recaulking windows. In view of the conditions during the winter, I thought it would be an attempt to take care of this item by making our boat builder being able to stop water entering so well as he does. I think he will make a good attempt at stopping the entrance of these cold winds.

I trust that you will be able to approve these estimates and to forward them to the Department so that we may undertake the work during the holidays. I shall of course, submit exact accounts in quadruplicate for each of the above repair jobs, the total not to exceed the figures as given above.

I hope to be passing through New Westminster— perhaps on Tuesday of this week and shall call to see you.

Yours sincerely,

August 26, 1935.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing, herewith, estimates of repairs, which we discussed during your visit to Coqualeetza last month.

I am sorry to be a bit late in sending it in, but it has been an almost interminable job, between finding the best methods and materials and waiting for estimates and then having them revised or re-submitted. As stated on the Repair Sheet, the floors in #2 & 3, boys' lavatories have been renewed with San san, and I have no doubt that the installation of the proposed urinals will safeguard them greatly. I have had these floors treated with raw linseed oil and am taking every precaution to make the job lasting and satisfactory.

I do not know whether you will be able to increase your suggested expenditure for the dining room, but as intimated in the estimates, the cost to the school will be at least $100.00. In addition to this, there will be the extra cost above the amount allowed by the Department for kalsomining, which the school will have to absorb. Then we shall also have to face the cost of laying the linoleum and a good many other items which mean that the school will be carrying its full share of repairs. I have gone very thoroughly into the matter of the improvement of our toilet system and am convinced that some such equipment as these Mueller Valves will have to be installed. They are the most fool-proof and simple of all equipment I have seen.

I want to thank you most heartily for that authorization of $75.00 and only wish you could see the transformation it has worked in the dining room. Any consideration you may be able to give to my suggestion in the estimates now submitted will be deeply appreciated.

Yours very sincerely,

R. C. SCOTT,
Principal.
COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SARDIS, B.C.

August 29, 1935.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Day before yesterday, I handed to Mr. Daunt, a list of estimates for repairs, and included equipment for the year, 1936. This included estimate for refrigeration plant by Marshall-Wells, B.C. Ltd., which amounted to $852.00 complete.

It is a job, similar to the one done at Alert Bay, by this firm recently, only somewhat smaller. I am at present negotiating, through Mr. Daunt's office for a supply of dried salmon.

We find that the smoked fish, which we get from Westminster Distributors, is not relished by the children, in fact a very great deal of it is left on the plates and wasted, and some of it, I know, has not been very palatable. I think Mr. Anfield has found that the native cured fish has a decided advantage as food for these children. If I am successful in getting a supply of it, I will need cold storage for it. Then there is the matter of the care of our milk, which has always been a source of concern to me. We have a dairy drain in the space allotted at present and it is exceedingly difficult to keep it clean and sweet. If we had a Refrigeration plant such as proposed, it would be wonderful for the school and I am quite sure, would pay for itself in saving of food and betterment in the quality of the meals.

If we decide to put in the dividing wall, in order that we might take care of fish in a separate place from the other food, it would mean an additional $76.00 to the price above quoted. This, however, is just about the same as that submitted by McLennan, McFeely & Prior Ltd., although their box is 2' shorter. We stand to save over $100.00 for the price of the Marshall-Wells, through doing the carpenter work ourselves and this is a consideration. I would be glad, however, to have either one, if the Department saw fit to install it, but it looks as though the Marshall-Wells one would be a little more economical.

I am writing you because I included this in the estimates for next year and if there is any possibility of our getting it in this year, I would certainly appreciate it if you were to help in any way to that end. With all good wishes and thanking you for your interest in the school, I am,

Yours sincerely,

R. C. Scott,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Danny:

RE: NEW LAUNDRY CYLINDER & CASE.

I regret to inform you that our Washing Machine has gone completely out of business. Strangely enough, it is not the end of the cylinder which we expected would go, but the other end, at the left hand side, as you face the machine.

We tested this end last summer, when Mr. Hutchinson, of the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company was here and decided it would have to be the end on the right hand side which would have to be renewed. I presume the machine had been standing for 4 or 5 weeks and had got thoroughly dried out and had hardened up, which would account for our not realizing the state it was in. Last week, however, it gave out entirely. The wood along the seams in the end is thoroughly rotten. I had to make some sort of shift in order to get along and had our Boat Builder build in a new end, which we have bolted through the old one and have also spiked through the casing. We are getting along after a fashion, but this new end is so heavy, that it throws the cylinder out of balance and increases the load on the gears and the motor and I am in fear and trembling lest we have a mechanical breakdown. We get along by putting in a very light load of washing, and this, of course, means that the laundry is kept working for a much longer period than would otherwise be necessary and interferes seriously with the carrying out of our work time table.

If you will refer to the Repair Sheet which I sent in last August, you will note that under the Laundry I asked for one new cylinder for the washing machine at a price of $82.00 F.O.B. Vancouver, if made there. I have talked this over with Stanley Brock Limited, and their advice is that we secure a new cylinder and a new case from the Factory in Toronto. The cost for the new cylinder complete, without the metal trimmings, would be $73.00. The outer case, woodwork only, would cost $70.50. The approximate freight on these parts from Toronto to Chilliwack would be $56.50. This is all in accordance with the estimate which I received from Stanley Brock last September. These prices, of course, mean that we would use all our own trimmings, to be taken from the present cylinder. In conversation with Mr. Nowat, representative of the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company, in the Offices of Stanley Brock Ltd., last week, I was informed that the life of one of these cylinders is 5 years. As this present one has...
been in operation continuously for the last 10 or 12 years, you can see that it owes us nothing.

I trust that the Department will authorize the expenditure for the new cylinder and new outer case immediately, as we cannot get along the way we are and it is impossible to finance sending laundry for an Institution like this, to outside concerns. If the machine gives out again, I do not know what we can do and hope that the Department will deal with this with all possible expedition. The main bearings will also have to be renewed. Referring again to my Repair Sheet of last August, there was an item of $15.00 included. There seems to be a discrepancy between the figures as given in my Repair Sheet of August, as compared with the ones I have set down in this letter, but these latter figures, I am quoting from a letter of Stanley Brock Limited, under date of September 21st, over the signature of Mr. D. J. Hutchinson.

Thanking you for your kind assistance in this urgent matter, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

R. C. SCOTT,
Principal.

P.S. I have also received a figure on a Champion Cascade Washer, of a size to do the work of our present Globe Wood Washer. It is composed of monel metal and practically without wear in continual service. Some of these machines have been in use in big city laundries, for 10 years or more and do not show any appreciable signs of wear. The cost, I fear, however, is prohibitive, namely $2,440.00 F.O.B. Toronto.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I am enclosing copy of a letter received from the B. C. Electric Railway Co., with references to back charges on our lighting account.

The letter is self-explanatory. A year ago, when I came to the school, I went to the office in Chilliwack and did my best to get information as to the different meters and the cost respectively, for power and light, in order that I might have some way of checking up and they informed me then that they had no way of telling which bill was for which meter and after a second attempt I had to let it go. You may imagine the shock which this letter gave me. I do not see how they have any legal claim, as we have paid the accounts which they have rendered from month to month. I took the matter up with Mr. Jaunt, the Indian Agent and his suggestion was that I write you, and that if you would take it up at Ottawa, it may be that the Department would make a "love gift" or something of that kind.

You may understand that if we have to pay this back charge, even though it is spread over a considerable period, it is going to mean a considerable handicap, especially in view of the developments I had hoped to undertake here this year. So far as the moral obligation is concerned I feel that such an obligation is much greater on my part, towards our girls, some of whom will be putting in their last year at school this year. If they do not get that training in home economics as planned this year, they will not get it at all, so I have to decide between the moral obligation between them and this company. In the latter case it seems like adding money, which would be found money, to their profits; while in the case of the girls it is a case of personal loss and I think this is the obligation which ought to obtain.

You will note that the corrected K.W. hours in each case, add practically an amount equalling one month's salary, so that in any case, this year I must, without any back payment at all, provide for what amounts to another member of the staff, then if I put someone in charge of the Home Economics Department it is like adding two members, which you will understand, needs serious consideration. I would be glad if you could do something at Ottawa but I feel that the negligence of the company is quite inexcusable and that the blame rests squarely upon them.

In talking to the Manager in Chilliwack this week, he said that he would write you and doubtless you will hear from him in this connection.

Dear Sir:

Re: Coqualeetza Institute - Lighting Account

I regret having to advise that a recent check of our electric meter No. 1261180 indicates that you have been underbilled for energy consumed since December 1929 (when a change of meter was made) due to the omission of the multiplying constant 10 in computing the monthly kilowatt hours resulting in our billing only one-tenth of the actual consumption.

An analysis indicates that over a period of seventy-eight months you have been short billed 107,433 kilowatt hours, value $3,493.93, or an average of $44.80 per month.

With these facts in front of you I have no doubt you will desire to make some arrangement for the payment of the underbilled amount, which is what the company would have to do had you been overbilled. The effect on your future accounts is illustrated by taking the past two months for example:

Corrected K.W. hours 1400 - Corrected bill $70.70

Month ending June 18 - K.W. Hours billed 130 - Amount $6.50
Corrected K.W. hours 1300 - Corrected bill $70.70

I shall be pleased to call and discuss this matter with you at your early convenience with a view to arriving at some satisfactory basis of settlement.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Benson:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter recently received from the B.C. Electric Railway Co., regarding their account for underbilled consumption of light in Coqualeetza. They have made a substantial reduction. At the same time, I feel that they have no legal right upon us, as we paid their bills from time to time, upon presentation, and the meters are their own property and supposed to be kept in shape by them.

So far as the moral obligation goes, it seems to me that my moral obligation to these children outweighs any which may exist towards the B.C. Electric. In the one case, if we have to shoulder the extra payment monthly, over and above the increased cost, as per their corrected meter, it means that we shall have to forgo the plans we have in mind for practical instruction for our Senior Girls, and they will be girls graduating this year, who will never have the chance of getting that instruction. On the other hand, it is simply a question of adding to the profits of the Company. It seems to me, as I have said, that my moral obligation to these children would preclude any compromise with the B.C. Electric Co., which would be likely to infringe upon the rights of the children.

At the same time, I would be quite agreeable, if you can influence the Department of Indian Affairs to make a settlement in this connection.

I am just starting north this evening on a trip to bring in children from the Nass River.

With all good wishes,

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

'Signed' R. G. Scott,
PRINCIPAL,
Per E. Munro.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

Replying to your letter of October 22nd, regarding the B. C. Electric Claim, I beg to say that from all enquiries I have been unable to find any original contract between the School and the Electric Railway Co. Dr. Haley says there was no original contract. I have interviewed the local manager in Chilliwack and he informs me that there could be no original contract, as he has no record of it in his office. In all probability, all that would be between the school and the Company would be the signing of a card requesting service. In conversation with Mr. McPhet, the local Manager, I inferred, very clearly, from his that he felt we were under moral obligation only.

Just to make it clear let me repeat that this claim for back payments rests only, and altogether on the fact that their meter was not registering the full amount of power that we were using. It is not a case of us not paying in full, the accounts they rendered. We paid in full all accounts rendered by the Company upon presentation. The shortage is due to the fact that their meter was not properly registering. The meter was their property and supposed to be kept in order by them. I may also say that I went twice to the local office after I first undertook the Principalship, and sought to find just which meter was for which particular service, in order that I might know how much we were paying for power in the laundry, how much for light in the main building and how much for power to the barn and the manual training building. They were not able to give me any information and said that it was all looked after from Vancouver. It was not until after the meter was found to be wrong that our Engineer and myself were able to get a line on these meters.

I am enclosing a copy of the bills rendered regularly by the Company. These have been paid by cheque each month. We have sent the coupon upon several occasions, along with the cheques, but these coupons were never returned to us, marked "paid", so we discontinued attaching them.

Trusting this will be of some help, I am,

Yours sincerely,

'Signed' R. G. Scott,
Principal.

P.S. Their manager informed me that the same thing occurred with the Chilliwack Hospital and the Board had made a settlement. The claim in that instance, $600, was not paid in full.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I am now in a position to give you the details of the proposed improvements to our fire escapes.

First of all, I had Mr. Brock of Chilliwack out, and have gone into the matter of the door in the upper corridor, between the boys' and girls' sides, and it does seem, after considerable deliberation, that it would be quite unwise and quite unsatisfactory, to have the doorway through the clothes closets in the teachers' rooms, and have them go through these rooms and out into the corridor. There is no doubt, that in case of fire, this roundabout way would result in confusion and so, would not be satisfactory. Mr. Brock, who has done a good deal of work satisfactorily for the school, would undertake to supply all materials and do the work of cutting the door through and hanging same in the partition between the Boys' and Girls' sides on the upper floor for the sum of $15.00.

Regarding improvements to our fire escapes, I think I have pointed out the difficulty caused in readiness of exit, when the children come down the fire escapes. When they reach the lower platform, which is still 8' above the concrete floor of the yard, they have to come down through a manhole, one by one, on an iron ladder, which is attached to the brick wall. In our fire drills, down the front and out the front door, where we have readiness of exit, we can clear the school in less than one and one half minutes. But when they have to come down these fire escapes, progress is good until this lower landing is reached and then there is a blockade, with children standing waiting upon the steps all the way up. I feel sure that this would result in tragedy, if we ever have a fire and have to use these fire escapes. It took the boys 6 minutes to get out of the school and down the fire escape, and it took the girls 9 minutes, owing to congestion, as the children went down, one by one, on this ladder, through this manhole.

I had a long talk with the Deputy Fire Marshall in Vancouver, and he advised me that it would be necessary to have several improvements and that our present system was certainly inadequate. He advised me to see the Pearson Wire and Iron Works, who have done a lot of this sort of thing for the city schools and not one of whose contracts has been unsatisfactorily filled. While there are other firms, he said he never had to turn back any work which this firm had done. I have shown the Manager of this firm, the sketch prepared by Mr. Williams, and from it the Pearson Wire and Iron Works have agreed to provide two counterbalance stairs complete, with weights, sheaves and cable, delivered at Coqualeetza for $243.00.
There would be some small expense extra in having these fixtures attached, but I think we could perhaps attend to that at the school, or certainly by getting one man up from the city, it could be done with two days' work and help from ourselves. There would be 1054 lbs. weight in the two stairs and counterbalance weights; the stair stringers to be 4" x 6" iron. The chairs to be 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 3/16", 5/8" flexible cable used, supposed to be good for 25 years. 3/8" x 2" stirrup, and 28 checker plate treads.

While a counterbalance stairs is not admitted in some schools in the city, it is still used in hospitals and in certain schools and other public buildings. I think you know the type. The stair remains suspended until the first child begins to come down, when it lowers to the ground and remains in that position until the last child has come down the escape. If we had these, we could empty the school in practically the same time, down the fire escapes, namely 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) minutes. It does not seem possible, owing to there being an exit in the way, to bring the stairs down right to the ground.

I would be glad if you would forward this estimate to the Department. We ought to have also, stairway fire escapes of the type, on the back of the school, one on each end of the building, allowing exit through the lavatories. As you know, apart from the stairway escapes on the back of the building, there is nothing but the ladders attached to the front. Even if two new fire escapes were not given us, I feel there certainly should be one new one on the girls' side. One could take a chance on the boys getting out, perhaps, down the present ladder, but it would be exceedingly difficult for the girls and certainly not adequate for either boys or girls.

Two new stairs, with two landings and counterbalance stairs, at the bottom, would cost $465.00; if we ran the stairs right to the ground, the cost would be $90.00 less. This is an approximate estimate. I trust that at least you may be able to get the two counterbalance stairs to complete our present equipment.

Thanking you for your interest and assistance, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

R.C. Scott,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Coqualeetsa Indian Residential School, giving details of improvements which he recommends be carried out in connection with the fire escapes.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of the expenditure required - approximately $15.00 - in having a door installed in the partition wall, between the two sides of this building, on the top floor. You may arrange, also, for the purchase of two fire axes and have one installed in a case on each side of the partition. Please forward an itemized account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure.

The Department has noted the Principal's request, that stairway fire escapes, of the same type as those on the back of the school, be provided at each end of the building. While there are no funds available in our Appropriation for the balance of the current fiscal year, it will be possible to provide for this expenditure from the appropriation for the coming fiscal year. The Department will therefore approve of you taking up this matter with the Principal and arranging for the installation of a stairway fire escape at each end of the building, allowing exit through the lavatories. These fire escapes should include counterbalance section, as outlined in the Principal's letter. It is noted that the cost of the two new stairs, with two ladders and counterbalance stairs at bottom, would be approximately $465. The school authorities, themselves, should perform as much as possible of the labour in carrying out the work.

The accounts covering the cost of installing the two stairways should not reach the Department until after the middle of April, next, when funds are available to pay the cost of the work. At that time, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, giving in detail the amount of labour required, the number of hours employed and the rate paid. Should there be any freight charges on materials for same, a receipt should accompany the vouchers.

The Department will leave in the hands of the Principal and yourself the matter of installing the fire escapes, and all work should be satisfactorily carried out. It is hoped that when these escapes are installed it will overcome the present danger of the existing ladders and provide ample means of escape in case of fire, with the least possible loss of time.

SIR:-

I regret that your letter dated the 12th of December, File No.158-0-5, should have remained so long unanswered, but on taking the matter up with the Reverend R.C. Scott, Principal of Squaileetza Indian Residential School, further possible fire hazard was pointed out, and I wished to obtain an idea of the cost of some of Mr. Scott's suggestions before laying the matter before you.

I am enclosing a communication from the Reverend Gentleman, from which you will see that the original change suggested by Colonel Pragnell can be made for approximately $15.00, and I would recommend that this be authorized.

In connection with Mr. Scott's remarks on the fire-escapes, there is no doubt a distinct slowing up in the evacuation of the children from the School occurs at the lower platform, as indicated. This might easily cause the rear of the departing line of pupils to be endangered by a fire.

What is, to my mind, worse, is the system of up-right ladders from the top story attached to the wall outside the windows, on to which children would have to swing. In reasonable weather these could be negotiated by the boys, but would be very dangerous for girls. In weather, such as we have had during the past month with low temperatures accompanied by northerly gales, they would be impossible for anyone.

The first proposition outlined by Mr. Scott and estimated to cost $243.00 would do away with the congestion on the existing fire-escapes.

The second proposition estimated to cost $465.00 would eliminate the dangerous ladders and provide extra facilities for rapid evacuation.

The cost being considerable, I hesitate to make a recommendation, for immediate purchase, but I wish to emphasize the danger of the existing ladders and I do think it would be most desirable to install a better system of evacuation at the earliest possible moment.

SIR:

I beg to forward you herewith, a communication from the Reverend Principal of Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, in which he sets forth the need for a Steam Ironer in their laundry.

Apparently, the cost of such a machine, new, is $3,000.00, but there is a good used one available at $1,000.00.

This seems a great deal of money, and I refrain from comment, other than to remark that there would appear to be two sides to the school situation:

On the one hand we have the fact that undoubtedly the ironing at this Institution is very heavy, and done in the present manner takes up a great deal of the girls' time, besides exposing the present machinery to a heavy steam strain. The proposed installation would do away with both these drawbacks.

On the other hand, having their future welfare in mind, it appears to me that too much machine help in these schools, useful as it is in operating the Institution, is not the best kind of preparation for life in a shack on a Reserve, where the ability to carry on domestic duties with plain everyday appliances will count more than academic proficiency, or a knowledge of steam ironers and electric stoves. That appears to me, to be one place these big schools fail to function.

Under the circumstances and conditions there is no doubt this machine would be very useful, and if the money is available would probably warrant the expenditure.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I would be grateful if you would bring to the attention of the Department, my request of last August, for a Steam Ironer for our Laundry. I pointed out at that time, the urgent need.

With about three thousand pieces going through, per week, with our present equipment, the girls are kept working from four to five days weekly. It is not only hard on them physically, but it renders it almost impossible to find time, outside the classroom periods, for instruction along Home Economics and Handicraft lines, which is vitally necessary for the practical training of these children. I pointed out also, how wasteful our present system is, by using live steam to bring the water in our washer, up from cold to washing heat. It is also hard on the cylinder itself, and in view of the fact that the Department has just installed a new washer, I would like again, to point out that using steam in this way creates a pressure, which is hard on the cylinder.

A new Ironer, 100", two roll, one pass, belt driven machine, would cost in the neighborhood of $3,000.00, but I pointed out, that Stanley Brock Limited could supply a used ironer, passed by the Inspector and in good condition, two roll, one pass, 100" machine installed for $1,000.00. This machine has been discarded, not because of any deficiency or breakdown in it, but simply because it had become too small and required four attendants, two putting the goods through and two taking them away. The new machines have a return apron, which enables the two workers who feed the machine, to take away also, and thus saves 50% of their labor cost.

By installing a hot water tank, which could be secured second-hand, for two hundred dollars, with heating coil complete, we could use the exhaust steam from the ironer, to create a plentiful supply of hot water, which could be piped direct to the washing cylinder. In view of the fact that the Department will be asked to furnish a high pressure steam boiler this coming year, I would like to emphasize again, the gain that there would be in having this equipment, from the standpoint of decreased fuel consumption.

The main thing, however, is the fact that our present system keeps our girls too long in the laundry. If they could get rid of doing all the heavy flat work, such as sheets, towels pillow cases,
etc., it would speed up the process, as these articles could go direct from our tumbler, or dryer, through the steam mangle and be finished with. The training of the girls in ironing, would not at all be interfered with, because all articles of personal clothing would still be washed and ironed individually.

I have been going through our roll of pupils and beg to point out, as showing that we have fewer and fewer girls available. Six years ago we had three girls from 6 to 8 years; today we have 15. Six years ago we had eighty-six girls from 9 to 16 years of age; today we have only seventy. Six years ago we had 16 girls who were over 16 years of age and today we have three. The proportion of Grade VIII and High School girls is very much the same, so that it does not affect the depletion of available labor. Six years ago there were seven girls in Grade VIII and High School and today we have five.

This will make clear, I am sure, the need for doing something to lessen the time that our girls spend in the laundry. I am most anxious to do even more than we are doing this year, for these girls, in the way of a practical training in house keeping and home making, dress making and handicrafts such as spinning, carding, dyeing and knitting wools into all kinds of articles for clothing. Of course if the Department felt like giving us a new machine, well and good, but I feel that this second hand machine, if passed by the Government Inspector, would be adequate, and in view of the necessity mentioned above, of installing a new High Pressure steam boiler, I feel that the Department might well give the matter consideration.

Thanking you for your interest, I am,

Yours sincerely,

R. Scott,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

On Thursday, March 25th, the writer had an interview with the Reverend Scott, Principal of the above Institute, regarding the aforementioned arrears, due to our having billed you only half the correct consumption for several years past.

No doubt Mr. Scott has explained to you that this arose out of the fact that the meter registers only one-tenth of the current passing through it and therefore has a multiplying constant of 10 to give the correct result. This was inadvertently omitted when billing you. I explained that had the reverse been the case and you had been overbilled, we would have immediately issued a credit for whatever was due to you.

The stand taken by Mr. Scott is that the Institute is provided with a certain definite proportion of the expense by the Government Department of Indian Affairs; that no further funds are available and therefore the debt can not be honored. We, on the other hand, are endeavoring to meet the Institute in a liberal way by 8 cents, instead of 7 and 5 cents and 6 and 3 cents, which rates have prevailed during the major portion of the time. Not only this, I have suggested that as the underbilling extends over a period of six and one-half years that if the Institute was short of funds we were willing to accept payment of the arrears over the same period during which they had been incurred, which would add approximately $25.50 per month to your regular lighting account.

It would appear to the writer that as the Government bear the major portion of the cost of this Institution, which according to the annual statistics is in the neighborhood of 75 per cent, that they have benefitted to this extent in connection with the arrears, and it does not seem unreasonable that they should pay this amount. I shall, therefore, be glad if you will take this matter up with your Board, especially the suggestion I have made that the debt be liquidated over the same period in which it was incurred, which I believe you will agree is a very reasonable proposal.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) Edmond E. Walker,

Dear Mr Daunt:

I am enclosing herewith Blue Print of suggested Fire Escapes for the end of our Main School Building. I am sorry that the amount now submitted is so much in excess of that which the firm gave to me as a rough estimate. That is largely due to the fact that the sketch which was made for me by Mr Williams took account only of the first two stories, and left the upper story unprovided for. It is this, as stated in the letter from The Pearson Company which has increased the cost.

The windows on the third floor are set back from the wall, so that the platform has to extend over a part of the roof in order to get clearance for the stairway to the second floor windows. The flight of steps is a long one, so I had the quotation made for ladders going right to the ground. Otherwise it would have had to be a counterbalance unit from the ground floor window. This would have been much more costly, and there is the unsatisfactory element of upkeep to be sure that it would always be ready for use. The other fire escapes come practically to the ground, by means of the ladder from the lower landing. This is very unsatisfactory so far as utility and ready exit is concerned. These ladders should be replaced by stairways as suggested in the second part of the Pearson Co.'s quotation but so far as allowing access to the dormitories from the outside, the ladder is almost as big a menace as would be the stairways proposed. I think we can eliminate the Counterbalance unit. We have had no trouble for some years, so I am informed, through use of fire-escapes to obtain entrance to the building. Locks and seals, on the inside are all we use, and they are sufficient.

The ladders on the front of the building, and again from No. 5 dormitories on both boys' and girls' sides, are quite inadequate and unsafe for use. The proposed units would allow access through the Lavatory windows as shown in the sketch. There would need to be made into a basement window to allow ready exit, but that is not an expensive undertaking. It should, however, be provided for. The main shaft would be the main, and likely the only expense as we could change them ourselves.

Our present system of fire escapes is entirely inadequate and would not pass inspection by a fire marshal. These proposed additions, especially if supplemented by the additional sections from the main floor landings to the ground on our present escapes at the rear of the School, would give us equipment that would be adequate. We would then have three exits, namely:

1. By the stairways and through front and rear entrances;
2. Down fire escapes at the rear of the building;
3. Down fire escapes (as proposed) at the end of the building.

If the Department is unable to meet the cost of the proposed new units at $948.00, plus cost of erection, then I trust that they will undertake the extra unit from the lower landing to the ground, or the unit now on the rear of the School. We might do the work of installation in this case, as there would be no new
braces required. It would be only a matter of cutting the present platform, and attaching the new stairs to the present landing.

In our last fire drill, the boys took 6 minutes and the girls 9 minutes to get out and clear of the fire escape. This was due to the congestion on the lower landing through having to go down the ladder one at a time. The addition would give us ready exit right to the ground, and I cannot too highly recommend its being granted. The matter of the units on the end, as proposed in the enclosed Blue Print might wait for further consideration, but are vital to greatest degree of safety.

If the work were done on the new units during the summer vacation we would supply board for the workmen.

Regretting the increase of cost for the proposed new units, but emphasizing once more the need of some such further protection, I am,

Yours sincerely,

RCS/ PRINCIPAL.

P.S. I am really up the Coast on a visit to the villages in hope of stimulating recruiting of pupils, and shall call to see you early in May upon my return.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I beg to enclose herewith vouchers to complete the account for shingling the Principal's Residence at Coqualeetza. I very much regret that the amount has exceeded the estimate which I sent in to you for $56, for both materials and labour. This is wholly due to the mistake which Mr. Mower made in his estimate. It now turns out that instead of twelve thousand shingles it took sixteen thousand. This was due to the character of the roof. Each of the "hips" on the roof were shingled and also the "hips" on the front verandah, and this made very much more loss through cutting than he had estimated. The cost of nails was also almost double his estimate, due to using 1\(\frac{1}{4}\)" size instead of 1".

I think this is the first time an estimate has exceeded the amount first sent in. Under the circumstances in which we find ourselves financially, I do not see that I can absorb the extra cost. At the same time I am loath to ask the Department for the balance. Consequently I would suggest that some of the $50 authorized for shingling the out buildings at the School, be used to pay this balance. Then by taking a Number 2 shingle for these buildings and exercising care in putting them on, we could get by with a minimum expenditure. I shall leave it to your own judgement as to whether you adopt this suggestion or ask the Department for the amount required.

The first account for materials, which should have been the only one, was for $43.89. This left $12.11 of the $56.00 remaining. The balance for the shingles and nails amounts to $21.85. The bill for work is $22.40, a total of $44.25. This leaves $17.85 of the other $50 allowed for shingling. It is not very much and I would appreciate it if the Department would pay the extra for shingling as above, and leave us the full $50 for the out buildings.
Mr. A.O'N. Daunt.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I am now able to present to you certain facts in connection with an increase of equipment for boys and girls handicrafts. I have a competent Dress-Maker undertaking instruction for our girls over and above the work that is done in the Mending Room, where repairs to clothing are made. In addition, Mr. Peake, who is Boys' Supervisor and a tailor by trade, has undertaken to do the repairs for all boys' clothing. We have had to take a machine from the girls' side and give it to Mr. Peake over on the boys' side, but he is satisfactorily. He is training boys in this work which I feel is a very practical thing. The difficulty is that we have not enough machines to do this work properly. I need at the very least one new machine for the boys' side.

I have taken the matter up with the Singer Sewing Machine people, and they have an up-to-date machine which would be satisfactory at $105. Applying the usual discount of 15% and a special discount of 4%, this leaves the price of the machine to the Department at $50.49.

I would like also to bring the matter of increased equipment for our Shoe Repairing to the favorable consideration of the Department. This is a very practical training and something which a boy can take hold of and put to practical use in his home village. In order to give adequate training, using only tools necessary for Hand work and one machine, which the average boy would be able to secure for himself, it would require $125. I have secured prices from the Singer Machine Company and from Denby Brothers with regard to cost of supplying a satisfactory machine. The price from the Singer people is $103 while that from the Denby people is $90. In addition to the buying in 1930-31, I think that the Denby machine would be more satisfactory. The lower part of the machine is adjustable and could be renewed if necessary, while the same part on the Singer is cast in one piece as part of the body of the machine. The Denby machine is heavier also. It is practically impossible for anyone doing Shoe Repairs to get along without one of these stitching machines, as the stitching is not only a very slow process by hand, but in some cases can not be done by hand. Mr. Fordred, our instructor, is a Shoe Maker by trade and he intends to have each of the boys now working at shoe repairing supply their own pair of shoes complete this year in addition to doing the repair work for the School. If the Department would be agreeable to securing the Stitching Machine from Denby Brothers at $90, I would take care of the $35 for hand tools out of School funds by applying the balance from our Manual Training Prize money for that purpose. You will remember that last year the Department allowed Allan Young to remain for a year to take further training on condition that he buy his own tools.
It happened that he was able to do so, but when he went home last Summer, he took his tools with him, hence the need for extra tools if we are to keep two boys employed as we hope to do. I trust that the Department will give this their favorable consideration, as I am sure it will put our Shoe Repairing on an adequate basis for training of these boys. With all good wishes, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I have been going into the matter of a Diesel engine with some care and I am now able to give you certain facts in this connection. From all I can learn the full Diesel put out by the Vivian Engine Works of Vancouver is giving good satisfaction on the Coast. I have talked with engineers who have had them in charge and also with officials of the Canadian Fishing Company, and they are well pleased with the performance of these engines. The cost however of purchasing a Vivian engine seems to me too high. I do not feel like asking the Department for an expenditure sufficient to get one at this time. I have received specifications and prices on their Marine and Stationary units. One 3 cylinder 30 H.P. Vivian four cycle full Diesel complete would cost, along with the auxiliary compressor unit, $2349.00 after a 10% discount. This same engine in a stationary type would cost $1989.00. A single cylinder marine unit, 11 H.P. complete, would cost $775.00 exclusive of Sales Tax in each case.

It is possible however, to secure a 7 H.P. Lister four cycle, full Diesel, the same as has been installed in St. Michael's School, Alert Bay, for $410. These Lister engines have given fine satisfaction at Alert Bay. If we had one I think it would be sufficient for demonstration purposes, as it has the Bosch fuel injection system just the same as the Standard Vivian or Atlas Imperial machine, thus we would have in this unit all that is necessary for instruction purposes. In addition, by expending $40 we could extend our main line Laundry shaft through the partition of the adjoining room. The engine could be set up there and used to run our Laundry. This is the same engine they have been running at Alert Bay to supply Laundry power with perfect satisfaction for the last six years.

In view of the fact that it seems likely we shall have to make some compromise with the B.C. Electric Company in connection with their account for back power, if we had this engine we could supply that power for 1½¢ per K.W. hour as compared with nearly 4¢ taken to run the big 7 H.P. motor at present supplying that power. Thus this engine would fill a double need and I would strongly recommend its being installed. I might add that the year of the Ice Storm we had to rent a gasoline engine to provide power for over three weeks, and having this unit it would insure against a repetition of that.

Our Motor Mechanics department seems to be doing good work, and the boys are interested. Several of them who are at present attending School this year, have been on Seine boats and Packers, and if we can give them

Dear Sir:

For a long time I have been anxious to secure a better Moving Picture outfit, but up to the present have not seen how we could possibly finance it even if we were able to buy the machine itself. We have a small silent machine, and while it is a great deal better than nothing, still it does not allow much scope for either educational or purely entertainment films. We are reduced to using the same ones over and over. In the standard 35 mm. machine we would have the one for which films are being made and we would have access to a large and constantly growing library of educational, travel and other films. As I have said, I could not see up to now how we could finance it, but if we could get some assistance from the Department in buying the machine, I think now we could handle it to great advantage.

It seems more necessary that we secure a machine with sound reproducing apparatus because each year we are reduced to our own resources to provide entertainment for our pupils. This is due to the Quarantine which our Medical Officer places us under. Some times we have contagious diseases in the School. This year in the first part of the term it was Mumps, but ever since last Fall Measles have been rampant in the surrounding community. Consequently our children have not been allowed to go to the Picture Show in Chilliwack, and it has aggravated the problem of School discipline in addition to the loss of education in such things.

In conference with Mr. Williams, our Manual Training Instructor, we have devised a scheme whereby pupils at the beginning of the term would take out a Season Ticket. In this way we would be assured of paying for film rentals and perhaps something towards the cost of the machine. We have gone into this matter in detail and we feel sure that the best offer received yet is for a second hand 'Soundon' machine with a guarantee of first class condition with the sound apparatus completely new. The cost of the machine is $150. If the Department could see its way clear to make us a grant of $75, the School could handle the remaining amount.

I am sure this would help immensely, as I have heard what goes on the Reserves, stories of considerable dissatisfaction especially among the older pupils over the quarantine. In view of the tragic happenings in some other Schools this year, I feel that the action of our Medical Officer is warranted, but I do feel at the same time that we should do something to make the life at Coqualeetza as self-contained and happy as possible.

Trusting you will be able to grant us this consideration, I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.C. SCOTT
PRINCIPAL

I would appreciate receiving authority, at an early date, to proceed with the installation of the refrigerating system as this is the holiday period at the school and the work can be done more easily.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I believe you have on file a letter from the Frigidaire people, McLennan, McFeely and Prior, with regard to installing a refrigerator in our School. I think too that the Kelvinator people through Marshall-Wells B.C. Limited put in a bid some time ago. On looking up our files I find the Marshall-Wells quotation was put in under date of August 26, 1935, at a total cost of $852 complete. Davies and Logan of Chilliwack are the local representatives. You will be able to compare this figure with the one handed in by the Frigidaire people, for whom Menzies Hardware is the local representative.

I would like to emphasize again our need of such a plant. With four hundred pounds of milk a day to be taken care of and most of it used in the School, it is essential that we have proper facilities for taking care of this and other perishable foods. Now that we have a Milk House at the Barn, I intend to put in a Aerator by means of which the milk would be brought down at once from 95 degrees to a temperature as near 50 degrees as possible. Then if it were put at once into our refrigerator it would mean that the milk would be kept at a temperature below the point where bacteria spread freely. This would mean a great deal to us, as there will be days within the next two months and for the first two months following the opening of School, when we will lose milk. All through the Summer this is of course particularly true.

If it is at all possible I would appreciate it very much if the Department would give this installation their favorable consideration. This matter was first referred to in an estimate prepared in August 1935. I would be glad if you would forward this letter to the Department.

Thanking you I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.C. Scott

3. For new Kitchen Drain: Move one sink, if necessary; all materials, fittings, and labor to be supplied by the Plumber. (Exclusive of manual labor to make cutting for the drain) ----------------------------- 75.00

The above work is rendered necessary by the breakdown of the old drainage system. We have had great difficulty in carrying on until the end of the School year last month. It is impossible to get at these old drains, and the only way we could keep them open was by continuously blowing them out with steam. This we cannot do for another year. These old drains run into the walls, and cannot be followed, as we have been unable to secure plans of the same. All we know, is as far as we are able to explore with the steam hose. Apparently one of these drains runs under the Boiler Room floor.

The new drain will run across the Kitchen floor in front of the Kitchen Range, right to the outside wall. It will go through at a point opposite the Range, and then turn into the outside drain which at present takes away the dish water, and Kitchen refuse, and leads to the main drain to the settling tanks.

There will be clean out plugs on the inside, as the kitchen, and on the outside, at the point where it comes through the wall. This will enable us to insert a clean out rod both inside the building and out, for the entire length of the drain. The pipe used will be a four inch Soil Pipe and should obviate all trouble for years. The present pipe inside the building is only 2".

4. For 2 new water fronts for Kitchen Range, Pipe, all fittings and Labor -------------------------------------------- 35.00

At present we cannot get hot water although the fires are on from early morning. After consultation with Mr Arnall, there seems nothing to do but to install two new water fronts, as above. The old ones have been in for over twelve years, so far as I can learn. The range concerned is, of course, that in the main kitchen, a two fire box, two oven one.

Carried forward ----------------------------------------------- $245.00
Refit sink in Serving Pantry for washing dishes by steam, fittings and Plumber's work -------------- $245.00

Provide 22 wire baskets for this @ $1.50 each -- 33.00

The above project entails the item under 3. At present dishes are washed on each of the tables in the dining room. In the process, in spite of our supervision, food scraps, bits of dish cloths etc find their way into the dishpan, and are carried out and emptied down the outside drain mentioned under Item 3. In spite of triple screens, much of this waste, at least in pulverized form, gets into the drain and plays havoc with its functioning.

In addition, flies are attracted by food particles left in these screens; the smell, at times is very objectionable, and the whole system is not in the best interests of the children for health reasons.

Under the new system, all dishes will be placed in wire baskets, and hosed off with steam into which a small quantity of water has been introduced. They will then be carried back to the tables and the tables will be set for the next meal. All scraps of food will be scraped off before dishes are placed in the baskets, and will be taken in containers direct to the barrels in which our table scraps are kept until used for the pigs.

Thus, dishes will be sterilized, they will not be subject to improper drying, and the clogging of the outside drain, smells, and fly dangers, will be obviated.

I have discussed this change with Mr Arnall, and he assures me that it is quite feasible. Adequate care and supervision will be given during the washing of the dishes. Steam is at present laid to this sink, but the pipes lead to the bottom of the tubs, and is utilized to heat cold water until it is hot enough for washing purposes. Under the new system, valves will be placed on each of these pipes, and the water introduced in a common pipe leading to a short length of steam hose which will be used to direct the steam and water to the dishes in the baskets. Nothing but hot water and such grease as may adhere to the dishes will find its way into the drain.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I am enclosing herewith vouchers in quadruplicate for materials secured from the Valley Lumber Yards in connection with fitting up a Vegetable Room under the barn. I do not often go ahead without securing the Departmental authority, but something had to be done at once in order to save our vegetables. I had thought of getting a combined implement shed and vegetable house, and was making plans for it. This large room in the basement of the new barn was however available. I had it drained at School expense last Winter, but we were not sure that it would keep dry, and so I was somewhat undecided about using it. After investigating however, I found that it had no water in it even during the time of heavy rain, so I went ahead and had it fitted up.

It has given us a large room somewhat "L" shaped, approximately 36' long on each of two sides, and 18' wide. It is reached by a stairway from the main floor of the barn and can be locked securely. I have lengthened the air vents making them to lead from the floor of the barn to the floor of the vegetable room for the cold air, and from the ceiling of the vegetable room high up into the loft of the barn. We have sufficient bins and shelving to take care of all our vegetables.

The account is for materials only. The work was done by our Boat Builder and his helpers, and is a fine job. I am sure the Department will be pleased with the space we have made available in this way. I trust they will overlook my having gone ahead in this instance for the reasons given above, and will authorize payment of the account.

Yours sincerely,

R.C. SCOTT
PRINCIPAL

November 4th,
1937.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Res: Claim of British Columbia Electric Ry. Co. against Coqualeetza Residential School.

As you probably know, for some years the electric power for the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School has been supplied by the British Columbia Electric Ry. Co. When Mr. Scott took over the principalship a few years ago, he called in a representative of the Company and he checked over all the wiring, meters, etc. However, on July 12th, 1936, Mr. L. McPhee, District Representative of the Company, wrote to Mr. Scott, making a claim for $5,482.93 (later revised to $5,583.03) for power allegedly used by the School and not paid for because of an alleged defect in the meter supplied by the Company.

Since the date of the claim, our office has been in correspondence with the Company in regard to the matter. Mr. Beaton, my former colleague, in discussing it in Ottawa had his attention drawn by the Solicitor of your Department to the case of General Dairies Limited vs. Maritime Electric Co. Ltd., the decision on which he thought provided us with a good defense against this claim of the B.C. Electric Company. However, when, at the request of the Executive of the Board of Home Missions, we consulted the law firm of Clearihue & Strath in Victoria, B.C., it was pointed out by them that this case had been appealed to the Privy Council and that the latter body had given a decision a few months ago, reversing the decision of the Court of Appeal. This case will be found in the Maritime Electric Company vs. General Dairies Limited 1937 1 B.L.R. 609. As a result of this decision of the Privy Council, the law firm I have mentioned above advise us that, in their opinion, the B.C. Electric Company could collect this bill, and, if it were not paid, the Company could turn off the electric current from the School.

Then we suggested that the Solicitors negotiate for a settlement with the B.C. Electric Company, and they write now to say that the Company will accept $1,000. in full settlement, to be paid at the rate of $32.50 a month.
Now, our difficulty is that Mr. Scott has a deficit in the School account at the present moment and our Home Mission appropriation from the funds of the Church is exhausted. We have no available money with which to meet this unexpected—and to my mind—unfair claim. It does seem to us that the Indian Department ought to help us out in this unfortunate situation. It was no fault of Mr. Scott's, nor of our Board, that the Company's meter did not register the full amount of current which it is said was used. All the bills which were presented by the Electric Company were paid promptly. The Coqualeetza School is an enterprise which is carried on jointly by the Government and the United Church, and the per capita grant from the Government is not enough, of course, to make it possible to have any reserve from year to year.

As you know, the United Church is not a business organization and it is purely on charitable and Christian grounds that we are engaged in this work. My submission is that your Department ought to, at least, bear the major part of this account.

Will you be good enough to bring the matter to the attention of Dr. McGill and see if something substantial cannot be done.

With kindest regards,

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

RBC MLT

Dear Mr Daunt:

I am glad to report that our new system of washing dishes with steam by means of the wire baskets kindly supplied by the Department is a great improvement on the old way. It has been especially valuable during this Measles epidemic. Dr McQuarrie and Dr Henderson both seemed pleased that we were handling the work in this way.

In fact, I have made it thoroughly effective. I really need some more baskets. These supplied, take the large plates and the knives and forks at one time, but the "stalls" are much too high for the saucers. When these are put in, they slip through and lodge one on the top of the other in the bottom of the basket. They cannot be cleaned in that fashion. So we have to put them in the sink which is not very good in itself, and when they are finished, the basket from which they were taken has gone back into the dining room and confusion results.

If we had another 16 baskets, we could put the cups and saucers into them, and thus take care of all the dishes on each table at the one time, and ensure their getting the maximum benefit from the steam and hot water. The saucers could be washed down while the baskets were in the washing room, and would be ready for the dishes and to be reset upon their return.

Mr Fordred, our Engineer, takes charge of the washing and handles the steam, so that there is no danger to the children in any way. The confusion resulting from the inability to handle ALL the dishes belonging to each table, at the one time, does not help to get the girls into the way of the new system. I am anxious that it should be a complete success and would greatly appreciate it if the Department would allow me to secure the additional 16 baskets. These would cost the same as the first set—$1.50 each. Even though the sides are lower, being just half the height of the baskets for the plates, there is an extra compartment put in which makes up for the lesser amount of material used.

I am setting down a rough sketch of the basket I need.

Hoping for a favorable reply from the Department, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

P.S. The above would, of course, be a charge against the sum authorized for repairs for the current year. There is just over $1000.00 of the original $2000.00 still remaining, according to my count, so that there would appear to be room to include the above. It is getting late to attempt outside painting now.
