November 4, 1937.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Claim of British Columbia Electric Ry. Co. against Coqualeetza Residential School.

As you probably know, for some years the electric power for the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School has been supplied by the British Columbia Electric Ry. Co. When Mr. Scott took over the principalship a few years ago, he called in a representative of the Company and he checked over all the wiring, meters, etc. However, on July 12th, 1935, Mr. L. McPhee, District Representative of the Company, wrote to Mr. Scott, making a claim for $3,493.93 (later revised to $2,583.03) for power allegedly used by the School and not paid for because of an alleged defect in the meter supplied by the Company.

Since the date of the claim, our office has been in correspondence with the Company in regard to the matter. Mr. Beaton, my former colleague, in discussing it in Ottawa had his attention drawn by the Solicitor of your Department to the case of General Dairies Limited vs. Maritime Electric Co. Ltd., the decision on which he thought provided us with a good defence against this claim of the B.C. Electric Co. However, when, at the request of the Executive of the Board of Home Missions, we consulted the law firm of Clearihue & Straith in Victoria, B.C., it was pointed out by them that this case had been appealed to the Privy Council and that the latter body had given a decision a few months ago, reversing the decision of the Court of Appeal. This case will be found in the Maritime Electric Company vs. General Dairies Limited 1937 1 D.L.R. 609. As a result of this decision of the Privy Council, the law firm I have mentioned above advise us that, in their opinion, the B.C. Electric Company could collect this bill, and, if it were not paid, the Company could turn off the electric current from the School.

Then we suggested that the Solicitors negotiate
for a settlement with the B.C. Electric Company, and they write now to say that the Company will accept $1,000 in full settlement, to be paid at the rate of $32.50 a month.

Now, our difficulty is that Mr. Scott has a deficit in the School account at the present moment and our Home Mission appropriation from the funds of the Church is exhausted. We have no available money with which to meet this unexpected - and to my mind - unfair claim. It does seem to us that the Indian Department ought to help us out in this unfortunate situation. It was no fault of Mr. Scott's, nor of our Board, that the Company's meter did not register the full amount of current which it is said was used. All the bills which were presented by the Electric company were paid promptly. The Coqualeetza School is an enterprise which is carried on jointly by the Government and the United Church, and the per capita grant from the Government is not enough, of course, to make it possible to have any reserve from year to year.

As you know, the United Church is not a business organization and it is purely on charitable and Christian grounds that we are engaged in this work. My submission is that your Department ought to, at least, bear the major part of this account.

Will you be good enough to bring the matter to the attention of Dr. McGill and see if something substantial cannot be done.

With kindest regards,

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

(Sgd) R.B. Cochrane, D.D.
Ottawa, November 9, 1937.

The Cocolaletza Indian Residential School, at Sardis, B.C., is owned by the Department but is operated under the auspices of the United Church of Canada. They obtain their electric current from the British Columbia Electric Railway Company. Last year the Company checked the meters in use at the school and found that they were defective and that this condition had been in effect for the preceding two or three years. This resulted in the meters registering under consumption, and, as the Company based their bills on the meter readings, they did not receive payment for the actual amount of electric current that had been used. After carefully checking the meters the Company submitted to the Principal of the Cocolaletza School an account for $2,562.03, which amount they computed was due them but had not been paid.

As the school authorities had paid the amount requested by the company during the period in question and as the discrepancy arose owing to defective meters owned by the company, the school authorities took the position that they were not responsible for payment of the claim for $2,562.03. The Principal wrote the Department at that time and asked our opinion, and it was found that a similar case had occurred in the province of New Brunswick. This was the case of General Dairies Limited versus Maritime Electric Company. The Supreme Court of Canada ruled that the General Dairies Limited was not liable for the payment but the Privy Council reversed this decision and gave judgment in favour of the Company.

In view of the information contained in the above...
above paragraph, it would appear that the British Columbia Electric Company can legally collect the amount from the authorities of the Coqualeetza Residential School.

Within the last few months, the Company has offered to settle its claim against the school for $1,000.00. As you are aware, the school authorities pay for the electric current from the amount received for per capita grant. The authorities of the United Church of Canada point out that at the present time they are operating the Coqualeetza Residential School at a loss and are obliged to provide the deficit from their Mission funds. They have, therefore, appealed to the Department to assist them in meeting the claim of the British Columbia Electric Company. In view of all the circumstances, as outlined above, I feel that we should assist them to the extent of at least $500, and I enclose, for your consideration Memorandum to Council, which, I trust, will receive the approval of the Honourable the Minister.

Director.

Dear Mr Daunt:

I believe there is an amount of $982.67 which remains unexpended of the $2000.00 allowed for new equipment and repairs for the year 1937-8 which is now drawing to a close. As there does not seem to be any need for waiting further for what might be termed emergency items, I wish to submit the following list of really important items which I trust the Department will give its sympathetic consideration.

Disc Harrows: ----------------------------------------------- $ 89.00

The Department was good enough to authorize the purchase of a Gang Plow, and for the same reason I am asking for a set of Disc Harrows, namely, we have none of our own. For years we have borrowed and have had to await the time when neighbors could lend us theirs. As the years have passed this has been more and more difficult until now it has become exceedingly uncomfortable, and it results in loss to the farm through delays. I have taken this item up with the Massey Harris Company through their local agent, Frasides Ltd., of Chilliwack, and they have put in a set of 12 suitable for a three horse team, and supply carrier for the tongue for the same at the above price. I trust that the Department will grant us this; it is fundamentally necessary for the farm work and for the training of our farm boys as well.

2. Urinals and Toilet Equipment: ----------------------------- $ 683.34

Not long ago, I believe Inspector Barry sent in a report criticizing very severely our toilets and lavatory conditions generally. I wrote to the Department through you on that matter. At the same time, it is very urgent that we get the items listed at the foot of this paragraph. I may say that I have had Dr McQuarrie and Dr Henderson, our local Medical Health Officer look over these premises and equipment and they both declare that it is "impossible" for us to keep these toilets free from odor owing to the fact that the lime has penetrated the floor materials at the front of the toilets, whereas on both sides do their part, and while I do not for a moment admit the situation to be just as Inspector Barry has apparently presented it, still it is imperative that something be done to lessen the danger to floors, with consequent odors, and perhaps menace to health. Certainly it is prejudicial to comfort or satisfaction to any of us.

Carried forward: -------------------------------------------- $ 772.34
I took this matter up with the Department some two years ago, and submitted prices etc., but nothing has been done. I feel that if now, after receiving reports as noted above, if nothing is done, the responsibility for conditions will have to rest with the Department. I shall still do my best in any case.

We have done away with the bed room pails in the dormitories, and have put in partitions in the corridors so that the toilets are not liable to the boys during the night. At present they have to use the toilet bowls and it is in this way the floors become saturated with the dripping of urine, a certain amount of which is bound to find its way into the floors. The use of urinals—a 1-Stall in each of the upper Lavatories would lessen this difficulty at least fifty per cent, if not to completely eliminate it.

The 2-Stall Urinals are for the Basement Lavatories where the boys wash and use toilet facilities at least three times a day. I may say that we are very much pleased with the way the boys are responding to the endeavor we are making to give them better toilet facilities, such as toilet paper, deodorizers etc., and I feel sure that if we had these urinals, they would give hearty support to our efforts to improve conditions. In case of fire in the daytime or early morning or after supper in the early evening, our present alarm would not be heard in the Kitchen, Laundry, Dining Room, nor at the Barns or Manual Training Building. It is planned to put one of these alarms in the corridor leading to Staff and Student Dining Rooms, Staff and Student Kitchens, Laundry, Bakeshop and Shoe Repair Shop. Then the second gong would be put on the end of the Boiler Room outside, which would throw the sound to the barns and Manual Training Building quite easily. BOOK COPY
SPECIFICATION for the Several Works and Materials Required for

HIGH PRESSURE VERTICAL BOILER

for the

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, SASKATOON, B.C.

July, 1926

Generally:

The Contractors tendering on this work shall examine the premises and determine for themselves the amount and nature of the various works required, as it is the intention that everything necessary for a complete and perfect job shall be included and no excuse shall be taken for any oversight.

The Contractor shall supply all scaffolding, tools, materials and labour required to properly carry on the work to completion as speedily as possible. The materials used to be the best of the several kinds.

The whole of the works are to be carried out to the entire satisfaction of the Government Official acting under the instructions of the Department. Colours, etc., will also be selected by him.

The Contractor shall, on completion, leave the premises neat and clean, removing all rubbish and dirt whatsoever, and also repairing any damage to walls, glass and such like that may have arisen prior to the works being handed over.

Labour:

In the execution of the work as far as practicable and consistent with reasonable efficiency and economy, first consideration shall be given to the employment of those who if available and competent are most in need in the locality in which the works are to be performed, without any discrimination whatsoever; preference being shown to unemployed ex-service men and unemployed married and single men with dependents.

First Class Job:

Any work or material obviously necessary for the proper completion of the work, although not specified herein, is to be done or supplied by the Contractor without additional charge, it being understood that the amount of the tender covers everything necessary for a complete and first class job.

Character of Works, etc.

All the work is to be executed in a substantial and workmanlike manner and of the best materials and workmanship of their several kinds, in accordance with the specification and instructions given from time to time and all of the said work is to be carried out and completed under the inspection of the Officer in charge or his representative to the full and entire satisfaction of the same or any person delegated by him.
The Contractor or his representative is to give personal and constant attention to the work at the building as well as at the workshops.

Skilled, experienced workmen and their apprentices are to be employed on the work.

Sales Tax

Amount of the tender shall include all sales taxes in force or applicable at the time. In the event of a reduction in such sales being legally authorized between the time of the acceptance of the tender and the completion of the work, the benefits derived from such reduction shall accrue and be payable to the Department, and an amount covering such reduction will accordingly be deducted from the sum or sums payable to the contractor under the original agreement.

INSTALLATION

Supply and install at the above school a new vertical boiler having an approximate heating surface of 165 sq. ft., to be approximately 38" diameter, and 7'6" long, and to carry a working pressure of 140 lbs. per sq. in.

Boiler to be constructed of steel. The shell plates to have a tensile strength of 65,000 lbs. The longitudinal seam to be D.R.S.S. The furnace plates to have tensile strength of 55,000 lbs., and the longitudinal seam to be full lap.

Tubes to be of the best standard quality, and to be 2" outside diameter and rolled and beaded at each end.

Boiler Mountings.

Boiler to be supplied with the following mountings:

A 1½" Spring Loaded Top Safety Valve
B 2" Main Steam Valve of the regrounding type
C Try Gauge on the shell.
D Gauge Glass & Guard & Cocks.
E Long Pattern fusible plug.
F 1" Dropping Type Blow Down Cock. The Nipple between blow-down cock and boiler to be extra heavy black pipe.
G 1½" Injector including all necessary valves and cocks.
H A 6" Dial pressure Gauge graduated to 250 lbs., with syphon and cock.

Smoke Pipe and Hood.

Supply and install a new smoke pipe and hood made out of heavy black iron, hood to be flat top and to have a removable cover so arranged that free access to the tubes and tube sheet can be obtained. Smoke pipe to be taken from side of hood and connected to the chimney similarly to the present boiler. A damper is to be installed in smoke pipe between hood and chimney.
Boiler is to be complete in every respect and to fully comply with the B.C. Inspection Act for Steam Pressure Vessels of that type, and to be fully guaranteed for one year against material or workmanship defects. The Contractor will be required to furnish the Commissioner of Indian Affairs at Vancouver two (2) photostatic copies of the Registered Certificate of Manufacture.

The Contractor will be required to remove the present boiler from the boiler room and store it where directed.

On completion the whole boiler, head and smoke pipe are to be painted two coats of black fireplace paint. The boiler room is to be cleaned up, and all debris removed, leaving it in first class condition.

Dear Sir:

I have included in this year's estimates for repairs and new equipment, one Tailoring Sewing Machine for our Boys' Side. In the estimate I put in a price of $84.00, but on consultation with the Singer Sewing Machine Company, their recommendation was for a 31-K-15 machine with a motor, the total cost to be $113.

We have only one sewing machine on the Boys' Side, and the boys themselves are doing most of the mending of their own clothes. At present they do a great deal of sewing, patching, etc., by hand, but it is quite impossible to keep up with the demand. It is a fine thing that the boys are learning to look after their clothes, but as I have said, there is such a volume of it that they ought to have equipment to take care of it. There will still be plenty of mending to be done by hand, but the surplus which has to remain over from week to week, would be gotten rid of if they had the machine we are asking for. Mr. Peake, our Boys Supervisor, is a tailor by trade, and it is owing to his oversight and training that the boys are able to do this work.

I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would see fit to honour our request. We have 125 boys, so that you will see a machine such as we are asking for would be quite in order.

Thanking you for your interest and help at all times, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Many times throughout the year I have recalled your letter to me under date of May 5th, 1937, File 153-0-5 in which you stated that consideration was being given to the installation of two or three Moving Picture Equipments in some of the Schools. Once again I would like to bring before you our need of better facilities along this line. Our small 16 mm. Silent Machine has been in use a long time and before long will need either extensive repairs or renewal. Since my first letter, the library of 16 mm. films available for Schools has been largely increased, so that I am not now so much concerned, about a 35 mm. as compared with the 16 mm.

Last night Rev. A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's School at Lytton, visited us enroute home from Vancouver, and gave us a very fine picture show, using his new Sound Machine, and this has increased my anxiety to secure some such equipment. I find that not only Companies carrying 16 mm. films for rental have increased their libraries, but Government Departments and University Extension groups and the Board of School Trustees of Vancouver have provided libraries which are available to Schools such as ours. The educational factor in the showing of these films is very strong. No amount of teaching or reading for instance, could have given to our children the conception of the Fraser Valley, the rolling country, mountains and lakes of the Interior from Lytton to Telkwa, B.C., as did the showing of Mr. Lett's films last evening.

In addition to the educational needs, there is still the need for providing recreation owing to the strict quarantine which we are placed under for nearly two thirds of the School Year. Between Measles in the School before Christmas, and the amount of Whooping Cough, Scarlet Fever and Chicken Pox in the surrounding community since Christmas,

we have been left to ourselves to provide for our children's needs. Again let me say that I feel the quarantine is amply justified, as the health of the School has been excellent since Christmas. With the exception of a few mild cases of Chicken-pox, we have had little or no sickness.

Hoping that Coqualeetza may be one of the schools favored with the installation which you have in mind, and assuring you of my willingness to cooperate in any reasonable scheme which the Department may evolve,

Dear Sir:

As intimated in our conversation with you a day or two ago, we consider that the installation of a vertical boiler at the Coqualeetza Indian School is not of the most economical type, as when the boiler is under working conditions for laundry and sterilizing purposes, it has to be forced so as to maintain the head of steam required; and from this viewpoint we would suggest the consideration of the installation of a boiler of the horizontal type, which we consider would be better suited for the requirements. It would be much more economical to operate as it would not require to be forced as a steady head of steam can be maintained at a very low operating cost.

Furthermore, with this type of boiler the steam space is such that there always would be available a reserve amount of steam.

Furthermore, with the horizontal type of boiler much easier firing conditions are required, and with the travel of the gases being in a horizontal position you do not have the quick pull through that you have with the vertical type of boiler.

We would propose in this connection the supplying of a horizontal return tubular boiler complete in accordance with the requirements of the B.C. Inspection Act for a minimum working pressure of 155#, and with a heating surface of 155 square feet.
Instead of the ordinary brick setting we propose supplying steel casing made of 1/4" plate with connecting angles for bolting the panels of the casing together, and the interior of the casing would be lined with one inch of asbestos and 4 1/2" of brick, with the exception of the fire box portion which would be 3" thick.

This boiler complete with all steam mountings, and necessary castings for hand firing, completely connected up with suitable smoke pipe, etc., and including the removing of the old boiler would be at a price of One thousand three hundred and eighty-seven dollars ($1,387.00). This also being inclusive of all carriage and sales tax and installation charges.

This price is somewhat higher than that quoted by us on the vertical installation, but in the long run it would be a cheaper installation owing to the saving effected in operation.

Trusting this proposal will have your consideration, and awaiting your further word, we remain,

Yours truly,

Extract from Inspector Barry's report dated January 20, 1939.

I turned on the valves of the three outside hydrants and discovered that there was no water in the pipes that supply these outside hydrants. Water to the hydrants comes to them from inside the school. The pressure in the Sardis town supply is low in any case, about 40 pounds, and because of the size of the various supply pipes inside the school the pressure at the outside hydrants is too low for much success in fighting a fire of any size. As it would not be possible to increase the pressure much in any event I am not making any special recommendation at the present time. I just wish the Department to be aware that in case of fire at this school we shall have to depend mainly on chemical extinguishers, of which there are a number and these have been tested lately.

The Inspector's observations on the water supply and fire fighting arrangements have been noted. Dear Major MacKay:

I have read with some care an application from Rev. R.C. Scott, Principal of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, dated January 16th, in which he requests that approval be given for the expenditure of some $200.00 for materials in connection with the accommodation of certain members of his school staff.

I may say at once that I am very anxious that the services of Mr. Huddleston be retained as Boat Builder at this school. The retention on the staff of instructors who are married men, and who are well adapted for the work, is a very important factor in regard to the future of the School.

Could this matter, please, be considered as a Manual Training Project? The cost of materials only is being asked for and even here if the sum of $200.00 is exceeded the school authorities will be responsible for the balance. The boys, under supervision, will do the work and thus learn the best way to make such improvements to their own homes on the various Reserves.

I would therefore strongly recommend that not more than $200.00 be set aside for the above mentioned Manual Training Project if there is any available fund from which such a sum might be obtained so late in the Fiscal Year.

Re: Farmer's Cottage at Coqualeetza.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

On August 3rd, 1934, File 1-8-B, I took up with the Department through you, the matter of accommodation for our farmer, for even at that time, I could see that if we were to keep efficient help, one would have to provide for a married man. This has been my experience ever since. I had to pay rent for a cottage for Captain P.F. Pirie until the beginning of this School year, when Mr. R. Carter became Farm Instructor upon the resignation of Captain Pirie. Up to now Mr. Carter has been living in a small cottage just behind the residence, but it is totally inadequate, as he has four children, and there is only one bedroom, and another sort of enclosed verandah space, which they are using for the time being as another bedroom. As his children are growing up, it is absolutely necessary that he have more accommodation. Consequently, I had a cottage moved from down near the Boat Shop, to a position on the left of the driveway as you proceed to the Preventorium. This was done at School expense, at a cost of $55.00.

The case for accommodation for the Farm Instructor has been emphasized by my experience with the Boat Builder, Mr. R. Huddleston. As you know, we have been most fortunate in having an instructor of the type of Mr. Huddleston, who not only understands his business, but has a way of getting his instruction over to the boys who have worked with him in the Boat Shop. He got married just over two years ago, and then because I had no accommodation at the School, and of course because he thought he was going to better himself, he resigned and we lost his services. During the Fall Term, I interviewed several Boat Builders, but was not able to secure a suitable man. Either he was a really good man and wanted too much money, or they were men of doubtful standing in their work, and men whom I could not be at all sure of fitting into the life of the School as an instructor. However, I am glad to say, for the School's sake, we have been able to re-engage Mr. Huddleston, and if I can get accommodation for him and his family here...
at the School, he is quite willing to again undertake an instructor's position and I hope by the end of this month we will be again busy in our Boat Shop. As the majority of our boys will be fishermen when they leave, I am sure the Department will be heartily behind this phase of our School work.

From the foregoing, you will see that my problem is one of accommodation for both the Farm Instructor and the Boat Builder. Having moved the afore mentioned cottages, I have now two cottages which could be fitted up if I could get the help of the Department. I took this up with Inspector Barry last week, and he was of the opinion that the work of reconditioning these cottages under the supervision of our Manual Training Instructor, would be very valuable training for our senior boys. It would be necessary however, for me to secure the materials. When I wrote in 1934, my scheme was to build a bungalow for the Farm Instructor at a cost of $820.81. This the Department was not willing to undertake, but if they would now be agreeable to allowing us $200 for necessary materials, we could fix up both of these cottages, and thus have accommodation for these two very necessary instructors. All work would be done by the Manual Training staff and the senior boys. The materials needed would include:- replacement of doors and windows, wall board, painting, kalsomine, chimney repairs, shingling and bathroom equipment, septic tank, piping in water and water connections. Itemized statements of description, amount and cost of materials would be submitted to the Department in the usual way, the total cost not to exceed $200. All charges submitted will be for materials only, the work to be done by our senior boys as a Manual Training project, and any cost over and above the $200 would have to be absorbed by the School.

From my knowledge of Indian villages, that is exactly what is needed in very many of them, namely a reconstruction of the houses. In many of these villages, they have water piped to the homes, and the training that these boys would get in the above project, ought to be valuable both as training and as a suggestion of what can be done with an old building.

I trust that you may see your way clear to recommend this expenditure on the part of the Department, and as I have said, I feel sure it will be a very practical training for these boys, and will help to solve the problem of accommodation for staff, which has been a very pressing one for the School.

Thanking you for your interest at all times, I am,

Yours sincerely,

"R. C. Scott"

Principal.

Reverend Sir:

Your letter of the 24th instant reached my office this afternoon and I am very much disturbed to note that you have arranged for the painting of the building. When you visited the Department you were informed that money was available for this purpose, but no authority whatever was given to you to proceed with the work.

As you are aware, there are very definite regulations in force now, requiring that all material be purchased through our Purchasing Branch, and it is also necessary to consult our Head Office before employing anyone to do work at a residential school for which the Department is expected to pay.

Since you were in Ottawa I have been expecting to hear from you every day, giving the quantities of paint required and other information regarding the painting of the Coqualeetza school, but your letter of the 24th instant is the first communication that has been received in connection with this matter since you were here.

Please let me have your explanation regarding your action in this matter at the earliest possible date.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Referring to our conversation when in Ottawa in April, with regard to getting the paint so that we could do the work ourselves on the smaller buildings, I beg to say that I have received the enclosed statement from Davies and Logan of Chilliwack. They tendered on the whole job, but there was so little difference between any one of the three tenders, that I felt it better to give the contract for the main building, the Principal's residence and the Manual Training building to Menzies Hardware, and they are now at work, although the weather has been so wet that it has been exceedingly hard to make much headway.

Your suggestion was I think, in consultation with Mr. Phelan, that we might get the paint on the enclosed list and charge it to the B.C. Special Grant. All the buildings are very very much in need of painting. This is only too apparent in the work already undertaken and I trust that it may be possible for us to get the materials as enclosed. We will begin in the late summer and try to finish up in the early Fall when the weather is usually good. I may say that Davies and Logan are agents for Marshall-Wells paint and they are giving us the wholesale price, F.O.B. Vancouver.

I would be glad if you would advise me as soon as possible so that I may keep our staff busy through the summer.

Yours sincerely,

DEPARTMENT OF NATIONAL DEFENCE

Office of the Minister, OTTAWA,

June 17, 1929.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

I understand that your Department purchases trucks for your various residential schools. Representations have been received by the Minister on behalf of the Coqualeetza Residential School, Sardis, B.C., where it is stated they are urgently in need of a ton or a ton and a half truck.

The Principal, the Reverend R. C. Scott, has nothing for the transportation of his pupils except an old Buick car which he had made over into a truck. This has seen constant use and is stated to be unsafe for the transportation of the pupils at the present time. For your information I may say that the engine model is stated to be a 1917 model and the brakes are in very bad condition.

They use the truck for carrying drinking water during the two months they camp near White Rock, and as they have to bring two barrels at least of water each day for drinking and cooking purposes, they will certainly require some kind of vehicle before they go to camp. They also take the children once a week to Blaine, to the picnic park, and use the old truck and the Principal's car between the camp and the park, both going and returning.

They also need transportation in case any of the pupils become ill and have to be taken to a doctor or hospital. With sixty to seventy pupils at the camp, it can be expected that this will be necessary at least once or twice during the camp season. The Principal cannot leave his own car there all the time, and if the truck is unfit for use, they are without means of transportation and there is no telephone within two miles of the camp.

June 29th, 1939

Dear Mr Hoey:

I have your letter of the 28th inst this evening. I cannot say how deeply I regret having gone ahead with the painting job without first consulting the officials here. While I certainly did not take your words as authorizing me to go on with the work, I did however take them to mean that the matter was settled, and I inferred that the officials here had been informed and seeing that this particular figure had been accepted, as I thought, there was nothing to hinder my getting Menzies to do the work in accordance with the letter submitted to me a year ago, and sent on to the Department.

I have secured figures each year for the last three years, and have included the amounts in the repair sheet sent in to the Department. Consequently, as I have said above, when you mentioned the matter to me it seemed as though it had at last been decided, and I proceeded upon getting home, to see Menzies and advise them that their contract had been accepted.

I have been confusing all along, the acceptance of a figure for forwarding to the Department, and its being actually accepted. I have always felt that if a figure was for any reason not acceptable, it would not be forwarded by our officials here. Consequently, when this particular figure was the one which appeared on the sheet you showed me in Ottawa, I inferred that nothing else was necessary.

I have tried at all times to cooperate with the Department, and I would not for the world have gone ahead with this work, had it not been for what I now see to have been a rather stupid lack of thought on my part. I ought to have known that some notification should have been forthcoming from our officials here, but I really did not know it was the policy of the Department to get what seemed to me to be a repetition of a figure before accepting it. The procedure has never been explained to me, and it was only a few days ago when I mentioned the work being undertaken to Mr Daunt, that he explained that I had really gone ahead upon my own authority and that it would not be acceptable to the Department.

I apologize most sincerely, and only hope that my action has not been construed to have been owing to anything you may have said to me while in Ottawa, for it was only indirectly so, and I now see that I did not understand at all, the workings of the Department in these matters.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I am sending to Mr Daunt to be forwarded to Major MacKay, which I trust will make clear that I, and I alone am to blame.

I did not write you earlier about the materials for painting the other buildings, because I have been more than busy, and the weather has been such as to render any work of that kind impossible. Consequently, I decided to wait and get the materials late, and then do the work toward the end of the holidays, and complete it when the pupils came back as the weather is usually good in September.

I trust that some arrangement may be made which will be acceptable to the Department in the present instance, and can only say again how greatly I regret having seemingly set departmental regulations at nought; I did not realize I was doing so.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

June 26th, 1930.

Dear Mr. O'Connell:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Ross by Air Mail this evening in which he accuses me that he is much disturbed over my having gone ahead with the painting of the school building without authority. He states that his information to me was simply that there was money available for that purpose, but it was in no sense giving me any authority to go ahead with the work.

That is quite right. I did not take it that he was authorizing me to proceed with the work, but seeing I knew, misapprehended entirely the action of the Department in setting aside the particular sum involved, as being tantamount to acceptance, I inferred that officials here had been advised, and that it was expected that I would proceed to advise the firm which gave that particular amount as their figure for the job.

I now see that I have been quite wrong, and I want to take the full blame for my action.

With all the orders away of this year, and the School closing pressing upon me, I am afraid that I did not take time to really think the thing through. At the same time, I want to say that I have been quite wrong in my understanding of Department regulations, for I have proceeded under the assumption that no further action was to be expected by our officials here, if the figure set forth in a repair sheet was accepted as a basis by Ottawa.

I shall certainly never be involved in such a mistake again, and wish to apologize and to hope that the Department will accept my explanation, and be good enough to do what may be possible to bring the matter in line with their usual procedure. Meanwhile, I again wish to say how much I regret the entire misunderstanding, for I really do wish to act in harmony with the Department in all things.

I suppose I was influenced too, by the knowledge that this particular firm (Mandela) is an old time Liberal organization, and that their figure was the lowest one received.

I would appreciate it if you would forward a copy of this letter to the Commissioner, and assure him that I shall come in the first of the week to express my regret personally.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr Daunt:

Re Painting Principal's Residence, Main Building, and Manual Training Building.

Enclosed herewith please find letter from Menzies Hardware Co., of Chilliwack undertaking to do this work, specifying materials, details of work, and cost of same.

You may remember that I sent you the estimates for this work in September last, along with other items. I presume it was sent on to the Department in the regular way.

When Mr Hoey added "do not be too long getting started at this work," I naturally thought that he was informing me so that I might see to its being undertaken without delay, and it never occurred to me that neither you nor the Commissioner had seen it.

If it is the policy of the Department that such undertakings should be authorized also from the start, it is possible Mr Hoey had no other thought than that he would take it up with you upon my return.

However, seeing I had been informed down there, I went right at the work when I got home. It looks as though I am at fault, but as I have said, it never occurred to me that you had not been notified, and seeing the item had been sent on to Ottawa in the regular way, I did not realize that it should have been again taken up through your office.

I would be glad if you would inform Commissioner MacKay of this side of the occurrence, for I certainly would never knowingly have done anything aside from the regular procedure.

The slight increase in the amount of the contract is due to the fact that the moss was much more rank after a year's growth than when the original figure was submitted. At that, Mr Menzies informed me today that it had cost him more than twice what he had estimated this last time. The moss could not be removed with a long handled brush, but had to be dug out from between the shingles with smaller tools, and it took time.

I trust that you may see your way clear to recommend this expenditure and that Major MacKay will overlook my seeming neglect to put the item through in the regular way. As I have said, it never occurred to me that it had not been dealt with here.

There are other items pending of which Mr Hoey spoke, I shall take them up through your office in a day or two.

Regretting very much my lack of thought in this matter, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to say that I have received your letter under date of October 4th, File:150-65, enclosing copy of a letter of February 10th, 1938 with regard to fire drills.

We are carrying out the instructions of the Department and since getting the letter have been holding fire drills every two weeks previous to that time and holding them every two weeks in September and October. Each member of staff has written instructions as to his and her position and the sheet containing these positions is posted in dormitories and other departments, as well as that for the positions of the older children appointed for fire duty. None of our fire doors are locked and the windows are made into doors opening outwards in one piece so that there is no delay in exit.

Last March our fire alarm system shorted at about five o'clock in the morning, causing bells to ring. It was a complete surprise to everyone and was a very good test of discipline. I am glad to report that I was called immediately by the staff member appointed, and dressing hurriedly, reached the front lawn just as the girls were forming up in line. The staff member on duty in the girls' dormitory instructed the girls to each one put a blanket over their shoulders so that although they had not taken time to dress, they were fairly well protected. The drill was carried out just as though it had been a practice one and it was a great satisfaction to me, for we had often wondered what actually would happen if we had a fire. The only missing factor to cause panic might have been the presence of smoke, but the test was sufficiently real to afford fair confidence in the actions of both staff and pupils.

When I came to the school, I found they were using the dormitory over the Manual Training shop for accommodation of boys about twelve years of age. I was not satisfied at that time with the fire escape, an iron ladder, and had it lengthened. I also took precautions with the heating and have always had at least one staff member and one senior boy in charge. I thought of asking for assistance from the Department to provide an iron fire escape similar to those on the main building, but in view of the fact that the school may be discontinued, I did not press that expenditure this year. After a good deal of thought, I decided to build a wooden stairway down the outside of the building as this would be a big advantage over the one staircase in the building, which was almost sure to be a regular "trump" in case of fire. I purchased the materials out of school funds and had the work done by our Manual Training instructors and their senior class. Each boy in
Mr. R.A. Hoey,

November 4th, 1939

the Senior Class, made a drawing of the proposed stair case and then assisted in building it. It comes down from the middle window of the front, which opens out in one piece like a door, along the side of the building, providing an easy and safe exit. The boys are using this stairway in all fire drills just as though they were in the main building.

As the building of this stairway was a bona fide Manual Training project, I presume the Department will be quite agreeable to my including the cost of materials in my regular quarterly Manual Training vouchers. The total cost was under twelve dollars.

I may say I also have a night watchman on duty from the 1st of October.

Assuring you of my desire to co-operate at all times, I am,

Dear Mr. Todd,

Further to our conversation of today's date, I have to make application for the transfer of the washer, extractor, dryer and motors therefore from the laundry of the Coqualeetza School, same to be included in our Departmental Inventory on receipt.

As you are aware, we do the laundry work for the Preventorium and the volume is becoming heavier than our present equipment can handle, and the addition of this equipment would prove a real boon to the School. The equipment from Coqualeetza is motor powered and as we have city power now installed in the School for electric irons, this equipment could be hooked in on the power lines and an unnecessary load avoided for our Diesel engines.

There is ample room in our laundry for the installation of this equipment and I am prepared to recommend to the Commission that the School will meet freight charges on the shipment from Vancouver or from Seattle should there be no funds available. The addition of this equipment would be well worth the $30.00 or $40.00 required to pay freight.

As it appears that time is a factor, would you consider wiring the Department either at Vancouver or Ottawa to have a salvage sale of this equipment delayed until this application can be given consideration?

Thanking you,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
-Principal.

Dear Sirs:

We, the undersigned ex-pupils of Coqualeetza Residential School, Sardis, B.C., take this opportunity to lay a serious grievance before you as representatives and Secretaries of the Board of Missions of the United Church of Canada, to which Church we all belong.

Recently our people have been informed by the Local Indian Agent that no more boys and girls of this place are to be sent to the aforementioned school for their education, and we and our parents are very greatly disappointed and disturbed over the matter, and for the following reasons:

I. The day school of our village has never in the past, nor does it now supply all the advantages in education such as we require, Domestic Science, Music, Vocational Instruction, Boat Building, etc. Invaluable preparation for life service. Why should our younger brothers and sisters and our children be denied these advantages which have hitherto been given us?

II. During the recent epidemic of Flu in our village many of our fathers and mothers died, leaving several children of school age now having lost one or both of their parents are very greatly in need of guardianship and guidance at the critical time of life. Our situation, serious at all times, is doubly so just now in view of the fact that our parents find it difficult or impossible to support their families. Why should innocent children suffer and lose their lives because of the whims of present Government policy?

It has been our hope for some years that a Residential School might be built by the Government for our children somewhere in the north, say at Skidegate or Fort Simpson, for the education of our boys and girls from United Church homes. We have been encouraged to believe that we might expect this, but this changed policy of the Government has destroyed any such hopes. Would it surprise you to learn that there are more than two hundred and fifty people, seventy-five of whom are under guardianship in moral and religious endeavor is given to the Coqualeetza? Is the present Government not concerned about the future moral and religious conditions among the

Indian people? Or is the present trend the product of immature conclusions or ridiculous fads on the part of some officials in the Indian Department who are seemingly all-powerful today?

As children of the Church we lay our grievance before you in the hope that your influence as our advocates may speedily change the policy of the Department so that several needy cases in our village may receive sympathetic consideration and be permitted to proceed immediately to the school of our choice to receive such education which has been heretofore denied us.

Dear Sirs:

On March 5th we received from Skidegate a petition signed by 41 members of the Band asking us to use our influence to have the restrictions in regard to children from Skidegate being educated at Coqualeetza relaxed.

I am returning for your files a copy of your petition, and would like to remind you that you did not enclose a list of children who are at present applying for reception at Coqualeetza and being refused - according to your statement - by the Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of April 20, File No. 1-8-E, I beg to enclose herewith application forms for No. 0599 Robert Bolin and No. 819 Jacob Grant. I regret the poor form of this latter application. It was made out by the missionary R.L. McConnell at the time and corrected by Mr. Fougner, Indian agent, who put in the full name of the boy, Jacob William, and corrected the age from nine to eleven, and inserted the birthday. I had very great difficulty in securing this application. The parents sent the boy to school in the beginning of the year and then seemed to be on the move so constantly that the missionary was not able to get in touch with them until quite recently. September 10 was the date the boy arrived at school. There being only one mail a month to Kitimat, means a two months delay at the best of times.

I am also enclosing a list of pupils sixteen years of age and over who are in attendance and upon our rolls here in this school. I have given reasons why I feel it would be wise to allow these children at least another year. In general I would like also to say that the school has suffered financially this year owing to children staying away. This was largely due to causes quite beyond our control. The ice-storm a year ago came when parents from Vancouver Island were visiting the school, and they spread the news of the terrible condition of things, giving the impression that it was a usual occurrence. The unfortunate fatal sickness in four instances also meant that children were taken home and kept home. Added to this the long-shoremen's strike on lower Vancouver Island and the poor fishing in the Queen Charlotte's and on the Nass River, completed a very difficult situation. As a result I can foresee a deficit of in the neighbourhood of one thousand dollars. If we can fill the school next fall we can absorb it nearly all. In order to do this I would greatly appreciate it if we may be allowed to keep all sixteen year old children and upwards, those willing to stay as set forth in the list enclosed. This will help to insure our pupilage for next fall, in addition to being, I feel, very much in the interests of the children themselves. I feel that we are making progress in the practical side of the education we are giving these children and I am quite sure that they will benefit largely another year.

I am also enclosing a second list of pupils who have remained away from school without permission. There are fifteen years old and upwards and in accordance with Section 10 of the Indian Act. I hope it may not be necessary to use any compulsion, and in any case shall try to use all possible discretion, but I would like to be able in the case of these older children to have the assistance of the Indian agent in securing their return to school, if they remain out again.

Dear Mr Daunt:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your statement regarding the Blue Sheets which I have just sent you, in which you point out that I have not followed the instructions of the Department regarding discharges as set forth in their letter of May 28th last, a copy of which you had sent forward to me.

In reply I beg to say that I have asked for more discharges than the Department has asked for in Paragraph (1) of that letter, and have included most of those asked for there.

With regard to the first list of pupils, of whom the letter says "Their names should not appear on future returns", I beg to point out that in Para. 2, Paragraph (2) the Department authorizes at least four of these same pupils to remain in School for another year. This being so, and in view of the fact that it is quite impossible for me to advise the pupils involved, that they will not be allowed to return, and seeing I have already let it be known that several of them are planning to come back, it seemed unwise to ask for the discharge of any but those whom I have set down on the Discharge Sheet which accompanies the returns.

I note that the Department says that any who may return could be re-admitted, but my experience with regard to allowing pupils to come to School and then trying to secure the Admission Forms, has shown the great difficulties involved. The children come to School from the reserves, in most cases, go off to their tree lines or to places where they put up their winter supply of fish, and it is months before I can get the necessary forms. In one such case, that of Henry Pahl, I have been unable for the past year to get the required forms.

In view of these facts, and especially as the per capita grant is involved in only one case—that of Allan Young—I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would allow the returns for this Quarter (June) to stand with the distinct understanding that all the names set forth in their letter of May 28th will be put upon the Discharge sheet for the September Quarter, thus clearing up the whole matter without the chance of complications arising from any of them returning as is almost certain at the present moment. All who do not return should certainly be struck off the roll, and I shall undertake to see that this is done. I am quite in agreement with the desire of the Department to have the names of all these pupils taken off, if they do not return in September next.

With regard to Allan Young, the only name which involves the Per Capita earnings, he has been in residence all the past School year and in harmony with the practice of the Department's usage. I would appreciate it if his name might remain until the September Quarter returns go in, and we might receive the Per Capita grant for the 43 days allowed for holidays in the usual way.

I would be glad if you would acquaint the Department with the information contained in this letter, and trust that they will be agreeable to my request.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours sincerely,

In view of the information contained in the Principal's letter of July 11th, it has been decided to accept the June quarter return, with the distinct understanding that all pupils whose names were mentioned in official letter of May 28th, and who have not returned to the school by the time the September quarter return is being prepared, shall be included on the discharge sheet for the September quarter.

Please inform the Principal that, in future, in the case of any pupil who is absent from the school for three months, his or her name should be struck off the return and included on the discharge sheet.

In the case of re-admissions to the school, it is not necessary to secure new application forms. The only information the Department requires, when it is desired to re-admit a pupil who has been formerly attending the Coqualeetza School, is that application for such re-admission should be made to the Department by the proper Indian Agent, and assurance, by a medical certificate, that the pupil for whose re-admission application is being made is in good health.

It is noted that the June quarter return contains the names of three Peterson children, who come from the Vancouver agency. The application forms submitted for these children showed that the medical examiner considered each of them has active tuberculosis. Mr. Agent Ball was informed, in official letter of June 20th, last, the Department was not prepared to approve their admission to the Coqualeetza School. Please request the Principal to have these children re-examined at once, and, if they have active tuberculosis, they should be returned to their grandfather, who resides on the Capilano reserve.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

SIR:

I beg to forward you herewith, copy of communication received from the Office of Mr. Indian Agent Ball, Vancouver Agency, and also one from the Education Branch of the Department, in connection with the illegitimate children of Mary Mathias Joe, deceased, a Squamish Indian woman, who resided on the Capilano Indian Reserve.

Prior to relinquishing the position of Medical Superintendent of the Vancouver Health Unit, I arranged to have these three children clinically examined and X-Rayed at the Vancouver Chest Clinic, as I was informed that an application was being submitted to the Department to have them admitted to the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School at Sardis. I heard nothing more about them until I was informed that they had been in Coqualeetza School for two months, but not in the Preventorium.

Following the receipt of this information, I instructed the Reverend Principal that they were to be immediately removed from the student body and admitted to the Preventorium. Now I find that the Department will not sanction their admission to the School in any event.

Mr. J.D. Sutherland, Acting Superintendent of Indian Education, has apparently been misinformed about the health of these three children. None of them have active pulmonary tuberculosis disease of the infectious type. One child is entirely free of the disease, while the second has "type F" and the third "type G", neither of which are to be classified as "open" cases. From a medical standpoint all three of them are fit subjects for admission to Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

I am not particularly interested in anything but the medical end of this problem, but I am interested in keeping the main student body of this School tuberculosis-free.

I feel that if our efforts along these lines are going to be successful, there must be the fullest cooperation between the School, the Indian Agent and myself, in connection with the admission of suspected children such as these to Coqualeetza or any other School, which we are trying to keep free of tuberculosis. Two of these children are potential spreaders and since their admission the disease may have made such progress as to render them a source of danger to the whole student body. I cannot understand why Mr. Indian Agent Ball did not consult me before these children were sent to Coqualeetza Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

A.L. McQuarrie, M.D.
Assistant Director of Medical Services for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of May 28th received. We are very glad to know you were successful in securing some money for repairing our wharf. In a way we are helpless, we have no voice to demand our rights, that is why the Massett people appreciate your consideration. We are one and all very grateful, let us hope we may have a chance to show you how much we value your help.

Our Indian Agent, Mr Gillet, was transferred to Bella Coola, now we have no one here to look after the interest of the people. We have several very important matters to be attended to right now, we hope you would make time to look into this at once.

We have some children in Coqualeetza Residential School "Sardis B.C" and "Alert Bay." We have been unable to get our children to come home for their holidays the last two summers. It is a hardship and great burden on all our poor people, when we have to pay for their transportation to and from the school. It costs us forty dollars round trip for one child eighty dollars for two children. Now eighty dollars will buy enough grub for man and wife and four children to last them all through the winter. We appeal to you to ask the authorities to enforce the provision laid down in the Indian Act, which reads:

The Superintendent General may provide for the transport of Indian children to and from the boarding or industrial schools to which they are assigned, including transportation to and from such schools for the annual vacations.

We have some other matters to put before you at a later date.

With kindest regards, I remain

Yours Respectfully,

Chief Councillor

Dear Sir:

It is desired to refer to the problem of the three Peterson children who have been in the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School but who were directed not to be formally admitted to that institution. In this connection, I wish to refer for your convenience to the Department's letters 2-83 of July 20th, July 6th, and June 20th. Doctor McQuarrie has reported on their medical examination to the effect that none of them have active pulmonary Tuberculosis in a communicable form.

The matter seems to have become somewhat involved, and I think the best way of dealing with it is to lay down two principles which the Department would like to have followed.

1. That the Department cannot authorize the admission to Residential Schools of children who are not recognized as Indians. On this point it may be said that if the father has definitely abandoned them the Department might consider a recommendation for their admission to the Band whether entitled to interest distribution or otherwise. If the father has not abandoned them, he should provide for their maintenance away from the Reserve. If they are to live on the Reserve, they should be recognized as members of the Indian Community.

F. J. G. Ball Esq.,
Indian Agent
205-6 Rogers Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
2. That the Department does not wish to have admitted to the Coqualeetza School children who are already subjects for preventorium treatment. Admission to the school involves the Department taking charge of the children for a period of several years, and it does not wish to assume such responsibility for children who are in a doubtful condition from a Tuberculosis standpoint. This may not be entirely feasible at all schools, but it is feasible, and the Department thinks essential, in a school which has been placed under a definite system of Tuberculosis control as Coqualeetza.

It is desired that you will review the situation in the light of these observations. The present direction is that the children should not be in the school, and you should take whatever measures are necessary to remove them from it. The matter can be reconsidered on the basis of your further report before the school opens in the fall.

Yours truly,

T. R. MacInnes
Acting Secretary

Sir:

re: File No.153-0-10.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th of July regarding the three Petersen children. I discussed this matter personally with Mr. Sutherland last week, and he was of the opinion that the Provincial Child's Welfare Branch should take care of them, but upon taking it up with them today, they say that as Petersen and the mother were not married, the children are Indian. This is in contradiction to the third paragraph of your letter in which you state that the Department cannot authorize the admission to Residential Schools of children who are not recognized as Indians.

There is no possibility of the Squamish Band accepting these children as members, even if it were advisable to do so.

As you are aware, there are many children of this class in Residential Schools in this Province. The reason these children appear to be subjects for preventorium treatment is that the newly appointed Medical Superintendent, Dr. Atkinson, examined these children, and as they were his first cases, went into a great deal of detail in having blood tests and other examinations made through the Provincial Board of Health. Actually, I understand that when he made the examinations, he considered them far above the average of the children who are placed in Residential Schools, and passed by medical officers.

The father, Carl Petersen, is up North and presumably will not return until after the Fall fishing.

The Superintendent of Neglected Children is absent at the present time, but on her return, the matter will be taken up with her, although her office advised me that she had already had this case under consideration and had decided that she could do nothing as these children were the illegitimate offspring of an Indian woman, and therefore outside her jurisdiction.

Would it not be satisfactory to have the opinion of the School Principal and Medical Officer, as to what disposition should be made of these children?

I have the honour to be,

B/DH.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

SIR:-

With further reference to your letter dated the 28th of May, File No.153-0-10, and my reply dated November 10th, in which I informed you that I had instructed the Reverend R.C. Scott, Principal of Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, to discharge pupil No.542, Moses Leeson.

I have now received the following from Reverend Mr. Scott:-

"With reference to Moses Leeson, I would regret exceedingly if this pupil had to be discharged. He is one of the best we have ever had, and had he been advised earlier would likely have asked for the special courses, upon which he is now engaged. In other words I feel that it would be an injustice to him to have him leave Coqualeetza this year. He is going into his work in Shoe Repairing, Navigation, and Motor Mechanics with fine application. The Department was good enough to allow Allan Young to remain for Shoe Repairing last year, and I am sure it has meant and will mean a good deal to him that he had the opportunity. Moses Leeson is quite as worthy of similar consideration. However, I realize that there must be an end some time to continuing older boys and girls at School, unless for such special reasons, and would greatly appreciate it if the Department would allow me to keep him in school for the remainder of the academic year, even though they feel they could not allow the Per Capita Grant for him. I have several more pupils this year, as we have accommodation for them, even though we are not able to ask for the Grant, and would like to include him in the number. I feel a bit personally responsible to see that he gets a chance for this special training."

Regarding the above, it would appear that plenty

Dear Mr. Daunt:

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter containing list of pupils admitted to Coqualeetza last quarter and also list of pupils discharged at the same time. I am giving attention to those pupils whose application forms and certificates of health as mentioned in your letter are not complete.

Regarding No. 542-Moses Lessson, who is the only remaining pupil of the four suggested for discharge by the Department, I beg to say that I have been waiting until we had something more definite with regard to the Diesel engine which we have asked for before taking up his case with the Department. When I spoke to him of the suggestion from the Department that it might be better for him to discontinue High School work, unless he was preparing for some definite career, for which that work would be a preparation, he said that he thought it was necessary for him to complete High School before undertaking a course in Diesel engineering. I explained to him that if it was a practical course rather than one in advanced theory, we could give him all he needs here at Coqualeetza. He was quite satisfied to leave High School and said that he would think about taking the course here. Consequently I waited for further word before taking up his case. He came back to School late as he was engaged in fall fishing, and is here now. He has been one of our very best pupils, thoroughly dependable and has made satisfactory progress in his work. He is very anxious to take Shoe Repairing, for which he seems to have a natural ability, Motor Mechanics, Navigation and Boat Building, and if the Department would allow him to remain for this year, I am sure he would get a lot of practical benefit from his work. He has been for some time on the Shoe Repairing. Mr. Fordred says he is by far the best workman he has had. I am sure that we can give him enough Navigation and Diesel engine instruction to greatly increase his usefulness in the fishing industry, and therefor increase his chances of better financial returns. He would be able to work at the Shoe Repairing in the winter and as there is no one in his home village doing such work, his spare time in Winter might be profitably employed.

I have been gathering data for an appeal to the Department for assistance in getting equipment for Shoe Repairing and shall be writing shortly about this. I would greatly appreciate it if the Department could see its way clear to allow this pupil to remain for this year. I greatly appreciate the consideration the Department has shown in this case, and in this instance I am very sure that Lessson would amply justify any such privilege that may be granted him. Hoping that you may see your way clear to recommend it to the Department,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 25th over signature of Mr. J.D. Sutherland with regard to the list of pupils sent in by Captain Barry, a copy of which you enclosed with your letter. I beg to say that practically the same list was submitted to you through Mr. Daunt early in May. Not having heard anything I presumed that the Department was willing for these children to remain for this year. I note in your present letter that you are willing that these children, or most of them, should remain until the end of June next. I appreciate the consideration thus given the School. It is very necessary that we maintain our pupilage to the maximum this year in an endeavor to absorb the deficit of last year, owing to diminished pupilage. I can understand the viewpoint of the Department, but would like to say that in many instances these pupils get a good deal more out of their school years from sixteen to eighteen than out of any other two years in the School. I infer in view of the fact that the Department has added equipment for Manual Training, Motor Mechanics, Boat Building and Girls' Handicrafts, that it would be their wish to allow certain students to remain even after they have reached the age of sixteen years. If not, it would seem to take away any meaning from the policy of the past. I am quite in accord with the desires of the Department to make the education of Indian children in Residential Schools as practical as possible, and also to lessen the number of students above sixteen years. At the same time I think a few students who are likely to make use of it, should be allowed High School privileges and that students specially worthy should be allowed extra training along practical lines. These would be cases to be taken up with the Department directly, and I shall try before the end of this School year to bring before you any suggestion I have to make with regard to such pupils for next year. I greatly appreciate your cooperation by issuing

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, with further reference to Moses Leeson - pupil No. 542 of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

In official letter of the 19th instant, your action in instructing the Principal to discharge this boy was approved. However, in view of the contents of Reverend Mr. Scott's letter, the Department now considers that this boy might be allowed to remain at the Coqualeetza Residential School.

It is noted from Mr. Scott's letter that there are more pupils in the school than the number for which grant is allowed. You may, therefore, inform Reverend Mr. Scott that the Department approves of Moses Leeson remaining in the school for a short additional time, in order that he may complete his course but his name should not be included among the regular grant-earning pupils.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,

Ottawa, November 25, 1936.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School on the 12th and 13th instant.

With his report, Inspector Barry forwarded the enclosed list of pupils who are sixteen years of age and over. You are, no doubt, aware of the requirements of the Indian Act; viz., that pupils should not be retained in a residential school after they reach the age of sixteen unless our permission has been obtained. Our files do not indicate that such permission has been requested except in a very few cases.

Mr. Barry is of the opinion, in which the Department concurs, that it should be possible to obtain younger children and, in this regard, I may say that we are prepared to cooperate with you by issuing definite instructions to the Indian Agents concerned to assist you in recruiting for your school.

It is our desire that the pupils whose names are shown on the enclosed list should be discharged from the Coqualeetza School within a reasonable time and, certainly, all of these should be discharged not later than the end of June, 1937. The Department does not wish the pupilage at the Coqualeetza School to be suddenly reduced below the number for which grant is provided but, in writing this letter, we simply wish to point out to you our views in the matter and I feel you will agree that the matter can be handled within the next six or seven months in a manner that will meet with our approval and, at the same time, will not effect the finances of the Coqualeetza Residential School.

On the suggestion of Inspector Barry, I enclose copy of circular letter with reference to fire drill.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. R. C. Scott,
Principal,
Coqualeetza Indian Res. School,
Sardis, B. C.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 26th, File 153-0-10, with regard to Max and Jean Elliott, pupils at Coqualeetza School. I appreciate very much the fact that these children are being allowed to stay until the end of June. At the same time I wish it were possible for their cases to be reconsidered. They are certainly Indian children for all intents and purposes, living the Indian mode of life in a village where there is no Day School. Their parents are Indians. Even though the father is not recognized as an Indian he is living all the time on an Indian Reserve.

So far as our pupilage is concerned, if the Department insists on the graduation of all our sixteen year old pupils, it means almost a twenty percent exodus of our present enrolment. When you add to these the number who will remain out for the usual causes, I can foresee difficulty in filling the School another year. However, I am concerned for the future of these children, and if it were possible, would appreciate very much the reconsideration of their cases. I shall be glad to cooperate with the Department in every way.

Yours sincerely,

R.C. Scott
Principal
Ottawa, February 26, 1937.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to Jean Elliott.

From the information given in your letter it is not considered that this girl is a ward of this Department. You refer to her brother, Max Elliott, who is at present a pupil at the Coqualeetza School. He was sent to Coqualeetza in 1933, but on reviewing our files, it is found that no application was ever submitted for our approval.

Both Max and Jean Elliott may remain at Coqualeetza until the end of June. At the end of that time, however, they should be returned to their parents. It is felt that there should be no great difficulty in securing a sufficient number of recognized Indian children to keep the Coqualeetza School at full strength.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Rev. R. C. Scott,
Principal,
Coqualeetza Indian Res. School,
Sardis, B.C.

The Secretary,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada

Dear Sir:

I beg to bring before you the case of Jean Elliott, daughter of John Elliott of Ladysmith. This man is for all intents and purposes an Indian. He lives the Indian mode of life and claims to have been received as a member of the Chemainus Indian Band, to which his wife belongs. I have taken this matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Graham of Duncan, and he informs me that Elliott was not accepted by the Department as a member of that band.

Last Summer when I was visiting the Indian fishing camp at Cape Mudge, Mrs. Elliott asked to have their little girl received at School. There was nothing in the circumstances or the appearance of this man to indicate that he was anything but an Indian; consequently I received the girl and she has been here at School since September. Seeing that there is no Day School at Ladysmith, and her brother Max Elliott, No. 773 has been at this School for the last three years, I would appreciate it very much if the Department would agree to this girl being received as a grant earning pupil at Coqualeetza. Mr. Graham is quite willing, but simply waits for the permission of the Department as is usual in such cases.

Thanking you in anticipation I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.C. SCOTT
Principal

Dear Sir,

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 28th ultimo, the Department approves the transfer of Emma Adams and Ivy Duncan from the Kitamaat Indian Residential School to the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. Payment of their transportation will be made on receipt from you of a properly certified voucher, in triplicate.

Yours truly,

J. Gillett, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.
Dear Sir,

May I have permission to transfer Emma Adams and Ivy Duncan from Kitimaat Residential School to the Coqualeetza Residential School.

Emma Adams is fourteen years of age and is an orphan. Ivy Duncan is thirteen, and both parents are living, but have not been taking proper care of her during the summer holidays. These two girls will be going to the canneries in the summer if they are not transferred to Coqualeetza. Last year a number of girls from the Residential School at Kitimaat were involved in immoral actions. I would like to send these two girls to Coqualeetza as soon as school closes in June. It will be necessary for the Department to pay the transportation in both cases, if the transfer is approved.

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

P.S. Rev. Scott of Coqualeetza has agreed to take the above mentioned pupils, if the transfer is approved.
Ottawa, May 4th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to the children of Mrs. Frank Jones of the Skidegate Indian Reserve.

In view of your recommendation, the Department approves the admission of Kenneth, Stanley and Laurina Jones to the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School on the understanding that they are physically fit. The usual application forms and certificates of health should be forwarded to the Department.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

B. T. Phillips, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Massett, B. C.
Sir:—

I have just returned from a visit to the Skidegate Indian Reserve, where the subject children going to the Coqualeetza Residential School was discussed at the Council meeting.

One case of neglected children was brought before my notice where there are five young children, this is a case of a broken home, the result being that the children are the sufferers, the mother in question is Mrs Frank Jones, and she wrote the Principal of the above School for admittance for three of her children, the Council asked me recommend to the Department the admittance of these Children (Kenneth 9 Years Stanley 7 years and Laurina 6 years) as soon as possible.

I investigated the above case the following day, and found conditions for the children very bad, the woman stating that Mr Jones sends very little to support them, so in view of the circumstances, I strongly recommend that the above children be sent to the Coqualeetza Residential School as soon as possible.

The Principal of the above School is willing to accept these children right away owing to the circumstances that exist at this home,

Your obedient servant,

B.T. Phillips,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
