I have really had good fortune thus far with problem cases and have had no trouble in a single instance. I have a boy in School now from Kitimaat who just escaped being sent up to Prince Rupert for trial on a case similar to this. We have the girls here too, who were involved at Kitimaat, and were sent in by Mr. Gillett the Agent; so that our experience has been favourable to help out in such cases. However, this lad is along in years a bit and he is also over sixteen. From Mr. Boyes' letter it would appear that the Department is desirous of sending this lad to a Residential School. We are graduating both our Shoe Making lads this year, so that this boy might fit in alright. I would consider taking him on the understanding set forth in the last paragraph of Mr. Boyes' letter of May 17th. If you think the Department would be agreeable I shall be glad of your advice in the matter. Please return the letters when you reply.

With all good wishes and thanking you I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.C. Scott

Dear Sir:

I have received a letter from Mr. S. Mallinson, Acting Indian Agent at Hazelton, in which he asks me to inquire as to the possibility of your school accepting a boy from here.

This lad, George Williams, has been here for over a year and it seems a shame to keep him longer. He has never given a bit of trouble, has become a real worker in the shoe shop and should be sent home. Unfortunately there appears to be no home and the department is forced to send him to one or other of its Indian schools. Apparently Alert Bay is crowded, hence the suggestion that I get in touch with you.

If you have room for George I shall be pleased to notify Mr. Mallinson to that effect and to secure his transfer to you.

Very sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I was pleased to receive your letter and to learn that you might have a place for George.

The boy was seventeen on January 12 of this year. He was sent in on a charge of Carnal Knowledge, having to do with a fifteen year old Indian girl on the Kitwanga Reserve. He arrived here May 2nd, 1936.

Since the day of his arrival he has never given us a minute's trouble. He works well, plays hard and tends strictly to his own affairs. Naturally a quiet fellow he is learning to smile and even laugh on occasion and if he could see a place for himself when he leaves here I think he would develop even more rapidly.

In the event of your deciding to try him I want you to know that we would be prepared to take him back at a moment's notice should his conduct become unsatisfactory to you.

Thanking you for your interest in the lad, I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

I beg to say that there are six girls on the above list, who were not mentioned in the Department letter above referred to, but I have included their names for the reasons set opposite. There are forty-six names altogether on the above list, as compared with the forty-two on the list submitted by the Department.
I have not included one name in the Girls' list which was mentioned, namely, Marjorie Wilson. I am very anxious to have this girl remain at School for another year. Her father and mother are separated, and she is not developed enough to stand up under the circumstances which are certain to confront her. She is good at cooking, sewing and Home Nursing and is very anxious to return for a year's work in these departments. She got 75% in her Department work, and I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would allow her to remain in school next year.

The same is true with regard to Helen McMillan and Mildred Davis. I have included their names in the list, but both these girls warrant another year in Handicrafts, and have asked to be allowed to remain. I can heartily recommend this to the Department.

Regarding the Boys' list:

I have taken the liberty to leave the name of Elmer Pollard off the above list, although it is on that submitted by the Department, but I have included names which were not suggested by the Department.

Pollard is perhaps our best pupil. He is much interested in Navigation and Mechanics to get his papers so that he can be put in charge of Seine Boats or large fish boats. He has secured a place on the Seine Boat "Otter Bay" at Alert Bay for the summer and is very anxious to be allowed to return to Coqualeetza for one more year in which to take more Navigation and Motor Mechanics, as well as his Class Room work. I cannot too highly recommend him for this course, and trust that the Department will allow him the privilege. I feel sure it will mean progress in actual fitting out for his life's work.

The name of Elmer Green, has also been omitted. This lad is bed with Tuberculous glands and is in our Preventorium. I feel that he should be allowed to remain until he has been "X" Rayed again at the end of this School year, when the matter of his discharge can be taken up.

The same is true of Charles Erica Wilson, but he is in better shape than Elmer Green, and so I have included his name for discharge, as I think the "X" Ray report will be favorable.

The above list embraces the names of 45 pupils, which is a big class to discharge in one year. However, I am in favor of graduating Sixteen year old pupils, with exceptions such as I have intimated above. Hence, I shall be glad to have the support of the Department in recruiting pupils to take the places vacated by those listed above, as suggested in their letters of Nov. 25th/36 mentioned at the beginning of this letter.

I shall write more fully on this matter in a few days.

I shall be glad if I might have Certificates, such as the Department issues to pupils graduated from Residential Schools, for the above pupils, in time for our closing exercises next month.

Trusting this is all in order, and assuring you of my desire to cooperate in all that will increase the efficiency of the School, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

I find that I have not mentioned the name of Wilfred Sam. Both his parents are dead; he has no home, and conditions on his Home Reserve are bad. He is slow in Class Room, but started late to go to School. He has done better this year than any yet, and if he had another year to get more experience in farming, and in M.T., I am sure it would be money well spent by the Department. I would greatly appreciate it if this lad were allowed another year.

Sir:—

I have the honour to enclose herewith Application Forms for the Coqualeetza Residential School at Sardis, B.C., also for St Michael's Residential School at Alert Bay, B.C.

I have three Application Forms at Skidegate, being filled in by the Doctor, namely for the following children, George Greene; Pearl Collison; and Arnold Pearson. There are eight Applications altogether from Skidegate, as Capt Barry suggested in his report to send as few as possible to the Residential schools from Skidegate. Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith x x x x x
and beg to report as follows:

A great deal of my time was taken up in connection with applications for admission of pupils into the Coqualeetza and Alert Bay Residential schools.

On account of the poor fishing season many parents were unable to pay for the transportation of their children returning to school, and assistance had to be given in deserving cases.

Rev. R.C. Scott, Principal of the Coqualeetza school arrived in Prince Rupert on the 27th inst. to collect returning pupils. Another of our Graduates, Gordon Robinson, graduated a year ago but took High School work, Grade IO last year, and is being discharged as from June 30th last, says he did not receive a certificate. I would greatly appreciate it if a certificate might be issued to him also.

This lad was one of our best pupils, and did well in his work last year. He might have continued with good hopes of success, but felt that seeing he was going out along with others of his village to fish, trap and hunt, that he might better get at his life work. His record all through his School life was good, and I am hoping that in time he will give effective leadership to his people along lines that will make for their betterment.

Thanking you in anticipation of these courtesies, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

P.S. Gordon Robinson's number was 758.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

Some time ago I wrote the Department with reference to Jean Elliott, daughter of Jack Elliott of Ladysmith, being allowed to continue at Coqualeetza as a grant earning pupil. I wrote a second letter with regard to this girl, but have had no definite reply from the Department. Their first letter advised me that this girl would have to be discharged from Coqualeetza as her father rated as a White man. I would like to make another plea for this child.

Her mother is an Indian of the Ladysmith Band, and the father is a half-breed who lives with his wife permanently at Ladysmith. I understand that his brother's children attend Kuper Island School. He is to all intents and purposes an Indian, and lives the Indian mode of life entirely. There is no School of any sort near their home at Ladysmith, either Indian or White, and it means that this child, who is an Indian to all intents and purposes, will be denied an education. I have room for her and if the Department could see its way clear, I would be glad to have her continue at Coqualeetza.

Trusting that it may be possible to keep this girl, and awaiting the reply of the Department,

I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

R.C. SCOTT

Re Edmund and Baura Elliott: These are the children of Norman Elliott of Ladysmith, and are not registered as Indians. Their Cousin Jean Elliott was of the same standing and the Department granted her permission to attend as a Grant earning pupil. She is in poor health and I have not asked her to return. Other children of the above children are Indians of the Quamichan Band. They live the Indian mode of life, and have no school near them. I did not recruit them, but they came in along with other children from their area. I have room for them at the present and would appreciate it if they were allowed to attend as Grant earning pupils for the year.

No. 882 Is an ex-pupil of Alberni Residential School. The father and mother are separated, and the mother has looked after him from his childhood. She lives in Vancouver, on Powell Street. Ottawa, November 15, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Port Essington Indian Day School on October 29, 1937, Inspector Barry recommends that Silas and Roy Innes be sent to the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. He states that the father is dead and that mother is not giving proper care to the children and, as a result, their home life is hopeless.

In view of the above information, it is considered that it would be in the best interests of these children to place them in the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. You should have them examined by a medical officer and if he pronounces them physically fit, you may arrange for sending them to Coqualeetza at the earliest possible date. Payment of their expenses will be made on receipt from you of a properly certified account, in triplicate.

You should, of course, forward application forms and certificates of health for the Department's file.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA
Reverend Sir:

Indian Commissioner MacKay has brought to our attention the case of two sons of Robert Kelly of the Sumas Band. These boys are aged four and five, respectively, and have an older brother at present in the Coqualeetza Residential School.

Mrs. Kelly died on November 8, 1936, and there are no relatives who can look after these children.

If at all possible, the Department would like to place them in the Coqualeetza Residential School, even though they are under the regular age for admission. If you are willing to accept them, please advise Indian Commissioner MacKay at once.

THE VOCATIONAL TRAINING - GIRLS

The instruction the girls receive in Cooking is a very practical one; for many pounds of potatoes, vegetables, meats, fish, fruits, cakes, puddings and pies are prepared, cooked and served.

Four girls in the morning and four girls in the afternoon, with a change of time table once a month, makes it possible for a number of girls to receive this training, within the school year.

In Laundrying the girls are instructed in sorting, washing and ironing. Between two and three thousand garments pass through the hands of the seven or eight girls on duty, during the week.

The Manufacturing Department is becoming a place of interest, for, at least twenty distinctly different types of articles are made there during a school term. A girl's training culminates at graduation, for she is then supplied with new materials to make a complete set of clothes, including woolen material for a suit.

During the last year, the opening of a very small Indian Handicraft and Home Craft branch, was made possible by a $100.00 grant from the Indian Department at Ottawa. This work is under the direction of Miss Aust, Columbian College, and includes carding, spinning, dyeing, knitting and weaving of yarns into Cowichan sweaters, weaving and hooking of them into rugs, using symbolic native designs. They have also used commercial wools for knitting and for weaving on simple and more complicated looms. The result has been some well knit sweaters and berets, and artistically woven radio mats, purses belts and bandings. Into these latter articles they have woven canoe, whale, thunder birds, arrow heads, basket and totem designs.

Since last November the girls have been keenly interested and greatly encouraged through the kindly interest of Mrs. Scott, who has made it possible for them to have extra tuition in cooking twice a week, two to to the Principal's Residence and receive careful direction along this line. This is an expansion very much needed.
The girls of our Residential Schools need encouragement in house cooking, laundering, etc., necessary in family life; not only encouragement, but made to realize that it is not just daily routine, but that it all has a worthy Scientific and Economic side, very much needed in home life, and especially the home life of their villages.

A Home Economic plant or building is needed and a qualified Instructor. This would make it possible for the girls to have a minimum of five periods a week for three years, along the social science of housekeeping and home-making, and graduate from the school with a diploma.

Miss E. MacKay - Lady Superintendent.
Capt. R. C. Scott - Principal

January 30, 1935.
Vocational Training: Attached to this report are very full statements with regard to the Vocational Training at the school. Statements with regard to the Girls' Work, Manual Training, Boat Building, and Navigation were prepared for me at the school. Owing to the prevailing blizzard conditions and sub zero temperature while I was at the school, it was quite impossible to see as much of this work as I should have desired. It is possible that I shall have an opportunity of inspecting the Boat Building and Manual Training later in the year, if I visit the school to carry out Tests preparatory to the children writing the Provincial Entrance Examinations at the end of June.

The Navigation Class is a new addition to the activities of the school. The instruction given by the Principal ought to be of the very greatest help to the boys when they graduate and are engaged in the various types of boat work along our coasts.

It will be noted that the boat being built here is a 28 foot gill net or trolling hull. I am very glad to learn that the boys are doing the actual work. Little benefit is gained by the boys when the instructor does most of the work and the boys just watch or help with the rough work only.

The Vocational Training of the girls is receiving increased attention. I am in favour of the giving of instruction in the handling of the small boat; but I could not recommend any extra grant at present for this, as there are so many things badly needed in the school as mentioned in other parts of this report. I believe that it would be perfectly possible to have a few of the girls at a time attend to the cooking Etc. in the Principal's Residence, as is now being done, and that possibly this could be increased a little to cover the preparation of Staff meals Etc. as apart from the general work of the school. This or something very like it is being done, and I am of the opinion that this training must suffice for the present. The work in Weaving, Etc is proving a success.

Fire Protection: Fire drills are held regularly. It was of course quite impossible to hold such a drill during my visit to the school. The temperature was about six degrees below zero and there was a snow blizzard most of the time. Under these conditions to have attempted a Fire Drill would have been to expose the children to grave danger.

Dormitories: The general condition of the dormitories is quite satisfactory, as far as neatness, state of beds, floors, Etc. The dormitories located towards the front of the school were far too cold, even with the steam full on. The wind and snow make their way around the window frames. It is very necessary that something be done to remedy this state of things during the 1935 vacation period. It would be hard to exaggerate the adverse conditions under which the school was being carried on at the time of my inspection. It was found quite impossible to hold a conference with the Principal in his own office even with the steam heat full on and an extra electric heater working. The wind was blowing right into the room and we had to retire to the office of the Lady Superintendent at the back of the building. The Dormitories are taking every possible risk of losing a number of children through illness resulting from exposure to adverse health conditions during the winter at this school under present conditions. The failure of the heating plant is reported on again under the heading of Boiler Room.
Expense for equipment for these classes, the Department agreed, should be taken out of the grant of $600.00 for Boat Building Supplies.

A Compass, Parallel Rulers, Dividers, a Set of Charts and 18 copies of Rules of the Road have been secured at a cost of under $30.00.

Fifty-eight boys have been enrolled and two classes a week are held, one for the High School Students, and one for the Intermediates and Seniors. The course embraces a working knowledge of the Compass, laying of Courses, applying Deviation and Variation, familiarity with Signals, Buoys, Chart Reading and the Rule of the Road at Sea.

The boys seem greatly interested and the aim of the course is to help them to handle their own boats intelligently and to give them the rudiments of Navigation and Seamanship, which would make possible a start towards responsible positions upon boats for Fishing or S.S. Companies.

The assistance of the Department in providing equipment is much appreciated.

Capt. R. C. Scott,
Principal
COQUALNETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

- BOAT BUILDING -

Report:
18th January, 1935.

Through the kindness of the Department in granting $600.00 for materials, we have been able to begin a course in Boat Building this month (January, 1935).

The Instructor is Mr. R. Huddleston, formerly of the Sea Craft Boat Works, New Westminster, B.C. Mr. Huddleston is thoroughly trained and seems to have the knack of getting the boys to do the actual work under his supervision.

The Course will include building a 28' Fishing Boat, suitable either for gill netting or commercial trolling, and later on, two row-boats. Twelve boys are engaged, six in the morning and six in the afternoon, and each shift gives them three hours of continuous work. The work is laid down from a plan drawn by Mr. A. Halliday of Vancouver, a Marine Architect of long standing, and each class is instructed in what work may have been done by the other group, before going on with their own shift. This is a practical effort to make possible enlarged usefulness, with profit to the boys concerned and we feel that the Department will be well repaid for the initial outlay.

The salary of the Instructor, is, for the time being, paid by the school, out of Per Capita Funds, but it is hoped that, providing the work done is worth while, the Department may see its way clear to relieve the school of this item. Future work will depend upon our being able to sell the boats produced, so as to buy materials for further boats. It is not, of course, proposed to go into such production on a larger scale than may be necessary to give the boys adequate instruction.

Mr. R. Huddleston - Instructor
Capt. R. C. Scott - Principal
REPORT OF MANUAL TRAINING DEPARTMENT

The Manual Training course is divided into four divisions. The first, or elementary division gives a rudimentary knowledge of the bench tools and their use and care, demonstrated through a series of twelve exercises or models, such as small brackets, pot stands, etc. This embraces such operations as planing, sawing, chiseling and boring. Coupled with this, is the theoretical part, with the drawing of the models, printing and notes on the tool operations and assembly.

The secondary division is a continuation of the first, only following a more detailed course of models, with additional theory and drawing practice. The models range from a simple bench hook to small stools, trays, lamps, etc. Construction of these models employs a variety of joints such as butt, dado, mitre and mortise and tenon. Also tool operations as rabbeting and grooving. Finishing of models both painting and staining are introduced.

The third division branches into rural and farm projects, including milking stools, single trees, double trees, harness hooks, ladders, saw horses, etc.

The fourth division is a study in elementary cabinet making and involves table construction, frame construction, cabinet construction, door construction and drawer construction. The use, care and safety of machine operated tools are brought into this division. Elementary spindle turning on the lathe, is also a part of this division. The theoretical section deals with furniture designs and elementary drafting practices are introduced.

Mr. George Williams - Instructor.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Manual Training, Coqualeetza School

I have read the extracts from Inspector Barry's report, enclosed in your communication of December 11th, with a good deal of interest, and my first reaction is one of surprise that Mr. Barry should have been inspecting this school for five years without having discovered before what he is reporting at the present time. There is absolutely nothing new in the situation except for the fact that very decided improvements have been made since Captain Scott became Principal.

None of us is satisfied that the handicraft being taught either to the boys or to the girls at Coqualeetza is ideal, and yet it is only fair to the school to say that of all the residential schools belonging to our own or any other Church, visited by our Commission in May, Coqualeetza was the only one that had a manual training department worthy of the name.

I do not think it is necessary that I should attempt to deal with the details of these criticisms, but I would like to make one or two observations.

The Manual Training Instructor at Coqualeetza is a very highly qualified man and is working for less than half the salary that he could get teaching his own specialty in a vocational or technical school. He is genuinely interested in Indian design, art and crafts, and is probably, outside of Dr. Haley, the best authority in British Columbia to-day on that line. The designs and other work on the girls' side which Captain Barry commends - and quite rightly so - owe a very great deal to this man's investigations and suggestions. Like all specialists, he does tend too much to the manufacture of exhibition pieces, and does not give sufficient attention to the manufacture of the simple articles of home furniture which the boys should normally use after they graduate. It should be said, however, that very considerable improvement in that respect has taken place during the last year and that in the building and outfitting of the Preventorium the Department undoubtedly saved about $1,000 through the fact that the senior boys did most of the work under the direction of this teacher.

The teaching on the girls' side is just as weak from the same standpoint and is also in process of evolution. Their work in the making of Cowichan sweaters, kimonos, and other such articles, is indisputably excellent, but the amount of actual experience
they get in making the clothes that they will need for themselves and their children after they graduate, is less than in some schools with a much less elaborate programme.

I do not attach much importance to Mr. Barry's criticism of the manufacture of totem poles by the hundreds. There is plenty of excellent hand carving being done on totem poles at Coqualeetza. The lathe and saw being used in the manufacture of the cheaper ones are not so expensive but that any Indian boy could easily buy them for himself after a good fishing season, and there does not seem to me to be any valid reason why the Japanese should preempt the market for totem pole place cards and that type of thing, while the graduates of our residential schools go idle for half the year. So far as it's being a commercial venture is concerned, I think it can easily be demonstrated that it has never been profitable to the school. I place a fairly high value on it, however, as indicating to these Indian boys the type of thing they can do in their own homes in British Columbia between fishing seasons that will increase their income.

Personally, I regard the instruction which is being given in boat building as satisfactory. I think the electrical and radio course is excellent. The boys are getting a fine training in navigation. I do not know the reason why the department of motor mechanics is not now under the direction of the teacher who has been heading it up for the last two or three years. I sat through one of his classes on the occasion of my last visit to Coqualeetza and considered that as a mechanic and as a teacher he was far above the average. He was the owner of a fine garage and repair station in the neighboring town of Chilliwack and it may be that his own business has increased to the point where he finds it impossible to give any time to the school. I will write to Captain Scott and find out. I do know that the boys in the class which graduated in motor engine work last year were all competent to take down, repair, and put together two or three different types of boat engines.

In the words of the Instructor "A separate branch is the Indian Handicraft Section. We are attempting to give a course on Indian designs, carving, totem poles etc., using, as near as possible, the native coloring. Totem poles are made from photos, cuts, or drawings of authentic poles. The decoration of Manual Training projects is dealt with here, and carved or painted Indian designs are applied wherever suitable. We are treating this as a Commercial subject and are trying to develop a market for Indian Crafts. I would like to suggest that the Department recognize this branch and endorse it in the School Curriculum".

With regard to the work outlined in the words of the Instructor above, I wish to say that I consider the making of totem poles as it is done at Coqualeetza a complete waste of time. The poles are first cut out roughly by hand saw and then finished by the boys. Such poles are, the Instructor tells me, being ordered by the hundred as a commercial or quasi-commercial venture. The poles have a label attached when finished saying that they are Indian craftsmanship etc. To me the poles that I was shown appear very poor indeed. They are not much better than the rubbish sent to B.C. from Japan, and in fact the Instructor admits that the poles made at Coqualeetza have to compete with the article as made in Japan. From a Manual Training point of view the construction of totem poles, largely by machinery, would not appear to have any value whatever. Efforts are being made at Alert Bay Indian Residential School to teach the Indian boys to carve out the totem poles by hand, the Instructor being a well known carver of such poles, Charlie James. This activity at Coqualeetza appears to me a very minor activity started just because St. Michael's Alert Bay was making some splendid poles.

I would ask the Department to have the making of totem poles in Indian Residential Schools BY MACHINERY or PARTLY BY MACHINERY stopped as soon as possible. I expressed to the Instructor my own personal dislike of such machine made totem poles, and also informed him that there was a wide spread feeling in the Province that the making of totem poles partly by machinery at Coqualeetza was a very great mistake.

It will of course be understood that I am anxious that genuine native craft work be encouraged in the schools. I have reported on this in other years. The work now being done by the girls, as mentioned on the last page under the girls' part of this report on Vocational Training, deserves every encouragement.

The High School course in Manual Training is a continuation of the Fourth Division and is along more technical lines. Let the work and operations are here taught to all pupils. Furniture construction is the foundation of the course. The Vancouver Technical School Course is being followed to some extent at least.

I may say that I am not very well satisfied with the work now being done in the Manual Training Class here. The best thing I saw was the construction of a T.B. Preventorium. I consider that there are a number of articles needed in the classrooms which should be constructed by the M.T. Class before such foolish things as totem poles are made. The making of farm equipment
equipment such as that described in Division Three is an activity of use to the Indians.

It is hoped to introduce an Electrical and Radio Course along the basic lines laid down by the Vancouver Technical School. Students of such course will construct actual circuits from a simple bell circuit to the more complex wiring for houses, automobile and marine wiring and ignition, dry cells, storage batteries, generators, and radio systems will be studied. If the necessary funds are available actual radio projects will be taught, from the simple circuits used in crystal sets to more advanced circuits. This will enable students to service and repair existing sets, or to construct sets of commercial value.

The above three paragraphs are taken from the notes supplied to me at Coqualeetza. I may say that I am in favour of instruction being given to the older boys in the actual working and repair of engines likely to be used by them in fishing boats. I consider however that the instructor should be an outside mechanic, which would not appear to be the present intention at the school. When I reported on this work some two years ago an outside mechanic was employed. I certainly do not think that expensive equipment should be supplied by the Department. No doubt the Indian Agent will advise if necessary when the school makes requests for a grant for this work.

In general I would like to see the Manual Training and any added courses in Motor Engineering or Electricity take a very much more practical turn than is at present the case in the school. Highly finished cabinet work, telegraph poles made partly by machinery, and other work depending on machinery unlikely to be available in an Indian village would appear to me a waste of time. The actual building of a small fishing boat of from 24 feet to 26 feet is a worth while project, as such boats are used in the fishing industry. The Indians of the northern parts of the Province are very anxious that their boys should be taught to repair such boats and their engines.

Enclosed please find letter re the re-organization of our Motor Mechanics Department, along with list of tools for same. There are two items which may cause comment, namely the paint and the old engines for blocks. I may say that all the expense for lumber used in re-arranging these rooms, for building work benches, desks and seats cupboards etc has been supplied by the School. It has taken a good deal of paint as we had to paint the walls for about six feet up, all around and then the tables, work benches seats etc took a lot. I have really gotten it, and it is most of it used already, but I felt it was fair to ask the Department for a part of the cost of re-arranging. It is going to make the department a lot more efficient, as well as afford room for a Chemistry "Lab.", lecture room for Farm work etc etc. The old engines we have at present are useless for any practical purpose and the old car engines we propose to secure will afford the boys a fine chance to actually work with gas engines. The marine motor differs only in weight, and stroke etc etc, the principle is the same for both. I trust that the Department will see its way clear to give us this help, particularly as we are saving around $450.00 for salary of an instructor, as I mentioned before.

Although I have no idea that such a thing might occur, yet it is only fair to say, that if Mr Williams were to leave us, we might not be able to get a Manual Training Instructor who could do all the work he is doing, and it might be necessary to ask again for an outside instructor. However, we shall not borrow trouble, for I feel sure that if we had to distribute motor mechanics in a different fashion, I would be able to fall back on Mr Huddleston who is really a genius at working with machinery - in a practical way.

I am really away up the East Coast of the Queen Charlottes en route to Skidegate and Masset. I felt this was the psychological time to see these people. I shall not have the time later on, and they will soon be scattering to their trap line etc. I am sure the trip will work out well for the School. I am not yet prepared to drop this big Northern area for recruiting. It may come to that later, but for the present I feel it would not be right or advantageous either to the Indians or to the School.

With kind regards, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir:

I am submitting herewith examination papers written at examinations set for our Motor Mechanic students last month. They will afford an idea of the instruction which is now being given in this department of Coqualeetza. Even though they are three of the best papers, may say that the average mark obtained was just over the minimum for Second Class Honors. I am anxious to give as practical a training as possible to the pupils of this School, and thought that you would be interested in seeing what is being attempted.

The practical work is a large part of the training. These boys have taken down engines, cleaned and fitted the heads and gaskets, ground valves, polished and fitted bearings etc., and done such work as would be done by them in repairing or refitting their engines, in connection with their work at home as fishermen.

I am anxious to go one step further, and have a small diesel engine in our department for instruction and demonstration. Several of our older boys are anxious to get training in this type of engine, and if we had one here, we could give a real practical training which would, I fancy, be better for such students than to send them to a Technical School, unless, of course, in the case of students extraordinary, who might be able to take a longer and more technical course. For the average boy, however, it is the practical training that counts. I have run and cared for a 30 H.P. 2 cylinder, full Heisel engine for nearly ten years. I have taken down cylinder heads, ground and fitted valves and sleeves, timed valves and carried on all the work of an engineer on such a machine and feel that I could give adequate oversight, while Mr. Williams, our present instructor could give all the theory. I shall write you through Mr. Indian agent Hunt more fully on this matter.

I would be glad if you would return the enclosed papers and note books as they ought to be retained by the boys concerned.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Fine Boat Job
By Boys At Coqualeetza

Thirty-five Foot Power Boat of Special Design For Local Waters

A very fine job of boat building has just been completed by a dozen boys of Coqualeetza Industrial School, Sardis, under the supervision of Mr. R. Huddleston, formerly of the Seagull Boat Works at New Westminster. The boys are between the ages of 14 and 17, and the work has been done in four months under normal instruction and conditions.

The boat might be termed a combination runabout and light tow boat, and is 35 feet long with an eight by six beam, and is said to be the largest boat yet constructed in these parts. It will be equipped with a 100-h.p. motor and will have a speed of 16 miles per hour. There is a gas tank capacity of 200 gallons. It has nice lines and is light draught, being designed for lake boat use. Planking is of B.C. red cedar, the gunwales of oak ribs of oak, while half a ton of Australian gum tree wood has been used.

Construction throughout is standard and the boat is a sturdy, business-like craft. Delivery was made last week by Harold Cartmell for use on the Fraser river and Harrison lake.

The training given the boys is of practical importance, as all of them come from families engaged in boat-building and fishing at the head and lower ends of Vancouver Island. The workmen's job shop is located in the Progress saw outside the boat-building shop Saturday is a credit to the boys and their instructor. A smart looking rowboat nears its hours of completion, and will probably be used at the school's summer camp on the River this season. Training in this department is such that one boat of the type referred to may two rowboats be completed each year for commercial undertakings but for instruction purposes only.

The boys at Coqualeetza are not only trained in building sea and water-going craft but also in power plants. Under George Williams, the boys are taught the principles of gas engine construction and repairs. In this way they are on leaving school proficient in building and repairing boats, taking down and raising chimneys and other mechanics associated with the work in home surroundings. Attached to the manual training department has separate a machine shop from the classroom, where navigation and chemistry in addition to motor mechanics are taught.

The Progress was afforded a peep at the arts and craft department by Captain Scott, where the wool is carded, spun into yarn dyed in colors produced from native materials, the yarn being woven into the Cowichan sweaters, and other articles by the girls of the school.

With nearly two hundred pupils are assembled, proper means to health are important. In this matter Captain Scott reports that results through the medium of the Preventorium established some time ago have been very gratifying.

Dear Sir,

PP/O'M.
SIR:

I have received a request from the Reverend R.C. Scott, for a revival of the Grant of $100.00, made by the Department in 1933, (Your File No. 153-0-11, to Doctor Raley, Dec. 24th, 1933.), as a refund of the expenses for an Instructor of Indian Handicrafts, at Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

Mr. Scott is having Miss Aust up every week-end from New Westminster, to do this work. She is an excellent teacher, knows her work, and gets along well with the girls.

She teaches them to card, spin, and to dye wool, using nearly altogether native dyes, and finally, the knitting of this heavy yarn into "Cowichan Sweaters". In addition, she does all sorts of other work, such as the application of Indian designs to blankets, bath robes, pillows, chintz, etc., which, among the North, who may not be so interested in knitting "Cowichan Sweaters", are taught the knitting of sweaters, mitts, socks, etc., using the ordinary manufactured wool, which they would have to rely upon in their northern homes.

This instruction is of as much value to the girls, in their future lives, as Manual Training and Motor Mechanics are to the boys, and if it is at all possible, I would most strongly recommend that the recognition and assistance asked for, be extended to this valuable form of training.

Your obedient servant,

A.O'N. Daunt,

Dear Mr Daunt:

I am enclosing herewith a list of tools which we would like if the Department would be good enough to give us, for our Motor Mechanics classes. I would like to point out that we would have had to ask for these tools in any case, even had we carried on as we did last year, but with the re-organization which we have effected, we have saved the Department an expenditure of $45.00 per month, which, extended for the ten months of the School year, totals the sum of $450.00. Looked at from this angle, the expenditure for tools is fairly a moderate one. As I have just stated, even had we carried on as last year, with an outside instructor, we would have had to ask for these tools so that the boys might have had the opportunity of actually doing work themselves.

I might say that I found the former arrangement not just satisfactory. While Mr Edwards is one of the best mechanics in British Columbia, still he is a very busy man in his own Garage, and I found that the senior boys were loth to join up with his classes and the younger ones were withdrawing, because they said they did not get anything new; they had covered the work in the first year or so. There was no definite curriculum, and again, much of the work Mr Edwards did himself, while the boys looked on. Of course, he was handicapped for the want of tools, and a different arrangement would have had to be made in this connection even had he stayed.

Under the new plan, the instruction will be given by Mr Williams our Manual Training Instructor, and I feel sure he can do the work. He is practical, and at the same time has had the training in teaching. Added to that he has worked out a curriculum based on that of the Vancouver Technical School. Pulla will follow that course, and will write examinations to those of the Vancouver Technical School, and will be able to get credit for such work if they wish to continue. This is a gain I think. It will give the exceptional student a chance to go on if he wishes, and it will give the entire class the benefit of following a definite line of instruction. Every boy will take machine drawing and theory, and will actually do repair work, such as making and fitting gas-kets, valve grinding, bearing fitting etc., in a simple series of exercises covering both the two and the four stroke engines.

A sample page of the course is enclosed, the ten units covering approximately ten weeks.

As I have said, tools are necessary if the instruction is to be practical and of the best value, hence our request as enclosed. We propose too, to use our assistant manual training instructor, who is a thoroughgoing boat builder, to instruct the boys in actual installation of engines in boats. An engine bed will be set up, and an actual installation made in the work room. We also plan to adapt truck engines from automobiles for use in fishing boats. This is actually being done by fishermen up the coast and is thoroughly practical and makes it possible for boys who might not have an outfit for years, to acquire one. Engine costs are prohibitive for the average boy. A truck engine can be secured for a "song", and can be adapted for boat use. This will be another distinct gain, we feel.

In asking for automobile engines, I might point out that this is done in all automotive instruction schools. The system is the same as that of the marine engine, and it is feasible to get old

Cars engines at the ridiculously low figure suggested, which will be quite good as "blocks" for instruction purposes, and it may be we shall be able to get engines which we may be able to adapt for use by some of these boys. Some day, we shall build and equip a boat with such an engine, as one of our boat building projects. In keeping with this programme, I have charged the quarters of the boat building class to one of the other buildings not at present in use, which will give more room. It also gives the room formerly used as a boat shop, to be used as a "school room" for Motor Mechanics. The boys under Mr. Williams have done all the work. Formerly only one room was used, and benches were carried in and out each time the class was called. They were old and unsightly, and the temporary character they given to the class, did not help to make the boys feel they were actually at school.

New tables have been made, and new benches built, the walls of the room and the equipment just mentioned have been painted, and as a result we have a class room for Motor Mechanics where the boys can sit down comfortably and do their theory and get instruction along theoretical lines. The room formerly used for both, will now be used only for practical bench work.

I may say in closing, that this class room will also be used for a "Lab" for the chemistry work in our Grades Nine and Ten, and will fill a much needed part of our equipment as we are to continue to do High School work. This undertaking by CCQualeetza, by the way has also saved the Department a big item for fees. Last year fees amounted to just over $600.00. However, it will be only about one fifth of that amount. The room will also be used for my Navigation classes. I had formerly to use the Assembly Hall, without tables or black board. Cupboards are provided in this new room, for each of these classes.

The lumber used in this new set-up has been secured out of School funds, we are asking only for the paint. I trust that the Department may see its way clear to grant us the request for tools, and for old engines for engine blocks. If our classes are to be practical we must have these "blocks". The ones now in the room are practically worthless, and cost much more than the ones we now propose to secure.

In deep appreciation of the aid the Department has given to the School and assuring you that we desire to be as helpful as possible in this mutual task on behalf of the Indian people, I am,

Yours sincerely,

To Remove and replace a cylinder head.

JOB SHEET 1.

Information: The cylinder head is bolted to the top of the block and acts as a cover for the cylinders.

Tools: Kit—speed wrench—sockets—putty knife.

Method:
(1) Drain water from cooling system.
(2) Remove high tension wires and plugs; break water joints on cylinder head.
(3) Break loose cylinder head bolts and speed off with the speed wrench.
(4) Lift off head.
(5) Clean faces of head and block free of all carbon with putty knife, taking care not to fill bolt holes with carbon.
(6) Put new gasket in place taking care that all holes required are in gasket and that gasket is properly positioned.
(7) Start all bolts before starting to tighten any up.
(8) Spin bolts down snug and then cinch up half a turn at a time, beginning at centre and working outwards in all directions.
(9) Replace plugs, connections and fill radiator with water.
(10) Start engine and allow to run for ten minutes.
(11) Tighten bolts down again after running.

Note: aluminum alloy heads are not retightened after heating.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith several pages descriptive of the work being given in our Motor Mechanics department. I hope it will be of interest, and give you some idea of the extent of the course, both in theory and practice, which we are giving out boys. The accompanying data will give some idea of the course in Motor Mechanics for Part I. The outline of the theory and a copy of the lesson, Unit No.7 together with all drawings for that lesson, are attached. An outline of job and assignment sheets, together with a copy of Job No.1 are also attached.

Our present equipment includes several old car engine blocks which we use for instruction in repair work. We have not a complete engine suitable for overhauling, consequently I would like permission to purchase a Model A Ford engine complete at a cost of about $50. This would give us equipment to cover the complete job and assignment work for Part I. It is essential that a working model be obtained for this class. For instance, it is not enough that the boy merely grinds the valves in an engine. He should also complete all jobs leading up to that, such as removing head wires, valve plate covering, as well as the actual process of valve grinding. After re-assembling, the boy should start up the motor and make all necessary adjustments such as tuning it up, timing, starting and operation. A boy, for instance, might renew a gasket on a non-working motor and not realize that he might have covered some inlet or outlet in the water circulatory system. He might grind valves, but he would have not certain knowledge whether he had made a good job unless it could be tried out on a regular working model. Both of these necessary items in his training would be provided if we had a motor such as that for which I am asking. Again, we have not a motor which has a complete...

General topic: The Engine (continued)

Valve Arrangements

The type of motor cylinder head is determined by the arrangement of the valves. There are usually two valves to a cylinder, one inlet and the other exhaust. The various designs of heads are called by letters, which resemble the shape of the valve heads and the centre line of the cylinders.

Poppet Valves

All valves shown are of the poppet type; that is the valves pop or work up and down, being opened by the camshaft and closed by a spring. The stem acts as the guiding part of the valve while the head prevents the gases leaking.

"L" Head

An "L" head or side valve engine arrangement as shown, the valves are side by side and placed to one side of the cylinder. The stems project downward so that they can be worked off the camshaft with a short push rod or tappet. This is a very popular design because of simple construction and quiet operating.

"T" Head

This has a valve on each side of the cylinder, one the exhaust and the other the inlet. Two camshafts are used, one working the inlet valves, the other the exhaust.

"I" Head

The "I" head or overhead valve engine has the valves arranged directly above the cylinders. The valves are inverted or upside down and are worked by push rods and rockers from the camshaft. The valves are placed in a line parallel to the centre line of the engine; the advantage claimed is better scavenging of the cylinder. Sometimes the valves are worked directly from a camshaft placed on top of the cylinder head in which case the engine is known as an overhead camshaft engine.

"F" Head

A combination of overhead and side valve is used in this type. The inlet valve is overhead, while the exhaust is in the side. The side is operated by a tappet or push rod and the overhead by a push rod and rocker.

Side Valve

A section of a side valve is shown in place in the cylinder block. The valve head fits in a seat, the angle being 45° though 30° seats are occasionally used. The valve head and seat are made gastight by grinding the valve so that it fits closely to the seat. The combustion chamber is completely sealed when the valves are closed. If the gases leak when the valves are closed, the valves require grinding. The valve stems move in the guide,
which is removable and is made of cast iron. The valve port or opening conveys the gas to or from the valve.

**Overhead Valve**

The overhead valve is shown in the section drawing. The cylinder head in this case forms the valve seat, and on removing the head the valves and assembly come away with the head, so that regrinding and cleaning are very conveniently done.

**Side Valve Assembly**

The valve assembly is shown. The camshaft raises the valve, the motion being transmitted to the valve stem through the tappet. The valve is closed by the spring which is of sufficient strength to prevent the gases leaking when closed. The seat is formed in the block, access to the valves being gained by removal of the cylinder head. The spring acts on the valve through the retaining cup which is locked to the valve stem by split taper collars, or rectangular or round pins. The guide clearance on the stem is .003" which is necessary to prevent sticking of valves.

**Tappet**

The tappet and adjustment are casehardened and may be shaped in a variety of ways where it works against the camshaft. The common designs are shown, a disc tappet and a roller tappet.

**Valve Clearance**

Is the space between the end of the valve when closed and the tappet adjustment when the tappet is on the wounded portion of the cam. This adjustment is very important and is made when the engine is hot. The clearance differs with engines from .004"-.006" When adjusting it is good practice to set one cylinder at a time, leave one valve open when of course the other is fully shut and can be adjusted. The engine is then turned until the valve adjusted is open and the other one set.

**Overhead Valve Assembly**

The motion is taken from the non-adjustable tappet by the pushrod to the rocker. The rocker is pivoted above the cylinder head to give a downward motion of the valve when the push rod moves up. The valve retainer shown is of the horseshoe type. The wearing points are hardened and lubricated by oil pumped from the interior of the engine.

**Clearance**

The clearance is checked where the rocker meets the valve stem. It is adjusted by the screw and locknut on the end of the rocker arm. Clearance runs from .006"- .002".
Valve Heads

There are two types of valves, mushroom valve and tulip-head valve. The mushroom head valve has a domed head of cast iron fitted on a stem of steel. The tulip head is concave for lightness and is made in one piece from tungsten, silicon-chromium, cobalt-chromium or other heat resisting steel. A valve made of special steel has a high strength even at bright red temperatures.

Valve Seats

Most of the modern engines have valve seats of hardened steel or hardened bronze for the exhaust valves. These are either pressed or screwed into place in the form of rings, one for each valve. These special seats resist the action of the burning gases better than the seats formed in the metal of the block, thus cutting down the necessity of grinding valves so often. Shrinking the seats into place is the most popular method of fitting. The rings are placed in liquid air which has a temperature of -190°C. This contracts the rings so that they can easily be driven into the recesses; then as the rings heat up to atmospheric temperature the recesses are gripped tightly.
I visited and went over the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. I met Captain Scott this time though I had missed him before. At the time of my visit there were 223 children in the school. (I think this must be 123, but I have 223 in my notebook). I did not see the children in any of the classes as it was Founders' Day and they were all having a holiday.

I also went over the Preventorium which is nearly completed, and which is filling a long felt want.

The Principal mentioned several things required at the school. For instance, they are going in for boot making in the same way as the Mission School has done. This, of course, includes repairs. He states that they require a stitching machine which costs $103.00. Further, in the Manual Training class they are concentrating upon boat building, and instruction in marine engineering and navigation. All of this is useful to the Inuit boys at the school who will have to earn their living by fishing. They badly want an old Deisel engine for instructional purposes. They have an old gasoline one, but a Deisel is required. I should suggest that the Deisel engine out of the Naskeena be given to the school for instructional purpose and a new Deisel put in the Naskeena of the Skeena River Agency. As you know, I am expecting this engine in the Naskeena to give out in time the same as the one in the Duncan Scott, and with the constant repairs I believe it would be a saving to remove this engine before a serious breakdown occurs.

The Principal also informs me that some fencing is required. He showed me the fence which certainly does require renewal and re-erection. This will cost $60.00, and I recommend that this be done.

Further, the roofing of the school is badly in need of repair in various places, and an estimate should be obtained of what is required in this way.

I found everything else at this school clean and tidy and in every way satisfactory. The children looked happy and healthy.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

Reverend Sir:

The following is an extract from the annual report of Mr. P. B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent for the West Coast Agency:

"Due to existing conditions on the Coast making it imperative that Indians seek other than their natural source of livelihood, it is respectfully recommended that manual training and domestic science be conducted on more practical lines. At present the girls are taught fancy sewing and are employed in kitchens, both admirable in their way, but they should be taught how to make fishing nets and the operation of canning machinery, also how to wash without the aid of electric washing machines, and the baking of bread without electric bakeries. They should also be taught simple home nursing, hygiene, and kindred subjects.

"Boys should be taught practical boat building and operation of marine engines. These Indians are natural mechanics and could very easily be taught under a competent instructor. Every year these Indians lose hundreds of dollars owing to shipping furs not properly prepared, and this art could be taught to advantage."

As you have a number of Indians from the Coast in your school I am bringing Mr. Ashbridge's suggestions to your attention. I expect that you will give these your careful consideration as their adoption would result in the pupils receiving the practical training that they require.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of May 2nd in which there are quotations from the report of Mr. P.B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent for the West Coast, with regard to Manual Training, etc., for Indian children.

In reply I beg to say that we are endeavouring to bring Coqualeetza School more and more in line with the wishes of the Department, and I fancy we are having fairly good success at present. We still lack of assistance to the graduates of this School in later life. Some fancy sewing is of course taught the girls, but we are laying more and more stress on making their own clothes. The carding, spinning of wool in preparation for knitting and weaving articles of clothing is taught. They are taught to use native dyes from hemlock bark, alder bark and onion skin, etc. We have what we call a Home Economics Kitchen a separate unit from the main Student Kitchen. Here the girls are taught to plan, prepare and serve a meal similar to one that would be served in the ordinary home. I may say that all our girls use the wash tub. We have no electric washing machines or electric laundries. We also have a Home Nursing class which is under the care of our School Nurse, who is a graduate Registered Nurse. Here the girls are taught Home Nursing, Hygiene, etc. In addition, our Senior girls are detailed to the Preventorium where they learn to take care of the dishes of sick persons. These are washed separately. We use different colored dish pans, different colored dish cloths, and in every way try to impress upon them the need for keeping such dishes separate. The girls also get training in the taking of temperatures and the preparing of meals for the sick, although we do not of course allow them to do any nursing where they would come into close contact with tubercular cases.

Our boys are getting a very fine training in Boat Building. We built two 35 foot boats last year, and we are completing a second one this year, 33 feet in length. I am enclosing a copy of the specifications and materials used for this boat. This is a boat similar to the ones used on the inside waters. Next year, all being well, we may build a 38 footer, which will be of heavier construction suitable for the off-shore fishing in which our Queen Charlotte Island Indians engage. I am thoroughly conversant with both these types of boats. For fifteen years I was on the Coast in inland waters in Mission work; and for four years I was stationed at Queen Charlotte in the Marine Mission Work. I have just returned from a trip to the Islands and other points up the Coast in the endeavour to bring the School into closer touch with the people, to keep
in touch with graduates and in every way help to make the influence of the School more effectual and permanent. While in Skidegate, I saw Vernon and Clifford Jones rebuilding an old hull. Both these boys had been trained in our Boat Building Shop. They secured this 36 foot hull which had been in disuse for a good while, put in a new keel, some new timbers, raised the deck combings, laid on some new planking and recaulked the whole hull. They were also getting a new forefoot on her, and had secured an engine which they were installing without any other assistance than that of their father. The father was greatly delighted, and thanked me for the help we had given these boys. It just means that they will have become independent. It was very encouraging to me, and I would like to thank the Department sincerely for the assistance which they have given us in making this training possible.

Our Manual Training classes are this year being conducted on much more practical lines. It will likely result in a somewhat less spectacular exhibit, but I am quite sure that the boys will have gained greatly in knowledge that will be of practical use. Over a year ago I thought of the making and repairing of Fish Nets, and I had a young Cape Mudge fisherman under promise to come and give the boys training along that line. He was also going to show them how to rig up trolling outfits and give them some idea of how to use such gear at different depths and at different seasons of the year. However, he failed me, but I have it in mind for another year. I have myself conducted Junior and Senior class in Navigation and Seamanship throughout the year. I have several senior boys going out this summer who own Seine boats, and I am quite sure the knowledge they have gained will be of great use. They are taught "The Rule of the Road at Sea", Compass and Chart work, some knowledge of the buoyage system, the laying of courses, and practical suggestions in seamanship are given. The Department of Marine is tightening regulations all the time, and these young men will need not only to have local knowledge in the future, but knowledge such as I have indicated above which will make it safe for them to take their vessels into strange Coast waters. The traffic in such waters is increasing all the time.

I trust that you will see from this that we are endeavouring to cooperate with the Department in every way to give the pupils a training which will best suit them for after school life. I would say that about 75% of the pupils of this School make their living from the sea or from Coast industries. I trust that you will be reassured, and feel that the grants paid by the Department to this School are being expended to the best of our ability to produce results in harmony with the aims of yourself and other officers in charge.

At the same time, if there should be any criticism of the size of boats built at Coqualeetza, I trust that my twenty years experience and my practical knowledge of what is needed, together with the fact that we have a thoroughly capable Boat Builder in charge, will be given due consideration. When we first began, there was a disposition on Inspector Barry's part to want us to build a 24 or 25 foot boat for fishing purposes. A boat this size would be simply worse than useless in the areas from which most of our pupils come. It might do on the Fraser River, but in Northern waters it would be hopeless. I should have said that we build from two to four Row Boats each year, using both the Carvel and Clinker built types. The entire programme of Boat Building however, is kept upon an instruction basis and not a production one.
MR. R.A. Hoey.

May 14, 1938

I refused an order for twelve Row Boats last Fall after one gentleman had seen the Row Boat we exhibited at the Vancouver Exhibition.

Again let me say how greatly & appreciate the assistance of the Department in the entire programme. It is very gratifying to me, and I shall always be glad to receive suggestions that will be helpful and make for progress. The letter of Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge is quite timely.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SARDIS, B.C.

August 24th, 1938.

Dear Mr Hoey:

For some time now, I have been thinking of writing you with regard to some assistance to one of our Graduates, Joseph Edgar of Clo'oose, on the West Coast of Vancouver Island. This lad was a member of our last Building Class for the last more than two years. Last Fall, Mr Huddleston, our Boat Builder, thought it would be a good thing for each of his six boys to make a Model of a fishing boat; then I was to act as judge, and the best Model would be used as a pattern for a boat.

Each boy made a Model, and then I examined each one. There was not very much difference between most of them, but the one made by Joseph I chose because the lines were a bit better than those of any of the others. Of course I did not know who had made it. Mr Huddleston concurred in my judgement, but suggested one or two minor changes that would be an improvement.

Well, that was the boat which you saw when you made your visit last June.

I have had a letter from Joseph and one from his father, and they are both very anxious to have this boat. The father says, "in order to give my two boys a chance to make a few dollars", I know they need a new boat, and the fishing grounds they frequent—right out on the open pacific—demand the best. I have been holding the boat at Four Hundred Dollars, as this would only give us the cost of materials, and allow a balance for replacement of tools and equipment etc. The Department gave us the money to get materials for our first boat, and then we sell, and re-imburse the School, and get more materials. This we must do in this case.

Joseph offers Two Hundred Dollars down, and the balance next year. It is a big order for him, and I have wondered if it would not be possible for the Department to make him a grant of One Hundred Dollars toward this boat. It is not more expensive than they do for Graduates in other parts, and it would certainly be a great inspiration to many others, for I would like to see other boys build their own boats. As I have said, this lad designed this boat, and worked on it right from start to finish, and I know it would do a lot to create a right sort of pride—that of craftsmanship—if it were made possible for him to secure it for his very own.

I trust that you will give this request your earnest consideration, and if at all possible make a grant to this lad which will enable him to get this boat. I am quite sure that four hundred dollars is a big order for him. One the other hand we can easily sell the boat for Four Hundred as it is a fine seaworthy craft, but the more I think of it, the more I feel that a Hundred dollars invested in this lad would bring dividends in character and accomplishment in the years to come.

Thanking you for your interest and help at all times, I am,

Yours sincerely,

RCS/

September 3, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo with reference to the boat that was built by the boat building class of the Coqualeetza Residential School last year.

I note that you are prepared to sell this boat to ex-pupil Joseph Edgar for $400.00 -- $200 of this amount to be paid this year and the balance next year. I have further noted that you suggest that the Department make a grant of $100.00 to Joseph Edgar to assist him in meeting this year's $200.00 payment.

Very careful consideration has been given to your suggestion but present regulations would not permit our making a grant in the manner that you recommend.

However, the Department would be prepared to purchase materials for the boat building class at a cost not exceeding $100.00. This amount would be over and above any other purchases that we might be making for the Coqualeetza School. In this event you would accept $100.00 from Edgar this year and in addition would receive materials costing $100.00 from the Department. By handling the matter in this way we will not subject ourselves to any criticism from the Auditing Branch. You should, therefore, purchase material for the boat building class at a cost of $100.00 and forward certified accounts in triplicate.

Yours truly,

February 7, 1939

Mr. Huddleston has done, on the occasion of your visit last Spring.

I presume that the request for assistance to provide materials for the reconstruction of two cottages, has reached you through Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, and I trust that it may receive favorable consideration.

The problem of accommodation for married help at Coqualeetza, has always been a pressing one. I pointed out to the Department, shortly after I came, that it seemed impossible to keep efficient help unless this were done. I have tried all the while Mr. Huddleston was away to secure another Bolt Building Instructor, but had failed to locate one whom I thought satisfactory. The applicants were all either too old, or too inexperienced, as something had to be done, I secured the materials to reconstruct a cottage for Mr. Huddleston and one for Mr. Carter our Farm Instructor. The work has been done entirely under the supervision of our Manual Training Staff, by the Senior boys, and it has proved valuable experience. My knowledge of Indian villages, leads me to feel that the one thing necessary is rehabilitation of old houses, and these boys certainly should have caught the vision of what can be done with an old building. The above two cottages have been unoccupied practically ever since I came. We now have two comfortable homes, which I hope will prove an essential factor in maintaining an efficient staff in these two departments.

While the expenditure will run over the $200.00 asked for, still if the Department is good enough to advance us that amount, it will relieve the school of some hardship. I am sure I have your full support in trying to increase the practical side of our instruction, and hope that you will be able to sympathize with me in the situation in which I was placed.

Thanking you for your enquiry, and hoping that this letter will give you all the information required,

I am, Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of January 26th, 1939, file:153-0-11, enquiring as to the qualifications of Mr. R.C. Smith, now engaged as Manual Training Instructor.

Mr. E.W. Lythgoe resigned at the end of last school year, as he preferred teaching in the White schools. I then wrote to Mr. F.G. Baird, Director of Technical Education for the Province, who submitted several names, among which was that of Mr. Smith, who with one other received his special recommendation.

I chose Mr. Smith, and have been well satisfied with his work. He has taken the course for Manual Training Instructors in the Vancouver Technical School. He has for a time, assisted to Mr. Parker, the Principal, in machine work. He is qualified to teach all woodwork subjects, and has had special instruction on hand work and machine work. In addition he has had complete Commercial education of four years, besides three years carpentry experience.

He is twenty-six years of age. I may say that in addition to his work as Manual Training Instructor, Mr. Smith has fitted in to the life of the school very well, and has undertaken his share of house duties on the Boys' Side with entire satisfaction. I am only hoping we shall be able to keep him for a few years, as I am sure, starting as he has now, with so many in the Junior classes, he will have a fine group of students by the time they reach the Senior grades.

Regarding Mr. Huddleston, Assistant Manual Training Instructor, you have perhaps noted that there were no vouchers for him at $40.00 a month, included in our Manual Training Account. That was because we were unfortunate enough to lose his services until December 31st. He is an excellent workman, and I was always afraid we would not be able to hold him. He married about two years ago, and when what seemed like an excellent opportunity opened with the Boeing Company of Vancouver, I could not blame him when he accepted it. However, as you perhaps know, that Company was engaged in a process of re-organization with a view to undertaking extensive aeroplane manufacture. As a result, the employment of Mr. Huddleston was held up so long that it seemed quite problematical as to whether the Company would re-open their Boat Building at all or not. Consequently he wrote to me towards the end of December and offered to return to the school if we could find him house accommodation, and arrange a mutually satisfactory schedule of house duties. As you may imagine, we were most glad to have Mr. Huddleston return, and are laying the keel for a new boat, which will be built by the Senior boys this term. I am sure that this will prove satisfactory to you, as well as to myself, having seen something of the work.

NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C
June 2nd, 1941.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on this agency for the month of May:

The Sardis Indian Preventorium continues to operate smoothly, pending the opening of the new Hospital. I regret to have to report that one of the children, William Phillips, of the Chehalis Indian Reserve, who was taken with tubercular meningitis, died today in the Chilliwack Hospital.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

A. O'N. Daunt.

SIR:-

I beg to report that I duly cleared the operation charges in connection with the Sardis Indian Preventorium, for the month of August, 1941, and under date of September 5th, 1941, submitted Form I.A.181, attached to Agency Voucher No.397 for $529.59, in favour of the New Westminster Indian Agency Trust Account.

The gross per diem costs were $1.04 cents per capita, which is very reasonable.

Statements of these charges, together with the receipted bills from the various Firms, are enclosed, in duplicate, for your information, and records.

With reference to the account from Messrs. McLennan, McFeely & Prior Limited, Chilliwack, for one second hand Jasper range and hot water coil, this was to replace a stove removed from the Preventorium to the Alberni Indian Residential School by Reverend R.C. Scott. The expenditure was authorized by Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner.

I shall be obliged if you will see that the $529.59 paid out, is returned in time to meet the September expenses.
